revision.text:
{{Infobox Olympic games|1940|Summer|Olympics| | image = Poster Olympische Sommerspiele Tokio 1940.jpg | caption = Poster for the 1940 games, when the games were scheduled to be held in Tokyo | host_city = ''[[Helsinki]], Finland'' | opening = ''20 July'' | closing = ''4 August'' | stadium = ''[[Helsinki Olympic Stadium|Helsingin Olympiastadion]]'' | summer_prev = [[1936 Summer Olympics|Berlin 1936]] | summer_next = [[1948 Summer Olympics|London 1948]] →
{{color|grey|London 1944}} | winter_prev = [[1936 Winter Olympics|Garmisch 1936]]
← {{color|grey|Garmisch 1940}} | winter_next = [[1948 Winter Olympics|St. Moritz 1948]] →
{{color|grey|Cortina 1944}} }} The '''1940 Summer Olympics''', officially known as the '''Games of the XII Olympiad''', were originally scheduled to be held from September 21 to October 6, 1940, in [[Tokyo]], [[Empire of Japan|Japan]]. They were rescheduled for [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]], to be held from July 20 to August 4, 1940, but were ultimately cancelled due to the outbreak of [[World War II]]. Helsinki eventually hosted the [[1952 Summer Olympics]] and Tokyo the [[1964 Summer Olympics]]. ==1940 Tokyo Olympics== The campaign to choose a city for 1940 began in 1932, with Barcelona, Rome, Helsinki, and Tokyo participating. Tokyo city officials suggested a campaign as a means of international diplomacy following Japan's alienation from the [[League of Nations]] due to the [[Mukden Incident]], in which Japan occupied [[Manchuria]] and created the puppet state of [[Manchukuo]]. While both Tokyo officials and [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) representatives were behind the campaign, the national government, which was ever more interested in military matters, did not have any strong supporters for such a diplomatic gesture.Sandra Collins. ''The 1940 Tokyo Games: The Missing Olympics: Japan, the Asian Olympics and the Olympic Movement''. p. 51 In 1936, Tokyo was chosen in a surprise move, making it the first non-Western city to win an Olympic bid. ===1930s Japan and international sports=== During the [[1930 Far Eastern Games]] in Tokyo, Indian participants were spotted flying the flag of their independence movement rather than the [[Swaraj flag|flag of British India]]. This caused a complaint from the [[British Olympic Association]]. In 1934 Japan attempted to invite European colonies to the [[Far Eastern Games]].[http://www.tulips.tsukuba.ac.jp/limedio/dlam/M74/M744147/6.pdf Historical Significance of the Far Eastern Championship Games]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Tsukuba University ===Planning=== [[File:Twelfth Tokyo Olympics (1940 Summer Olympics) souvenir handflag, 1936 AD - Edo-Tokyo Museum - Sumida, Tokyo, Japan - DSC06952.jpg|thumb|right|Souvenir flag (1936)]] The main stadium was to be [[Meiji Jingu Stadium]], later used at the [[1964 Summer Olympics]]. The Olympic Village was to be built on the present sites of [[Kinuta Park]] or Todoroki Gorge. A schedule was drawn up, and guidelines were printed in four languages. Monthly magazines and posters were printed and distributed internationally. Construction began on some buildings, and arrangements were made with hotels, travel agents, and airlines for easy access.{{cite web|url=http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1940/OR1940.pdf |title=Report of the Organizing Committee on Its Work for the Xiith Olympic Games of 1940 in Tokyo Until the Relinquishment |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-03-12}} ===Forfeiture of Games=== When the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] broke out on July 7, 1937, [[Kono Ichiro]], a member of the [[National Diet|Diet]] (legislature), immediately requested that the Olympics be forfeited.Sandra Collins. ''The 1940 Tokyo Games: The Missing Olympics: Japan, the Asian Olympics and the Olympic Movement''. p. 144 The [[1938 Far Eastern Games]] were also cancelled, but Japan's IOC delegates persisted under a belief that the war would soon be over.Sandra Collins. ''The 1940 Tokyo Games: The Missing Olympics: Japan, the Asian Olympics and the Olympic Movement''. p. 146 Amid the intensification of the war, the feasibility of both the Summer Olympics and the [[1940 Winter Olympics]] grew increasingly questionable to other countries, who suggested a different site be chosen and spoke of the possibility of boycotting the Games were they to proceed in Japan.Sandra Collins. ''The 1940 Tokyo Games: The Missing Olympics: Japan, the Asian Olympics and the Olympic Movement''. p. 149 In March 1938, the Japanese provided reassurances to the IOC at the organization's Cairo conference that Tokyo would still be able to serve as the host city. However, many Diet members in Japan had already openly questioned hosting the Olympics in wartime, and the military was unreasonably demanding that the organizers build the venues from wood because they needed metals for the war front.橋本一夫『幻の東京オリンピック』（日本放送出版協会、1994年） {{ISBN|4-14-001709-0}} In July, a legislative session was held to decide the matters of the Summer and Winter Olympics and the planned 1940 World's Fair all at once. The World's Fair was only "postponed", under a belief that Japan would be able to wrap up the war, but the Olympics could not be moved and was canceled.Sandra Collins. ''The 1940 Tokyo Games: The Missing Olympics: Japan, the Asian Olympics and the Olympic Movement''. pp. 161–163 [[Kōichi Kido]], who would later be instrumental in the [[surrender of Japan]] in 1945, announced the forfeiture on July 16, 1938. He closed his speech saying, "When peace reigns again in the Far East, we can then invite the Games to Tokyo and take that opportunity to prove to the people of the world the true Japanese spirit." This would come to pass in [[1964 Summer Olympics|1964]]. Despite the cancellation of the 1940 Olympics, the Tokyo organizing committee released its budget for the Games. In a departure from standard practice, the budget included all capital outlays as well as direct organizing costs. The total budget was [[Japanese yen|¥]]20.1 million, one-third of which would have been paid by the Tokyo metropolitan government.{{cite journal | last = Zarnowski | first = C. Frank |date=Summer 1992 | title = A Look at Olympic Costs | journal = Citius, Altius, Fortius | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | pages = 16–32 |url=http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/JOH/JOHv1n1/JOHv1n1f.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2007-03-24}} ==Helsinki and other competitions== [[File:Equipment made in Yleisradio's workshop at the end of the 1930's intended for broadcasting the 1940 Olympics, ca. 1940. (15301312367).jpg|thumb|right|Equipment manufactured by [[Yle]], the Finnish broadcasting company, for the purpose of broadcasting coverage of the 1940 Games]] The IOC then awarded the Games to [[Helsinki]], Finland, the city that had been the runner-up in the original bidding process. The Games were then scheduled to be staged from July 20 to August 4, 1940. The Olympic Games were suspended indefinitely following the outbreak of World War II ([[Winter War]] in particular) and did not resume until the [[1948 Summer Olympics|London Games of 1948]]. With the Olympics cancelled, the major international athletics event of the year turned out to be the annual [[Finland-Sweden athletics international]], held at the new [[Helsinki Olympic Stadium]], exceptionally held as a triple international among [[Finland]], [[Sweden]] and [[Nazi Germany|Germany]]. [[Gliding]] was due to be an Olympic sport in the 1940 Games after a [[demonstration sport|demonstration]] at the [[Gliding at the 1936 Summer Olympics|Berlin]] Games in 1936. {{cite book |last= Welch |first= Ann |title= The Story of Gliding 2nd edition |publisher= [[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray]] |year= 1980 |isbn = 0-7195-3659-6 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.deutsches-museum.de/en/flugwerft/collections/sailplanes/olympia-meise/ |title = Glider design to be used at the 1940 Olympic Games | accessdate = 2008-03-25 }} The sport has not been featured in any Games since, though the glider designed for it, the [[DFS Olympia Meise]], was produced in large numbers after the war. Meanwhile, Japan hosted the [[1940 East Asian Games]] in Tokyo, with six participating nations. Helsinki eventually held the [[1952 Summer Olympics]], while Tokyo held the [[1964 Summer Olympics]] and will hold the [[2020 Summer Olympics]]. During August 1940, prisoners of war celebrated a "special Olympics" called the ''International Prisoner-of-War Olympic Games'' at [[Stalag]] XIII-A in [[Langwasser]], near [[Nuremberg]], Germany. An Olympic flag, 29 by 46 cm in size, was made of a Polish prisoner's shirt and, drawn in crayon, it featured the Olympic rings and banners for Belgium, France, Great Britain, Norway, Poland, and the Netherlands. A feature film, ''[[Olympics 40|Olimpiada '40]]'', produced by the director [[Andrzej Kotkowski]] in 1980 tells the story of these games and of one of the prisoners of war, Teodor Niewiadomski.{{cite journal|last= Grys |first= Iwona |title= The Olympic Idea Transcending War |journal= Olympic Review |volume= 25 |issue= 8 |date= April–May 1996 |pages= 68–69 |url=http://www.la84foundation.org/OlympicInformationCenter/OlympicReview/1996/oreXXV8/oreXXV8zza.pdf |format= PDF |accessdate= 2008-07-31 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080910020833/http://www.la84foundation.org/OlympicInformationCenter/OlympicReview/1996/oreXXV8/oreXXV8zza.pdf| archivedate= 10 September 2008 | deadurl=no}} ==Torch run== {{Main|1940 Summer Olympics torch relay}} Had the 1940 Summer Games been held, a never-before used method of bringing the [[Olympic Flame]] from Nazi Germany to Japan was proposed - by air delivery, in the purpose-built [[Messerschmitt Me 261]] ''Adolfine'' long-range aircraft, which was designed to have a maximum range of some 11,024 km (6,850 mi) unrefueled.{{cite book |title=German Combat Planes |author1=Ray Wagner |author2=Heinz J. Nowarra |year=1971 |publisher=Doubleday |page=312}} ==See also== {{IOC seealso|games=1940 Summer Olympics }} ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1940/OR1940.pdf Official preliminary report. In English] ==Further reading== {{commons category|1940 Summer Olympics}} * International Journal of the History of Sport, vol. 24, 2007, No. 8, ''Special Issue: The Missing Olympics: The 1940 Tokyo Games, Japan, Asia and the Olympic Movement'' {{s-start}} {{s-bef|before=[[1936 Summer Olympics|Berlin]]}} {{s-ttl|title=''[[Summer Olympic Games]]''
[[Tokyo]]/[[Helsinki]] (abandoned)|years=''XII Olympiad (1940)''}} {{s-aft|after=[[1944 Summer Olympics|London]]}} {{s-end}} {{Olympic Games}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1940 Summer Olympics| ]] [[Category:Cancelled Olympic Games]] [[Category:Events cancelled due to World War II]] [[Category:Olympic Games in Japan]] [[Category:Olympic Games in Finland]] [[Category:1940 in multi-sport events]] [[Category:1940 in Japanese sport|Olympic Games]] [[Category:1940 in Finnish sport|Olympic Games]] [[Category:Sports competitions in Tokyo]] [[Category:Sports competitions in Helsinki]] [[Category:Summer Olympics by year]] [[Category:20th century in Tokyo]] [[Category:1940s in Helsinki]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Expand French|Crise constitutionnelle papou-néo-guinéenne de 2011-2012|topic=hist|date=February 2013}} :''More information on this topic can be found in the [[:fr:Crise constitutionnelle papou-néo-guinéenne de 2011-2012|equivalent article]] in the [[French Wikipedia]].'' {{double image|right|Peter O'Neill.jpg|113|Sir Michael Somare - 2009.jpg|117|[[Peter O'Neill]] (left) and [[Michael Somare]] (right)}}
'''2011–2012 Papua New Guinean constitutional crisis''' was a dispute between Sir Michael Somare and Peter O’Neill. Both claimed to be Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea.
O’Neill had been elected by parliament as prime minister on 2 August 2011<ref>Prime Minister Peter O’Neill. Available at: http://www.pm.gov.pg/about/about-2/ No date on posting. Accessed on 1 July 2018</ref> and Sir Michael Somare claimed the post on the basis of a Supreme Court ruling on 12 December 2011.<ref>{{cite news | title=Papua New Guinea in Crisis as two claim to be prime minister | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/14/papua-new-guinea-prime-ministership | date=14 December 2011 | author=Staff and agencies | accessdate=2 September 2018}}</ref> Article 142(2) of the Constitution provides that the Prime Minister is appointed "by the Head of State, acting in accordance with a decision of the Parliament." The Queen’s role is executed by the Governor General.<ref name="const png">Constitution of the Independent State of Papua New Guinea http://www.parliament.gov.pg/constitution-of-the-independent-state-of-papua-new-guinea No date on posting. Accessed on:1 July 2018</ref> The Governor General had therefore to decide on the actual wish of parliament: the opinion identified by O’Neill or the wish as defined by the Supreme Court.
The situation raised important constitutional issues. The actual crisis cannot be understood as a question of law in the first place. It was part of a longer standing power struggle between opposition and government. O’Neill won that struggle and remained the facto in power after the court ruling. It laid the foundation for his dominance in the PNG political arena. Somare did not admit defeat. The 2012 election, however, gave a clear victory to O’Neill. Somare accepted the outcome and he even supported the election of O’Neill as prime minister.<ref>Sean Dorney, Papua New Guinea’s democracy at work http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-08-07/an-sean-png-election-feature/4182648 Posted on: 7 August 2012 Accessed on: 1 July 2018</ref> The conflict flared up again during the O’Neill/Dion government period from 2012 to 2017.
==Prelude: An end to the Somare era?== The government of Michael Somare was already challenged before the constitutional crisis.<ref>R.J. May, Sir Michael Somare and PNG politics. Available at: http://www.devpolicy.org/sir-michael-somare-and-png-politics20110520/ Posted on: 20 May 2011 Accessed on: 1 July 2018</ref> The opposition had tried to mount a motion of no confidence since 2009.<ref>Opposition withdraws no confidence motion. Available at: http://asopa.typepad.com/asopa_people/2009/10/opposition-withdraws-no-confidence-motion.html Posted on: 23/10/2009 Accessed 1 July 2018</ref> This was blocked by the speaker, Geoffrey Nape, through adjourning parliament before the motion could be tabled.<ref>Liam Fox: PNG parliament chaos as Somare dodges no confidence vote Avasilable at: http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2010/s2960384.htm Posted on: 21 July 2010 Accessed on: 1 July 2018</ref> Somare’s reputation was also dented by a leadership tribunal in 2009.<ref>Papua New guinea PM steps down for tribunal. Available at: https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-pacific-11990157 Posted on: 14/12/2010 Accessed on: 1 July 2018</ref> That tribunal, however, treated him lightly.<ref>Sir Michael Suspended. Available at: https://www.thenational.com.pg/sir-michael-suspended/ Posted on: 25 March 2011 Accessed on: 1 July 2018</ref> During the tribunal he appointed Sam Abal as acting Prime Minister. Abal was again acting Prime Minister when Somare was hospitalized in Singapore in March 2011. The position of Prime Minister became particularly opaque when Arthur Somare, a son of Michael Somare and an MP as well, announced in June 2011 on behalf of the family that Somare had spent three weeks in intensive care and could not be expected to resume work as prime minister.<ref>Ailing PNG leader Somare retiring: family. Available at: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-06-28/ailing-png-leader-somare-retiring-family/2775212 Posted on 28 June 2011 Accessed on: 1 July 2018</ref> Arthur Somare positioned himself in this way for the post. The legality and validity of this statement was challenged immediately as Michael Somare had not been heard himself.<ref>Family urges Sir Michael Somare to quit as PNG leader but PM’s office denies resignation. Available at: https://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/sir-michael-somare-quits-as-png-leader/news-story/302839d1a7acbe13740393dac8fbbb61?sv=a8aceb9611d7522f45299c4a246083f8 Posted on 28 June 2011</ref>
In this uncertain situation the opposition mounted another motion of no confidence. The success of such a motion was not certain at all.<ref>Bill Standish: When the Grand chief is away Papua New guinea’s big man politics. http://www.eastasiaforum.org/2011/06/27/when-the-grand-chief-is-away-papua-new-guinea-s-big-man-politics/ Posted on: 27 June 2011</ref> The government of Michael Somare had been established with the support of a large majority in parliament (86 out of 109 votes).<ref>Papua New Guinea PM reelected- Michael Somare wins Second consecutive term in an uncontested vote. https://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia-pacific/2007/08/200852514415744579.html Posted on: 13 August 2007 Accessed on: 1 July 2018</ref> Somare had already lost the support of some MPs when the Supreme Court loosened the restrictions on MPs to change sides. A previous attempt to mount a vote of no confidence by breakaway ministers and MPs led by Puka Temu had been unsuccessful. Somare's majority could only be confidently challenged if there was a revolt in his party, the National Alliance (NA). It was also vital that the Speaker would change sides, as he had obstructed previous attempts. When the speaker did so and allowed an open vote for a new government, the parties supporting the Somare government split. NA divided in a breakaway group itself under the leadership of DonPolye (21 MPs), opposed to a group that remained loyal to Sam Abal and Michael Somare (20 MPs).<ref>PNG National Alliance party suspends Abal http://www.pireport.org/articles/2011/07/26/png-national-alliance-party-suspends-abal Posted on 26 July 2011 Accessed 1 July 2018</ref><ref>More ructions in PNG’s National Alliance. Available at: https://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/198668/more-ructions-in-png%27s-national-alliance Posted on 1 August 2018 Accessed 1 July 2018</ref>
The revolt proved successful. Peter O’Neill became the new Prime Minister with the support of 70MPs out of a 109-member parliament. However, O’Neill's People’s National Congress (PNC) had only six seats in parliament. PNC had supported the Somare government since 2007. Belden Namah and Mekere Morauta of the main opposition PNG party led the revolt, but they did not become prime minister. Namah, the leader of the opposition, became deputy Prime Minister. He had also been part of the Somare government. Don Polye, who had led the revolt in NA, became the Minister for Finance and the Treasury. He had been strongly tipped for the post of Prime Minister.<ref>Bill Standish PNG’s new prime minister: Peter O’Neill. Available at: http://www.eastasiaforum.org/2011/08/11/pngs-new-prime-minister-peter-o-neill/ Posted on 11 August 2011 Accessed on 7 July 2017</ref><ref> Ron May, Papua New Guinea’s "Political Coup": The Ousting of sir Michael Somare. Available at: https://openresearch-repository.anu.edu.au/bitstream/1885/141449/1/BriefNote_2011_1_May_0.pdfPosted on: 1 November 2011 Accessed on: 1 July 2018</ref> It was thus to a large extent a revolt from within.
Mekere Morauta on the contrary had been the prime opponent of the Somare government. He did not become involved in the ensuing struggles surrounding the legality of the first O’Neill government. Instead, he used this position to fight a vigorous cleanup campaign of public enterprises in which he attacked especially the heritage of his predecessor, Arthur Somare.<ref>IPBC: Unfinished Business, Speech by Rt Hon Mekere Morauta KCMG MPMinister for Public Enterprises, Dinner hosted by IPBC, 12 July 2012. Available at: http://www.kch.com.pg/unfinished-business/ Accessed on: 6 November 2017</ref>
==The legal battle== The government of Somare/Abal was not defeated by a motion of no confidence. In that case the position of O’Neill would have been unequivocally covered by law. It is puzzling that instead, the Speaker had allowed a motion to declare the post of Prime Minister vacant because of illness. That possibility was covered in the Constitution in section 142(5,c) on the grounds: "that two medical practitioners appointed by the National Authority responsible for the registration or licensing of medical practitioners have jointly reported in accordance with an Act of the Parliament that, in their professional opinions, the Prime Minister is unfit, by reason of physical or mental incapacity, to carry out the duties of his office."<ref name="const png"/> Parliament had approached the Papua New Guinea Medical Board for such a mission to Singapore at the beginning of Somare’s hospitalization.<ref>R.J. May, Papua New Guinea’s "Political Coup" The Ousting of Michael Somare Briefing note 1/2011 from State, Society and Governance in Melanesia /Australian National University p.3. Available as pdf through: http://dpa.bellschool.anu.edu.au/ssgm-research-communication/discussion-paper-series Accessed: 7 July 2018</ref> Nothing came of that.
The next possibility envisioned concerned the absence of a Member of Parliament, and because the PM is an MP in a Westminster parliamentary system, this is therefore applicable to the Prime Minister. The relevant section 104 (d) of the Constitution reads: "if he is absent, without leave of the Parliament, during the whole of three consecutive meetings of the Parliament unless Parliament decides to waive this rule upon satisfactory reasons being given".<ref name="const png"/>
Somare had been absent since March but his reasons were accepted by parliament and he was granted leave until May 2012. Parliament then withdrew this leave. However, in early September Somare returned to PNG and declared that he was willing and able to finish his term of prime minister. On 6 September he made a brief appearance in the chamber and therefore the rule of missing three consecutive meetings no longer applied.<ref>R.J. May, Papua New Guinea’s "Political Coup" The Ousting of Michael Somare Briefing note 1/2011 from State, Society and Governance in Melanesia /Australian National University p.4. Available as pdf through: http://dpa.bellschool.anu.edu.au/ssgm-research-communication/discussion-paper-series Accessed: 7 July 2018</ref> On 9 December, Parliament amended the law to state that an absence of ninety days would make a parliamentary seat vacant.<ref> Peter Donigi, Constitutional Technicalities: Why is O’Neill is PNG’s Prime Minister. Available at: https://garamut.wordpress.com/2011/12/28/constitutional-technacalities-why-oneill-is-pngs-prime-minister/ Posted on 28/12/2011Accessed on: 7 July 2018</ref> The Supreme Court would give a judgment on the legality of the O’Neill government on 12 December 2011.
The Supreme Court came unequivocally down on the side of Somare. There was no legal vacancy in the office of Prime Minister when O’Neill was elected. The Speaker’s decision to declare a vacancy in Somare’s parliamentary seat in East Sepik was similarly unconstitutional and void. Somare should have been reinstated as Prime Minister.{{clarify|date=October 2018|reason=Is this a statement of legality or opinion?}}<ref> Anthony Latimer, PNG constitutional crisis. Available at: http://www.nortonrosefulbright.com/knowledge/publications/61068/png-constitutional-crisis Posted on: December 2011. Accessed on: 7 July 2018 </ref>
The factual situation did not change: O’Neill remained in charge. The Supreme Court heard the case again in May 2012 and came again down in favor of O’Neill. The deputy speaker accepted the Supreme court ruling, but declared the seat again immediately vacant on the ground that Somare had been absent for 90 days. He referred to the change in law that parliament had passed on 9 December just before the Supreme Court's decision. O’Neill was therefore again elected as Prime Minister.<ref>Nick Perkins, Judicial Independence around the world. Available at: https://constitution-unit.com/2012/06/08/judicial-independence-across-the-world-papua-new-guinea/ Posted on 8 June 2012</ref>
The Supreme Court ignored the change of law of 9 December 2011. It was also not valid on 12 December, as the Speaker of Parliament still had to certify the change of law. This brought to the fore the issue of constitutional law. The Constitution stresses separation of powers. According to those on the side of O’Neill, this implies that the Court cannot exercise executive decision making. The constitutional court can only judge on the constitutionality of a law or general measure. In this case, they were seen to encroach on the power of parliament. The legal battle was a conflict on the sovereignty of parliament.<ref>Peter Donigi, Constitutional Technicalities: Why is O’Neill is PNG’s Prime Minister. Available at: https://garamut.wordpress.com/2011/12/28/constitutional-technacalities-why-oneill-is-pngs-prime-minister/ Posted on 28/12/2011Accessed on: 7 July 2018</ref>
==The political battle== The essence of the PNG constitutional crisis in 2011-2012 was thus whether parliament was supreme or whether the separation of powers implied that parliament was under control of the judiciary. This was not in the first place a legal battle, but a political one. It was a struggle for political support. The O’Neill/Namah government obtained that support immediately in August 2011. The PM and cabinet were recognized by the Crown through the Governor-General, Michael Ogio. It also immediately gained international recognition, and the approval of Australia was especially vital.<ref>Gregory B. Poling: Constitutional crisis erupts in Papua New Guinea. Available at: https://www.csis.org/analysis/constitutional-crisis-erupts-papua-new-guinea Posted on: 16/12/2011 Accessed on 18 July 201</ref>
There remained some pockets that were loyal to Michael Somare. For example, the court case challenging the legality of the O’Neill/Namah government was opened by the Provincial government of East Sepik, the home base of the Somare family.<ref>Bill Standish: Crises compounded; Papua New Guinea politics in November 2011 Available. at: http://www.devpolicy.org/crises-compounded-papua-new-guinea-politics-in-november-2011-20111114/ Posted on: 14 November 2011 Accessed on 18 July 2018</ref> Nevertheless, the O’Neill/Namah government seemed safe. The judgment of the Supreme Court on 12 December 2011 was therefore a shock.
Somare immediately announced a new cabinet and had his cabinet sworn in by the Governor General. Somare himself did in his opinion not need to be sworn in, as that had happened already when he became PM again in 2007. Parliament protested strongly against this. Ogio was suspended and the speaker of parliament, Jeffrey Nape, became acting Governor General. Nape then swore in O’Neill and his cabinet. Civil society organisations, especially churches, offered to mediate.<ref>Churches, civil societies seek a collaborative route out of PNG political impasse. Available at: https://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/201521/churches,-civil-society-seek-collaborative-route-out-of-png-political-impasse Posted on: 16/12/2011 Accessed on 18 July 2018</ref> O’Neill refused on the ground that it is up to parliament to form the government and not forces outside the chamber.
Somare did not come into parliament and was with his cabinet in an Ela Beach hotel. He had the support of about 20 MPs.
Ogio was therefore supporting a government that did not have a majority on parliament and his position became thus untenable. He changed his mind and supported the O’Neill government. Parliament ended his suspension.<ref>"Governor-General Michael Ogio suspended for backing Michael Somare". Available at: http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news /world/governor-general-michael-ogio-suspended-for-backing-michael-somare/story-e6frg6so-1226222379427 The Australian, 15 December 2011 Accessed: 16 July 2015</ref><ref>"End of PNG GGs suspension". Available at: http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/201598/end-of-png's-gg-suspension-weakens-somare-bid-for-power Radio New Zealand Inernational 19/12/2011 Accessed on: 17 July 2018</ref>
The dispute was about the power of parliament, but this does not mean that the conflict was fought with parliamentary procedures. For example, MPs stormed the house of the Governor-General when he supported Somare. It is thus not surprising that control over the police was one of the main issues during the stalemate. Somare immediately appointed Fred Yakasa as police commander. Yakasa controlled the armed response unit of the police. That unit had remained loyal to Somare and had prevented O’Neill from entering the Governor-General’s office (government house). O’Neill relied on his own appointment: Thomas Kulunga. Yakasa turned to the courts and got a restraining order that he was not to be harassed. The threat of arrest was no longer there, but Kulunga disarmed Yakasa’s unit a few days later.<ref>Rowan Callick, Judge to protect police chief after claims his actions "border on treason". Available at: https://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/somare-appointee-found-legal-commissioner/news-story/9262b1f8cce983f71af0fa4ddb533b92?sv=65e1eae05ab3be92442532a86972b4e6 Posted on:18/12/2011 Accessed on: 17 July 2011</ref><ref> Kulunge asserts his position. Available at: http://www.pireport.org/articles/2011/12/20/kulunga-asserts-his-position-png-police-commissioner Posted on 20/12/2011 Accessed on: 17 July 2011</ref>
O’Neill had control over parliament, the public service, the police and the army. Nevertheless, Somare did not accept his defeat. At the end of January he walked into parliament showing the court order and demanding a seat. O’Neill replied with a threat of arrest.<ref>Liam Fox: Rowdy scenes as Somare returns to parliament. Available at: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-01-18/somare-could-be-arrested/3781442 Posted on: 18 January 2011 Accessed on: 17 July 2011</ref>
The control over the army was challenged towards the end of January. A retired army officer, Colonel Yaura Sasa, claimed to have been appointed as army commander by Somare. He stormed the main barracks in Port Moresby with a group of soldiers, and took the army commander Frances Agwi hostage. Sasa presented his intervention as an attempt to mediation: he wanted to force both parties to return to parliament and forge a consensus. Vice president Belden Namah, a former ex army officer, announced the arrest of 15 of the 30 soldiers involved as well as the arrest of Sasa.<ref>Liam Fox: Rebel soldiers stage mutiny in PNG. Available at: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-01-26/military-mutiny-underway-in-png/3794314 Posted on 26 January 2012 Accessed on: 17 July 2011</ref><ref>Liam Fox: PNG leader claims end to mutiny. Available at: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-01-26/png-story/3795348 Posted on: 26 January 2012 accessed on: 17 July 2011</ref>
The fight to control the judiciary was the most bitter fight of the O’Neill government. It was originally fought on grounds that were not germane to the issue of legitimacy of the O’Neill government. The National Executive Council has no power over the appointment of judges; that is a prerogative of the Legal and Judicial Services Commission. The NEC (Cabinet), however, has the power of appointment over the Chief Justice and it used these powers during the constitutional crisis.
Chief Sir Injia Salamo was dismissed in early November on various grounds of personal misbehaviour. The main claim was stealing from the estate of a deceased judge entrusted to the courts. This was one month before the Supreme Court had to rule over the constitutionality of the O’Neill/Nama government.<ref>Bill Standish: Crises compounded; Papua New Guinea politics in November 2011 Available at: http://www.devpolicy.org/crises-compounded-papua-new-guinea-politics-in-november-2011-20111114/ Posted on: 14 November 2011 Accessed on 18 July 2018</ref> The Supreme Court reacted with a charge of contempt of court for the attorney general Alan Marat and the deputy PM Belden Namah. The police commander followed this up and detained them briefly.<ref>PNG court orders arrests of two MPS. Available at: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-11-11/court-orders-arrest-of-png-mps/3660584PNG Posted on: 11 November 2011 Accessed on: 18 July 2018</ref> The move against Injia Salamo was made under the leadership of the deputy Prime minister, Belden Namah.
O’Neill was at the time out of the country and declared himself not in sympathy, but he assuaged the situation by declaring that under the constitution the Chief Justice could continue to sit on the bench despite disciplinary procedures against him. The NEC withdrew the charges.<ref name="fox stand">Liam Fox: PNG stand by decision to suspend top judge. Available at: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-11-13/png-stands-by-decision-to-suspend-top-judge/3663198 Posted on: 13 November 2011 Accessed on: 18 July 2018</ref>
The Supreme Court comprising all five judges met on 12 December 2011 and decided that the seat of PM as well as of MP in East Sepik were not vacant and O’Neill’s position was unlawful. The court came down in the case against O’Neill with a three to two majority.<ref name="fox stand"/>
The Governor General proceeded to recognise the Somare government while parliament continued to support O’Neill. The court decision was ignored by the O’Neil government and ultimately the Governor General also gave in. The government was not satisfied and pursued the conflict with the Supreme Court further. In February there was another attempt to suspend the Chief Justice on grounds of personal misbehaviour, and a panel of judges was mentioned to look at misconduct by Injia Salomo. This charge was stayed shortly thereafter by the National Court. Despite this, Salomo was forcibly arrested on 6 March and charged. The National Court met on 13 March on the case and permanently stayed the charges, as these were flawed.<ref> Justice Logan: A year in the life of an Australian member of the PNG Judiciary. Available at: http://www.fedcourt.gov.au/digital-law-library/judges-speeches/justice-logan/logan-j-20130415 Posted on: 15 April 2013 Accessed on 18 July 2018</ref>
Thereafter the government tried a new tack to get rid of the Supreme Court judges, and announced a Judicial Conduct Bill that brought disciplining the judiciary effectively under political control instead of under the control of the Judicial Service Commission. Very soon after enacting the law two Supreme Court judges, Injia and Nicholas Kiriwom, were mentioned for disciplinary action to the Governor-General. Kiriwom had organised a protest meeting against the treatment of Injia. This led to widespread protests in the country, such as a massive student protest march.<ref>Tarvurvur: Why the judicial conduct Act 2012 is dangerous. Available at https://garamut.wordpress.com/2012/03/29/why-the-judicial-conduct-act-2012-is-dangerous/ Posted on 29 March 2012 Accessed on 18 July 2018</ref>
The Supreme Court proceeded to hear the case again as to whether O’Neill was the lawful prime minister. The government asked Injia and another justice to recuse themselves from the case because of personal interests in the case. That, similar to the arrest under the Judicial Conduct Bill, would have reduced the votes against O’Neill to a single one.
At the end of May 2012 the Supreme Court decided and came down again in favour of Somare, this time with three out of five judges while two withheld judgment. Belden Namah, the deputy PM, stormed the court and took Injia Solomon and Nichlas Kirwonto in detention. The government charged them with sedition on the accusation that they had created chaos in the country.<ref>Nick Perkins, Judicial Independence around the world: Papua New Guinea. Available at: https://constitution-unit.com/2012/06/08/judicial-independence-across-the-world-papua-new-guinea/ Posted on: 8 June 2012 Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref>
In the meantime elections were looming and these would be the definite determinant who would rule PNG. That line was strongly taken by the new Australian Minister of Foreign Affairs, Bob Carr.<ref>Daniel Flitton: Carr threatens to hit PNG with sanctions. Available at: https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/carr-threatens-to-hit-png-with-sanctions-20120315-1v3zs.html Posted on: 15 March 2011 Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref> There were strong forces to postpone the elections. Parliament of PNG even voted for a delay of six months. However, the decision to hold elections was in the hands of the Electoral Commission. There was widespread protest against this proposal.<ref>AAP: PNG defied Carr to postpone vote. Available at: https://www.news.com.au/world/png-defies-carr-to-postpone-vote/news-story/a4d2655af51c998e1f5f057ed10e0152 Posted on: 5 April 2011</ref><ref>Liam Fox, PNG pressured over election date. Available at: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-04-23/png-pressured-over-election-date/3965708 Posted on: 23 April 2012</ref> The plan to postpone was shelved. By the time the second Supreme Court decision was taken, parliament was dissolved and electioneering was in full swing.<ref>Liam Fox, PNG court ordered Somare to be reinstated, Posted on 22 May 2012. Available at: http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2012/s3507867.htm Posted on: 22 May 2012 Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref>
==Conclusion: the long-term effects==
Peter O’Neill’s party obtained most seats in the 2012 and 2017 elections and therefore he had the right to form a government. A clear majority coalition in parliament elected him as prime minister in both cases. He faced many legal challenges on governance grounds, which he successfully deflected. The only case where the executive was defeated was over the challenge over the Manus Island detention centre, which the courts declared unconstitutional.<ref>Madeline Geeson: PNG court decision forces Australia to act on Manus Island detainees. Available at: https://theconversation.com/png-court-decision-forces-australia-to-act-on-manus-island-detainees-58439 Posted on: 27 April 2016 Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref>
However, that did not challenge the right of O’Neill to his position. The power structure established during the constitutional crisis of 2011-2012 proved to be enduring: a politician who has the support of a clear majority in parliament can dominate over the whole government apparatus, including the courts.<ref>Papua New Guinea under the O’Neill government. Has there been a shift in political style. Available at: http://ssgm.bellschool.anu.edu.au/sites/default/files/publications/attachments/2017-08/dp_2017_6_may.pdf Posted on: 16 July 2017 Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref>
Somare's National Alliance Party was truncated from 20 to 6 seats in 2012. It was a surprise that he supported the coalition behind O’Neill despite his great enmity with O’Neill before the election.<ref>PNG leaders Somare and O’Neill form joint Government. Available at: https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-18979412 Posted on: 25 July 2012 Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref> Somare never did really accept his defeat in 2011. He reached an out of court settlement of one million Australian dollars as indemnity for his illegal removal from office in 2011.<ref>Liam Cochrane: PNG ‘s ousted prime minister paid almost $ one million for "illegal removal". Available at: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-08-12/png-ousted-prime-minister-paid-1-million-for-ilegal-removal/6690936 Posted on: 13 August 2015 Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref>
In November 2014 Somare withdrew his support for the ruling coalition. He advocated that Peter O’Neill should face a leadership tribunal because of his handling of the controversial UBS loan to acquire equity in the Oil Search company.<ref>Sir Michael Somare MP, Why I moved to the middle bench http://www.pngblogs.com/2014/11/why-i-moved-to-middle-bench.html Posted on: 25 November 2014. Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref> In November 2016 he resigned from the National Alliance Party.<ref>Girish Sawiani, Michael Somare resigns from the Papua New Guinea Party he founded. Available at: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-10-12/michael-somare-resigns-from-papua-new-guinea-party-he-founded/6848060 Posted on:7 February 2016 Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref> Almost immediately after that he proclaimed jointly with his old foe Mekere Morauta the need for investigation of O’Neill’s handling of the UBS loan by international and local agencies because of the alleged fraudulent nature of the deal.<ref>Helen Davidson: Papua New Guinea prime minister must resign say former leaders. Available: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/20/papua-new-guinea-prime-minister-peter-oneill-must-resign-say-three-former-leaders Posted on:20 July 2016 Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref>
Somare decided no longer to stand for office in the 2017 election and retired from politics. His most prominent son Arthur had lost his Sepik seat in 2012 and did not run in 2017. Dulianan Somare Brash, his youngest daughter, contested the West Sepik regional seat that had been secure for Michael Somare in his whole career; she lost. The constitutional crisis led to a decline of the Somare clan that may be final.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}}
The National Alliance Party (NA) survived the split in 2011.<ref>Blair Price: NA splits after Somare dismissal. Available at: https://www.pngindustrynews.net/government/news/1102868/na-splits-after-somare-dismissal?source=pngindustrynews Posted on:9 September 2011. Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref> It still gains most of its seats in the highlands, but it became a very different entity. It survived the departure of the Somare family, and in the 2017 elections they were the second largest party.
The loyalists to Somare succeeded in the expulsion of Don Polye and his friends. Polye founded the True Heritage Empowerment Rural Party (THE). THE party was second in the 2012 elections, with 12 seats. Polye became treasury minister but fell foul of O’Neill. Polye, as minister of the treasury, refused to sign the UBS loan to buy back the OilSearch shares that had ben lost in a previous financial deal. Polye considered it economically disastrous and the procedure unconstitutional: parliament needed to be consulted. Peter O'Neill sacked Polye and appointed himself as minister of the treasury.<ref>Prime Minister pushes through controversial loan. Available at: http://country.eiu.com/article.aspx?articleid=1061683290 Posted on: 1 April 2014 Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref> Polye did therefore not resign but was sacked.<ref>https://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/238680/sacked-png-treasurer-admits-differences-with-pm-over-loan</ref> <ref>Liam Cochrane. PNG Prime minister O’Neill sacks treasurer for causing instability. Available at: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-03-11/an-png-pm-sacks-treasurer-polye/5311526 Posted on 10 March 2014 Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref><ref>https://www.thenational.com.pg/polye-clarifies-reason-for-sacking/</ref> In the 2017 elections Polye lost his seat and THE party gained only three seats.<ref>https://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-05-03/png-opposition-leader-steps-down-after-his-election-win-disputed/7380126</ref>
Belden Namah, the deputy prime minister, was relegated to the opposition after 2012. He has since been the accused in several court cases and tribunals.<ref> Bonnie Kaiyo: Belden Namah: Tribunal- the development and drama. Available at: http://news.pngfacts.com/2017/11/belden-namah-tribunal-developments-and.html No date for posting Accessed on: 12 July 2018</ref>
Mekere Morauta resigned from politics in 2012, but came back to challenge O'Neill.<ref>‘PNG’s Morauta slams O’Neill on the economy’ Radio New Zealand 04/24/2016. Available at: http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/304690/png%27s-morauta-slams-o%27neill-on-the-economy Accessed 31 July 2017</ref><ref>‘Sir Mekere announces nomination’ Posted on 04/25/2017 on https://www.mekeremorauta.net/single-post/2017/04/25/Sir-Mekere-announces-nomination Accessed on: 31 July 2017</ref> He won his seat,<ref>Eric Haurupma Sir Mekere Morauta officially declared member elect for Port Moresby North West. Available at: http://www.emtv.com.pg/news/2017/07/sir-mekere-morauta-officially-declared-member-elect-for-moresby-north-west/Posted on: 07/27/2017 Accessed on: 31 July 2017</ref> but the grand coalition against O’Neill did not come off.<ref>Move by Basil is disappointing. Available at: https://www.mekeremorauta.net/single-post/2017/09/12/Move-by-Basil-is-disappointing-Sir-Mekere Posted on: 2 September 2017 Accessed on: 31 July 2017</ref> O’Neill has dominated the political competition since 2011 and the other protagonists in the constitutional crisis have been overshadowed.<ref>Rowan Callick, How Peter O'Neill dominates PNG's political landscape Available at: http://rowancallick.com/how-pm-peter-oneill-dominates-pngs-political-landscape/ Posted on:07/04/2015</ref>

{{refimprove|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox football match | title = 2016 Copa Sudamericana Finals | event = [[2016 Copa Sudamericana]]
''(2016 Copa Sul-Americana)'' | team1 = [[Atlético Nacional]] | team1association = {{flagicon|COL|size=30px}} | team1score = | team2 = [[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]] | team2association = {{flagicon|BRA|size=30px}} | team2score = | details = Cancelled due to crash of [[LaMia Flight 2933]]
Title awarded to Chapecoense | firstleg = First leg | team1score1 = | team2score1 = | details1 = | date1 = 30 November 2016 (cancelled) | stadium1 = [[Atanasio Girardot Sports Complex|Estadio Atanasio Girardot]] | city1 = [[Medellín]] | referee1 = | attendance1 = | secondleg = Second leg | team1score2 = | team2score2 = | details2 = | date2 = 7 December 2016 (cancelled) | stadium2 = [[Estádio Couto Pereira]] | city2 = [[Curitiba]] | referee2 = | attendance2 = | previous = [[2015 Copa Sudamericana Finals|2015]] | next = [[2017 Copa Sudamericana Finals|2017]] }} The '''2016 Copa Sudamericana Finals''' were scheduled to be the two-legged final that would decide the winner of the [[2016 Copa Sudamericana]], the 15th edition of the [[Copa Sudamericana]], [[South America]]'s secondary international club [[association football|football]] tournament organized by [[CONMEBOL]]. The finals were scheduled to be contested in two-legged home-and-away format between Colombian team [[Atlético Nacional]] and Brazilian team [[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]]. The first leg was scheduled to be hosted by Atletico Nacional at [[Atanasio Girardot Sports Complex|Estadio Atanasio Girardot]] in [[Medellín]] on 30 November 2016, while the second leg was scheduled to be hosted by Chapecoense at [[Estádio Couto Pereira]] in [[Curitiba]] on 7 December 2016. The winner would earn the right to play against the [[2016 Copa Libertadores]] winners in the [[2017 Recopa Sudamericana]], and against the [[2016 J. League Cup]] winners in the [[2017 Suruga Bank Championship]].{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/sites/default/files/copa_sudamericana_2016_-_reglamento.pdf|title=Copa Sudamericana 2016 – Reglamento|language=Spanish|publisher=CONMEBOL.com}} They also automatically qualified for the [[2017 Copa Libertadores]] group stage. The finals were suspended after the crash of [[LaMia Flight 2933]], carrying the majority of the [[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]] squad on their way to the first leg of the finals.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-38140981|title=Brazil football team Chapecoense in Colombia plane crash|publisher=BBC|date=29 November 2016}} CONMEBOL awarded the title to [[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]] on 5 December 2016, following a request by [[Atlético Nacional]]. ==Teams== {| class="wikitable" |- !Team !Previous finals appearances (bold indicates winners) |- |{{flagicon|COL}} [[Atlético Nacional]] |2 ([[2002 Copa Sudamericana Finals|2002]], [[2014 Copa Sudamericana Finals|2014]]) |- |{{flagicon|BRA}} [[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]] |None |} [[Atlético Nacional]] would have the chance to complete the [[Copa Libertadores]] and [[Copa Sudamericana]] season double, having won the Copa Libertadores title earlier in [[2016 Copa Libertadores Finals|2016]], while this would be the first South American club final for [[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]]. ===Road to the finals=== {{details|2016 Copa Sudamericana}} ''Note: In all scores below, the score of the home team is given first.'' {|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !colspan=3|{{flagicon|COL}} [[Atlético Nacional]] !Round !colspan=3|{{flagicon|BRA}} [[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]] |-bgcolor=#c1e0ff |width=25%|Opponent |width=10%|Venue |width=10%|Score |width=10%|[[2016 Copa Sudamericana elimination stages|Elimination stages]] |width=25%|Opponent |width=10%|Venue |width=10%|Score |- |rowspan=2 align=left|{{flagicon|PER}} [[Deportivo Municipal]]

The final would be played on a home-and-away [[two-legged tie|two-legged]] basis, with the higher-seeded team hosting the second leg. If tied on aggregate, the [[away goals rule]] would not be used, and 30 minutes of [[extra time (association football)|extra time]] would be played. If still tied after extra time, the [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shoot-out]] would be used to determine the winner.
==LaMia Flight 2933 crash== {{Main|LaMia Flight 2933}} On 28 November 2016, LaMia Flight 2933, carrying the [[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]] squad to the first leg, crashed on the way to the [[José María Córdova International Airport]].{{cite web|last1=Weaver|first1=Matthew|last2=Walker|first2=Bonnie|title=Brazilian football team Chapecoense on plane that crashed in Colombia|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2016/nov/29/brazilian-team-chapecoense-onboard-plane-that-crashed-over-colombia-latest|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=29 November 2016}}{{cite web|title=76 confirmed dead in Colombian plane crash|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/11/29/americas/colombia-plane-accident/index.html|publisher=Cable News Network|accessdate=29 November 2016}} There were 71 fatalities, including 19 of the 22 Chapecoense players on the plane.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-38155840|title=Chapecoense plane crash: The victims, the survivors and those left behind|publisher=BBC|date=1 December 2016}} CONMEBOL immediately suspended all activities, including the scheduled final matches, in the early morning of 29 November.{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/es/comunicado-la-opinion-publica|title=Comunicado a la opinión pública|publisher=CONMEBOL|date=29 November 2016|language=Spanish}} In light of these events, [[Atlético Nacional]] requested that CONMEBOL award the title to [[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]].{{cite web|title=Campeón de la Sudamericana|url=http://www.atlnacional.com.co/ultimas-noticias/campeon-de-la-sudamericana-015298|publisher=Atlético Nacional de Medellín|accessdate=29 November 2016|language=Spanish|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170129192510/http://www.atlnacional.com.co/ultimas-noticias/campeon-de-la-sudamericana-015298|archive-date=2017-01-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} As requested, CONMEBOL awarded Chapecoense the title of the 2016 Copa Sudamericana, their first continental title, on 5 December,{{cite web|title=Chape é declarada campeã e garante ao menos US$ 4,8 mi em premiações|url=http://globoesporte.globo.com/sc/futebol/times/chapecoense/noticia/2016/12/chape-e-declarada-campea-e-garante-ao-menos-us-48-mi-em-premiacoes.html|publisher=globo.com|accessdate=5 December 2016|language=Portuguese}} while Atlético Nacional received the "CONMEBOL Centenario Fair Play" award for their gesture.{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/es/conmebol-otorga-el-titulo-de-campeon-de-la-sudamericana-2016-chapecoense-y-reconoce-atletico |title=CONMEBOL otorga el título de Campeón de la Sudamericana 2016 a Chapecoense y reconoce a Atlético Nacional con el premio del Centenario de la Conmebol al Fair Play |publisher=CONMEBOL.com |date=5 December 2016 |language=Spanish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161206042227/http://www.conmebol.com/es/conmebol-otorga-el-titulo-de-campeon-de-la-sudamericana-2016-chapecoense-y-reconoce-atletico |archivedate=6 December 2016 }}{{citeweb|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/05/chapecoense-copa-sudamericana-champions|title=Chapecoense named Copa Sudamericana winners after plane crash|date=5 December 2016|work=Guardian|accessdate=5 December 2016}} ==Matches== ===First leg===
{{Football box |id=Atlético Nacional v Chapecoense |date={{Start date|2016|11|30|df=y}} |time={{UTZ|18:45|-5}} |team1=[[Atlético Nacional]] {{flagicon|COL}} |score=Cancelled |team2={{flagicon|BRA}} [[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]] |goals1= |goals2= |stadium=[[Atanasio Girardot Sports Complex|Estadio Atanasio Girardot]], [[Medellín]] |attendance= |referee= |report=http://estadisticas.conmebol.com/html/v3/index.html?channel=deportes.futbol.sudamericana.364982&lang=es_LA }}
[[File:Estadio Atanasio Girardot-Medellin.JPG|thumb|Estadio Atanasio Girardot in Medellín, Colombia, was scheduled to host the first leg.]] Atlético Nacional invited fans to the [[Atanasio Girardot Sports Complex|Estadio Atanasio Girardot]] dressed in white with candles at the scheduled time of the first leg, to pay tribute in memory to the victims of the crash.{{cite web|url=http://www.atlnacional.com.co/ultimas-noticias/de-luto-015304|title=De Luto|publisher=Atlético Nacional|date=29 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/es/homenaje-chapecoense-en-medellin|title=Homenaje a Chapecoense en Medellín|publisher=CONMEBOL.com|date=30 November 2016}} A vigil was held on the same night at Chapecoense's stadium, the [[Arena Condá]].{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/es/y-chapeco-le-canto-su-pena-infinita|title=Y Chapecó le cantó a su pena infinita|publisher=CONMEBOL.com|date=30 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-38166681|title=Colombia plane crash: Thousands gather for vigils|publisher=BBC|date=1 December 2016}} {{clear}} ===Second leg===
{{Football box |id=Chapecoense v Atlético Nacional |date={{Start date|2016|12|7|df=y}} |time={{UTZ|21:45|-2}} |team1=[[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]] {{flagicon|BRA}} |score=Cancelled |team2={{flagicon|COL}} [[Atlético Nacional]] |goals1= |goals2= |stadium=[[Estádio Couto Pereira]], [[Curitiba]] |attendance= |referee= |report=http://estadisticas.conmebol.com/html/v3/index.html?channel=deportes.futbol.sudamericana.364983&lang=es_LA }}
[[Image:CP2.jpg|thumb|Estadio Couto Pereira in Curitiba, Brazil, was scheduled to host the second leg, as Chapecoense's stadium, [[Arena Condá]] in [[Chapecó]], does not have a capacity for 40,000 spectators, as required by CONMEBOL.{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/es/copa-sudamericana-chapecoense-hara-de-local-en-la-final-en-el-estadio-couto-pereira-de-curitiba|title=Copa Sudamericana: Chapecoense hará de local en la final en el estadio "Couto Pereira", de Curitiba|publisher=CONMEBOL.com|date=25 November 2016}}]] Services were held in both the [[Estádio Couto Pereira]], and Chapecoense's stadium, the [[Arena Condá]], on the night that the second leg was scheduled.{{cite web|url=http://www.chapecoense.com/2016/noticias/363|title=Chapecó e Curitiba se unem em homenagens|publisher=Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|date=7 December 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://veja.abril.com.br/esporte/estadio-couto-pereira-fica-lotado-em-homenagem-a-chapecoense/|title=Estádio Couto Pereira fica lotado em homenagem à Chapecoense|publisher=veja.com|date=7 December 2016}} {{clear}} ==See also== {{commonscat|2016 Copa Sudamericana}} * [[2017 Recopa Sudamericana]] * [[2017 Suruga Bank Championship]] * [[List of accidents involving sports teams]] {{portal bar|Current events|Death|Colombia|Disasters|Soccer|Brazil}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * revision.comment: added a sentence about this being the first convention to award the John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer
revision.text:
{{Infobox convention | name = Torcon II, the 31st World Science Fiction Convention | image = | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = [[Fairmont Royal York|Royal York Hotel]] | location = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] | country = Canada | first = August 31-September 3, 1973 | last = | organizer = | filing = non-profit | attendance = 2,900 | website = }} The '''31st World Science Fiction Convention''', also known as '''Torcon II''', was held August 31 – September 3, 1973, at the [[Fairmont Royal York|Royal York Hotel]] in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada. The chairman was [[John Millard]]. The guests of honor were [[Robert Bloch]] (pro) and [[William Rotsler]] (fan). The toastmaster was [[Lester del Rey]]. Total attendance was approximately 2,900. == Awards == {{About-Hugos}} ===Hugo Awards=== * [[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Best Novel]]: ''[[The Gods Themselves]]'' by [[Isaac Asimov]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novella|Best Novella]]: "[[The Word for World is Forest]]" by [[Ursula K. Le Guin]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novelette|Best Novelette]]: "[[Goat Song]]" by [[Poul Anderson]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Short Story|Best Short Story]]: ** "[[Eurema's Dam]]" by [[R. A. Lafferty]] and ** "[[The Meeting (short story)|The Meeting]]" by [[Frederik Pohl]] and [[Cyril M. Kornbluth]] (tie) * [[Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation|Best Dramatic Presentation]]: ''[[Slaughterhouse-Five (film)|Slaughterhouse-Five]]'' * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Editor|Best Professional Editor]]: [[Ben Bova]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Artist|Best Professional Artist]]: [[Frank Kelly Freas]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Amateur Magazine|Best Amateur Magazine]]: ''[[Energumen (magazine)|Energumen]]'' edited by [[Mike Glicksohn]] and [[Susan Wood Glicksohn]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Writer|Best Fan Writer]]: [[Terry Carr]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Artist|Best Fan Artist]]: [[Tim Kirk]] ===Other awards=== The 31st Worldcon was the first one in which the [[John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer]] was awarded. * [[Worldcon Special Award|Special Award]]: [[Pierre Versins]] for ''[[L'Encyclopedie de l'Utopie et de la science fiction]]'' * [[John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer]]: [[Jerry Pournelle]] ==See also== *[[World Science Fiction Society]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web|work=The Hugo Awards |title=1973 Hugo Awards |publisher=[[World Science Fiction Society]] |url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1973-hugo-awards/ |accessdate=March 4, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yVVBdci0?url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1973-hugo-awards/ |archivedate=May 7, 2011 }} {{cite news |work=[[The Financial Post]] |title=Coming Events |page=13 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FGs_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=alQMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4668,648127&dq=toronto+world-science-fiction&hl=en |date=July 28, 1973 |accessdate=March 4, 2011}} }} == External links == * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/TheLongList.html NESFA.org: The Long List] * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/LongListNotes.html#1973 NESFA.org: 1973 convention notes] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[30th World Science Fiction Convention]]
L.A.Con I in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], United States (1972) | title = [[List of Worldcons]] | years = '''31st World Science Fiction Convention'''
Torcon II in [[Toronto]], Canada (1973) | after = [[32nd World Science Fiction Convention]]
Discon II in [[Washington, D.C.]], United States (1974) }} {{s-end}} {{World Science Fiction Convention}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Science Fiction Convention 031}} [[Category:1973 in Canada]] [[Category:World Science Fiction Convention]] [[Category:Science fiction conventions in Canada]] [[Category:1973 conferences]] {{sf-convention-stub}}

page.title: A Night of Horror International Film Festival

revision.comment: Typo fixing, replaced: An an → In an, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: l’s → l's (2)
revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} {{Infobox Film Festival | name = A Night of Horror International Film Festival | image = | caption = | number = | location = [[Sydney, Australia]] | language = English | website = {{url|http://anightofhorror.com}} }}
'''A Night of Horror International Film Festival''' is a horror genre film festival that is based in Sydney, Australia.<ref>[https://filmfreeway.com/festival/ANightOfHorror Filmfreeway.com]</ref>
There seems to be some consensus that the event is Australia's premiere, and possibly only, horror film festival. In his monthly column in ''Encore Magazine'', columnist [[Harvey Shore]] referred to the festival as "Australia's first horror film festival [it] recognises the past and gives the horror genre a platform for the future."<ref>''Encore Magazine'', September 2007, p. 46</ref> In an article in Sydney's ''Drum Media'' magazine, journalist Liz Guiffre refers to the horror festival as "a one of a kind in our parts".<ref name="Drum Media pg. 71">''Drum Media'', 1 April, no. 899, pg. 71</ref>
==Festival History==
The festival was founded in 2006, by [[Dean Bertram]], Lisa Mitchell, and Grant Bertram.<ref>''Encore Magazine'', June 2008, pg. 46</ref> It was originally a short film festival, but has since expanded to include feature films and horror themed music videos. Indeed, now that the festival runs for a longer duration, the festival's name, "A Night of Horror", is actually something of a misnomer (the 2008 festival actually ran for ten days and nights). The principal screening venue for the 2008 festival was the Dendy Newtown Cinema. Additional special events included a horror filmmaking forum, a [[zombie walk]], and a number of horror-themed parties.<ref name="Drum Media pg. 71"/>
In addition to the principal annual event in Sydney, a "best of" program of films from the festival tours within Australia and internationally. Some of these screenings take place at other festivals under the "A Night of Horror" banner, and have included programs at: It Came From Lake Michigan Film Festival,<ref>[http://www.itcamefromlakemichigan.com/icflm/?page_id=57 Itcamefromlakemichigan.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713064616/http://www.itcamefromlakemichigan.com/icflm/?page_id=57 |date=13 July 2011 }}</ref> Weekend de la Peur,<ref>[http://www.weekenddelapeur.cs.cx/ Weekenddelapeur.cs.cx] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080107183212/http://www.weekenddelapeur.cs.cx/ |date=7 January 2008 }}</ref> and Revelation Perth International Film Festival.<ref>[http://www.revelationfilmfest.org/index.cfm?objectid=2641D882-65BF-EBC1-23FA4445EE0E8441&navid=D9761779-C09F-1F3C-C809B0FDEF313ED9 Revelationfilmfest.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720064620/https://www.revelationfilmfest.org/index.cfm?objectid=2641D882-65BF-EBC1-23FA4445EE0E8441&navid=D9761779-C09F-1F3C-C809B0FDEF313ED9 |date=20 July 2008 }}</ref>
In 2007, A Night of Horror International Film Festival also programmed a special selection of Canadian produced horror films for Possible Worlds: Sydney's Canadian Film Festival (which took place at the Chauvel Cinema, Paddington).<ref>[http://www.possibleworlds.net.au/movies.htm&movie_id=9 Possibleworlds.net.au] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831193912/http://www.possibleworlds.net.au/movies.htm%26movie_id%3D9 |date=31 August 2007 }}</ref>
==Festival Judges and Winning Films==
The festival is competitive and films compete for several awards and prizes. A panel of judges decide these winners. 2009 judges included: Antony I. Ginnane (IFM World Releasing, SPAA), Jon Dalgaard (International Coordinator, Lionsgate), Jason Di Rosso (ABC Radio National Movietime), Lewis Alsamari (actor UNITED 93, GREEN ZONE and writer). Previous year's judges have included film author and curator [[Jack Sargeant (writer)|Jack Sargeant]], ''People'' magazine editor [[Martin Vine]], television and radio personalities [[Jaimie Leonarder]] and [[Aspasia Leonarder]], and [[FBi Radio]] presenter and journalist [[Chris Ruhle]].
'''2007 Winning films'''
Best of Fest: ''[[The Ancient Rite Of Corey McGillis]]'' (AUS)
Best Film: ''[[Happy Birthday 2 You]]'' (ESP)
Best Animation: ''[[The Tell Tale Heart]]'' (LUX/ESP/USA)
Best Lovecraft Film: ''From Beyond'' (USA)
Best Zombie Film: ''[[Love is a Shotgun]]'' (AUS)
Best Director: [[Paul Campion (film director)]], ''[[Night Of The Hell Hamsters]]'' (UK/NZ)
Best Performance: [[Emma Caulfield]], ''[[The Hollow (2007 film)|Hollow]]'' (USA)
Best Scream Queen: [[Kaja Trøa]], ''[[A New Life (2007 film)|The New Life]]'' (AUS)
Best Special Effects: [[Stuart Rowsell]], ''[[The Ancient Rite Of Corey McGillis]]'' (AUS)
Best Score: [[Milan Rusko]], ''Nazdravicko!'' (SVK)
'''2008 Winning Films'''
Best Film: ''[[Brain Dead (2007 film)|Brain Dead]]'' (USA)
Best Foreign Film: ''[[La Antena]]'' (ARG)
Best Short Film: ''[[Pumpkin Hell]]'' (USA)
Best Australian Film: ''[[When Sally Met Frank]]'' (AUS)
Best Lovecraft Film: ''[[The Call of Cthulhu (film)]]'' (USA)
Best Animation: ''[[Egg Ghost]]'' (KOR/USA)
Best Music Video: ''Torture Device'', featuring [[Dawn of Ashes]] (USA)
Best Director: Paco Limon, (''[[Doctor Infierno]]'') (ESP)
Best Performance: [[Sammi Davis]], ''[[The Double Born]]'' (USA)
Best Scream Queen: Tess McVicker, ''[[Brain Dead (2007 film)|Brain Dead]]'' (USA)
Best Special Make-Up Effects: ''[[Brain Dead (2007 film)|Brain Dead]]'' (USA)
Best Special Visual Effects: ''[[Eel Girl]]'' (NZ/UK)
Directors' Choice Award (Best Feature Film): ''[[Murder Loves Killers Too]]'' (USA)
Directors' Choice Award (Best Short Film): ''[[Kirksdale]]'' (USA)
'''2009 Winning Films'''
Best Film: ''[[Splinter (2008 film)]]'' (USA)
Best Foreign Language Film: ''[[No Morire Sola]]'' (I'll Never Die Alone) (ARG)
Best Australian Film: ''[[I Know How Many Runs You Scored Last Summer]]'' (AUS)
Best Director: Adrián García Bogliano (''[[I'll Never Die Alone]]'')(ARG)
Best Australian Director: Ursula Dabrowsky (''[[Family Demons]]'')(AUS)
Best Female Performance: Olga Fedori (''[[Mum & Dad]]'')(UK)
Best Male Performance: Shea Whigham (''[[Splinter (2008 film)]]'') (USA)
Best Special Effects: ''[[Splinter (2008 film)]]'' (USA)
Best Special Effects (Short Film): ''[[Treevenge]]'' (CAN)
Best Short Film: Una Storia Di Lupi (''[[A Wolf's Tale]]'') (ITA)
Best Short Animation: ''[[The Facts in the Case of Mister Hollow]]''<ref>{{cite web|title=2009 Festival Award Winners |url=http://www.anightofhorror.com/2009_winners.htm |publisher=Lovecraft 21C Productions |date=3 April 2009 |accessdate=17 April 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418164039/http://www.anightofhorror.com/2009_winners.htm |archivedate=18 April 2009 |deadurl=yes }}
</ref> (CAN)
Best Lovecraft Film: ''[[AM 1200 (film)|AM 1200]]'' (USA)
Best Short Australian Film: ''[[A Break in the Monotony]]'' (AUS)
Best Music Video: More Control - ''[[The Heist and the Accomplice]]''(Dir: Steve Daniels)(USA)
Directors' Choice (BEST FEATURE): ''[[Reel Zombies]]'' (CAN)
Directors' Choice (BEST SHORT): ''Allure'' (USA)
Independent Spirit Award (FEATURE FILM): ''[[Finale (film)|Finale]]'' (USA)
Independent Spirit Award (SHORT): ''[[The Red Hours]]'' (CAN)
Independent Spirit Award (AUSTRALIA): ''[[Taber Corn]]'' (AUS)
==2009 Festival==
The 2009 Sydney festival is scheduled for 25 March to 3 April 2009.
On 2 June 2008, the festival announced its call for entries for the 2009 festival. The festival accepts films in several different categories, including: feature films, short films, animations, films inspired by the writings of [[H. P. Lovecraft]], and horror-themed music videos.
It has also introduced a screenplay competition to take place in conjunction with the 2009 festival, and is calling for unproduced feature length and short horror scripts.
'''2009 Feature Screenplay Winners:'''
1st - Terminal - (Paul Campion & Elisabeth Pinto)
2nd - Children of the Night - ([[Harry Basil]])
3rd - Footage - (Duncan Samarasinghe)
'''2009 Short Screenplay Winners:'''
1st - Brother Moose's Broken Shorts - (A.J. Mitchler)
2nd - Fragments of Normal - (Gwyn Duffy)
3rd - Mr. Roach - (Franck Zuanic)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.anightofhorror.com A Night of Horror International Film Festival] website *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080720064620/https://www.revelationfilmfest.org/index.cfm?objectid=2641D882-65BF-EBC1-23FA4445EE0E8441&navid=D9761779-C09F-1F3C-C809B0FDEF313ED9 A Night of Horror at Revelation Perth International Film Festival]
