page.title: List of Western Australia tropical cyclones

revision.text:
{{Australian tropical cyclone intensity scale}} This is a list of cyclones that have significantly affected or made landfall over the coast of [[Western Australia]]. {{clear}}
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Name ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2"| Date of landfall ! colspan="2"| Peak intensity{{#tag:ref|If multiple landfalls took place along the storm's track, the highest intensity is listed.|group="nb"|name="multiple"}}{{#tag:ref|Listings in ''italics'' denote storms that did not make landfall but had impact on land.|group="nb"|name="Landfall note"}} ! rowspan="2"| Deaths ! rowspan="2"| Damage ([[Australian dollar|A$]]) ! rowspan="2" class="unsortable"| Remarks |- ! Winds ! Pressure |- |{{N/A}} || 1870 || {{sort|1224|24 December}} || {{N/A}} || {{sort|0956|956 hPa (28.23 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || A severe storm caused extensive defoliation and debarking of trees in [[Roebourne, Western Australia|Roebourne]].<ref name="Roebourne">{{cite web|work=Bureau of Meteorology|publisher=Government of Australia|year=2014|accessdate=23 March 2014|title=Tropical Cyclones Affecting the Karratha/Dampier/Roebourne region|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/cyclone/history/wa/roebourne.shtml}}</ref> |- |{{N/A}} || 1875 || {{sort|1224|24 December}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|69}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Cyclone hovered in [[Exmouth Gulf]] for nearly two weeks; 69 lives lost, mostly on ships at sea in the area. |- |{{N/A}} || 1881 || {{sort|0106|6 January}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|16}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Many schooners sank or were washed ashore by a cyclone that struck Roebourne. A large storm surge caused dramatic changes to coastal landscapes as well.<ref name="Roebourne"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1881 || {{sort|0307|7 March}} || {{N/A}} || {{sort|0942|942 hPa (27.82 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || A severe storm struck Roebourne and Cossack, damaging nearly every structure.<ref name="Roebourne"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1884 || {{sort|0401|1 April}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|140}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Forty vessels of a pearling fleet sunk with 140 lives lost in [[Lagrange Bay]] |- |{{N/A}} || 1889 || {{sort|0301|1 March}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|1}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || A cyclone struck Cossack at high tide, causing considerable flooding.<ref name="Roebourne"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1894 || {{sort|0104|4–9 January}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|40}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Two consecutive cyclones struck the Pilbara coastline and caused extensive damage in Roebourne and Cossack. The second storm destroyed the seawall in Cossack. All fatalities took place offshore due to the sinking of twelve luggers and the steamer ''Anne''. Damage was estimated at £15,000.<ref name="Roebourne"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1898 || {{sort|0402|2 April}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Severe damage, described as the worst ever seen, took place in Cossack. Infrastructure was devastated and losses reached £30,000. A record-breaking {{convert|747|mm|in|abbr=on}} of rain was measured in 24 hours at Whim Creek.<ref name="Roebourne"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1903 || {{sort|0108|8 January}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Storm dropped {{convert|637|mm|in|abbr=on}} of rain in [[Wyndham, Western Australia|Wyndham]] over a five-day span causing unprecedented flooding and severe stock losses.<ref name="Wyndham">{{cite web|work=Bureau of Meteorology|publisher=Government of Australia|year=2014|accessdate=23 March 2014|title=Tropical Cyclones Affecting Wyndham|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/cyclone/history/wa/wyndham.shtml}}</ref> |- |{{N/A}} || 1908 || {{sort|0112|12 January}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|50}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Struck [[Broome, Western Australia|Broome]]; most deaths at sea |- |{{N/A}} || 1910 || {{sort|1119|19 November}} || bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus3}}|{{sort|175|175 km/h (110 mph)}}{{#tag:ref|Estimated maximum wind gusts.|group="nb"|name="Gusts"}}||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus3}}|{{sort|0965|965 hPa (28.50 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|40}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Storm caused severe damage in and around Broome. Twenty homes were destroyed while seventy more were damaged, with losses amounting to £20,000. Offsore, 67 pearling vessels were blown ashore while 34 more sank.<ref name="Broome">{{cite web|work=Bureau of Meteorology|publisher=Government of Australia|year=2014|accessdate=23 March 2014|title=Tropical Cyclones Affecting Broome|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/cyclone/history/wa/broome.shtml}}</ref> |- |{{N/A}} || 1912 || {{sort|0321|21 March}} || bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus1}}|{{sort|102|102 km/h (63 mph)}}{{#tag:ref||group="nb"|name="Gusts"}}||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus1}}|{{ntsh|0}} N/A ||align="right"| {{nts|150}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || The coal steamer ''Koombana'' sank after sailing into the eye of this storm with all hands lost. The storm made landfall near Balla Balla and caused severe damage.<ref name="PortHedland">{{cite web|work=Bureau of Meteorology|publisher=Government of Australia|year=2014|accessdate=23 March 2014|title=Tropical Cyclones Affecting Port Hedland|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/cyclone/history/wa/pthed.shtml}}</ref> |- |{{N/A}} || 1914 || {{sort|0109|9 January}} || bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|depression}}|{{sort|065|<65 km/h (<40 mph)}}||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|depression}}|{{ntsh|0}} N/A||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Tropical low caused record-breaking floods along the Fitzroy and Lennard rivers; many cattle were swept away.<ref name="Derby">{{cite web|work=Bureau of Meteorology|publisher=Government of Australia|year=2014|accessdate=23 March 2014|title=Tropical Cyclones Affecting Derby|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/cyclone/history/wa/derby.shtml}}</ref> |- |{{N/A}} || 1925 || {{sort|0111|11 January}} || bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus1}}|{{sort|102|102 km/h (63 mph)}}{{#tag:ref||group="nb"|name="Gusts"}}||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus1}}|{{ntsh|0}} N/A ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Severe flooding took place along the Cossack River and every building was damaged in Roebourne.<ref name="Roebourne"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1925 || {{sort|0226|26 February}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || All homes in Marble Bar were damaged and some were destroyed. Extensive damage also took place in Nullagine.<ref name="Pilbara">{{cite web|work=Bureau of Meteorology|publisher=Government of Australia|year=2014|accessdate=23 March 2014|title=Tropical Cyclones Affecting Pilbara|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/cyclone/history/wa/pilbara.shtml}}</ref> |- |{{N/A}} || 1926 || {{sort|0122|22 January}} || bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}|{{sort|160|160 km/h (100 mph)}}{{#tag:ref||group="nb"|name="Gusts"}}||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}|{{sort|0982|982 hPa (29.00 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|40}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Extensive damage took place in Broome.<ref name="Broome"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1930 || {{sort|1228|28 December}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Considerable damage in and around Marble Bar and Nullagine.<ref name="Pilbara"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1935 || {{sort|0326|26 March}} || bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}|{{sort|130|130 km/h (80 mph)}}{{#tag:ref||group="nb"|name="Gusts"}}||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}|{{sort|0995|995 hPa (29.39 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|141}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Storm caused severe damage in Derby. A pearling fleet near the [[Lacepede Islands]] was devastated by the storm, resulting in 141 fatalities.<ref name="Broome"/><ref name="Derby"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1939 || {{sort|0111|11 January}} || bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus3}}|{{sort|200|200 km/h (124 mph)}}{{#tag:ref||group="nb"|name="Gusts"}}||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus3}}|{{ntsh|0}} N/A ||align="right"| {{nts|9}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || A storm surge of {{convert|9.8|m|ft|abbr=on}} caused extensive damage in Port Hedland and left 30 percent of the town homeless.<ref name="PortHedland"/> The ''Nicol Bay'' sank along the Ashburton River and some damage took place in Roebourne.<ref name="Roebourne"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1941 || {{sort|0301|1 March}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Homes flattened in Comet Mine and heavy rain caused significant flooding.<ref name="Pilbara"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1942 || {{sort|0111|11 January}} || bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus5}}|{{sort|230|230 km/h (145 mph)}}{{#tag:ref||group="nb"|name="Gusts"}}||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus5}}|{{sort|0938|938 hPa; (27.70 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|2}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || All homes in Port Hedland sustained some degree of damage.<ref name="PortHedland"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1956 || {{sort|0218|18–26 February}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || The Fitzroy River exceeded flood levels set during the 1914 flood, with the river spanning {{convert|24|km|mi|abbr=on}} across in some areas. The town of Derby was entirely cut off from surrounding areas.<ref name="Derby"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1957 || {{sort|0214|14 February}} || bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}|{{sort|161|161 km/h (101 mph)}}{{#tag:ref||group="nb"|name="Gusts"}}||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}|{{sort|0964|964 hPa (28.47 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|2}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Many homes sustained significant damage; losses reached £80,000.<ref name="Broome"/> |- |{{N/A}} || 1959 || {{sort|0401|April}} || {{N/A}} || {{N/A}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Cyclone dropped {{convert|440|mm|in|abbr=on}} of rain over two days in [[Wyndham, Western Australia|Wyndham]], causing flooding.<ref name="Wyndham"/> |- ||[[Cyclone Alby|Alby]] ||1978|| {{sort|0404|4 April}}|| bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus5}}|{{sort|200|200 km/h (125 mph)}}||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus5}}|{{sort|0930|930 hPa (27.46 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|5}} 5 || align="right"| {{ntsh|39}} $39 million|| Caused the most widespread cyclone damage in Western Australia's history. Destroyed a large portion of the [[Busselton Jetty]]. Affected [[Perth]] with the 3rd highest recorded wind gust in the city's history, {{convert|130|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}, and [[Fremantle]] with a {{convert|143|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} gust. Fueled bushfires which killed 2 more people indirectly.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tropical Cyclone Alby|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/cyclone/history/wa/alby.shtml|website=Bureau of Meteorology|publisher=Australian Government|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> |- ||[[Cyclone Jane (1983)|Jane]] || 1983 || {{sort|1983|9 January}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|170|170 km/h (105 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|0947|947 hPa (27.96 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Minor || Made landfall east of [[Port Hedland]] causing moderate damage, particularly in [[Pardoo Station]]. |- ||[[Cyclone Lena (1983)|Lena]] || [[1982–83 Australian region cyclone season|1983]]|| {{sort|1983|8 April}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}|{{sort|110|110 km/h (70 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}|{{sort|0980|980 hPa (28.93 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Minor || Lena passed directly over [[Port Hedland]] as a category two. Moderate damage was reported, one poorly-built house and several fishing boats were destroyed. |- ||[[Cyclone Quenton (1983)|Quenton]] || [[1983–84 Australian region cyclone season|1983]]|| {{sort|1983|30 November}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|170|170 km/h (105 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|0955|955 hPa (28.20 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Minor || The earliest recorded landfalling severe tropical cyclone in Western Australia. Caused minor damage at the [[Sandfire Roadhouse]]. |- ||[[Cyclone Chloe (1984)|Chloe]] || 1984|| {{sort|1984|29 February}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|170|170 km/h (105 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|0955|955 hPa (28.20 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown (severe) || Made landfall as a category four, severe structural damage occurred in [[Roebourne, Western Australia|Roebourne]] with some houses completely destroyed. Severe wind damage was also reported at [[Dampier, Western Australia|Dampier]], [[Whim Creek]] and [[Port Hedland]] while a flash flood damaged much of [[Wickham, Western Australia|Wickham]]. |- ||[[Cyclone Frank (1984)|Frank]] || [[1984–85 Australian region cyclone season|1984]]|| {{sort|1984|27 December}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|175|175 km/h (110 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|0952|952 hPa (28.11 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Minor || Frank made landfall over [[Port Hedland]] causing minor wind damage. |- |[[Cyclone Connie|Connie]] || [[1986–87 Australian region cyclone season|1987]] || {{sort|1987|19 January}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus3}}|{{sort|155|155 km/h (100 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus3}}|{{sort|0950|950 hPa (28.05 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Minor || Connie passed over [[Port Hedland]] on the 19 of January, causing moderate infrastructure damage. The roof of the historic [[Whim Creek]] Pub was also torn off in the storm. |- |[[Cyclone Elsie (1987)|Elsie]] || 1987 || {{sort|1987|25 February}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|175|175 km/h (110 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|0940|940 hPa (27.75 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown (severe) || Elise passed directly over [[Mandora Station]] as a category four resulting in catastrophic damage. Almost all of the stations buildings were destroyed, including the main homestead. Mandora was completely rebuilt with buildings constructed to withstand severe tropical cyclone winds. |- |[[Cyclone Herbie|Herbie]] || [[1987–88 Australian region cyclone season|1988]] || {{sort|1988|21 May}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus1}}|{{sort|075|75 km/h (45 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus1}}|{{sort|0980|980 hPa (28.94 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} $20 million|| Herbie made landfall over [[Denham, Western Australia|Denham]] as a category one storm. Severe damage was reported in the town, with some roofs torn off and fences blown over. Flash-flooding was reported from [[Carnarvon, Western Australia|Carnarvon]] to [[Geraldton]]. The storm crossed the coast on the 21 of May, the latest known date of landfall for a tropical cyclone in Australia. Responsible for the sinking, & hence rapid breaking-up, of the [[MV Korean Star (1984)]] near Cape Cuvier on the 20th May. |- |[[Cyclone Ned (1989)|Ned]] || [[1988–89 Australian region cyclone season|1989]] || {{sort|1989|1 April}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|165|165 km/h (105 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|0941|941 hPa (27.78 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Ned crossed the coast just south of [[Perth]] as a category one on the 1 of April. Moderate wind damage was reported in [[Rockingham, Western Australia|Rockingham]]. Ned is the most southerly landfalling tropical cyclone recorded in Australia and the only storm ever to directly affect Perth city at cyclone strength. |- |[[Cyclone Orson|Orson]] || 1989 || {{sort|1989|23 April}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus5}}|{{sort|250|250 km/h (155 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus5}}|{{sort|0925|925 hPa (27.31 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|5}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} $25 million|| Orson made landfall near [[Dampier, Western Australia|Dampier]] as a strong category five however damage was minimal due to the storms fast speed and small wind field. Severe damage was however reported on an offshore drilling rig and five people drowned after their boat capsized in rough seas. Before landfall, Orson was the fourth most intense cyclone ever recorded in Australian waters. |- ||[[Cyclone Ian (1992)|Ian]] || 1992 || {{sort|1992|3 March}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus5}}|{{sort|210|210 km/h (130 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus5}}|{{sort|0930|930 hPa (27.46 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Minor || Ian made landfall near [[Mardie Station]] as a category three. Minor damage occurred to mining operations in the [[Montebello Islands]] and on [[Barrow Island (Western Australia)|Barrow Island]]. |- |{{N/A}} || 1993 || {{sort|0201|February}} || bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|depression}}|{{sort|065|<65 km/h (<40 mph)}}||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|depression}}|{{ntsh|0}} N/A||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Twin tropical lows brought rainfall in excess of {{convert|500|mm|in|abbr=on}} to the [[Kimberley (Western Australia)|Kimberley]] region, causing severe flooding. Extensive damage to infrastructure occurred.<ref name="Derby"/> |- |[[Cyclone Annette (1994)|Annette]] || [[1994–95 Australian region cyclone season|1994]] || {{sort|1995|18 December}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|195|195 km/h (120 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|0925|925 hPa (27.31 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Minor || Annette made landfall over [[Mandora Station]] as a category four causing severe damage to the homestead and surrounding area and killing several hundred cattle. |- |[[Cyclone Bobby|Bobby]] || 1995 || {{sort|1995|25 February}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|195|195 km/h (120 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|0925|925 hPa (27.31 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|8}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Bobby crossed the coast as a category three near [[Onslow, Western Australia|Onslow]] on the 25 February causing severe flooding across the north-west. colour|Aus1}}|{{sort|085|85 km/h (50 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus1}}|{{sort|0991|991 hPa (29.26 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} None || Alessia brushed the [[Kimberley (Western Australia)|Kimberley]] region with minor effects.<ref>{{cite report|work=Bureau of Meteorology|publisher=Government of Australia|year=2013|accessdate=23 March 2014|title=Tropical Cyclone Alessia Impacts|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/announcements/sevwx/nt/nttc20131122.shtml}}</ref><ref>{{cite report|author=Perth Regional Forecasting Centre |work=Bureau of Meteorology |publisher=Government of Australia |date=23 November 2013 |accessdate=23 March 2014 |title=Tropical Cyclone Alessia Tropical Cyclone Technical Bulletin |url=http://weather.noaa.gov/pub/data/raw/ax/axau01.aprf..txt |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LMigfBNz?url=http://gwydir.demon.co.uk/advisories/AXAU01-ADRM_201311231331.htm |archivedate=24 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> |- |[[Cyclone Christine|Christine]] || 2013 || {{sort|1230|30 December}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|165|165 km/h (105 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|0948|948 hPa (27.99 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || Christine made landfall in the Pilbara. Caused heavy damage in the towns of [[Roebourne]] and [[Wickham, Western Australia|Wickham]] with many roofs torn off and smaller structures destroyed. |- |[[Cyclone Olwyn|Olwyn]] || 2015 || {{sort|1230|13&14 March}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus3}}|{{sort|150|150 km/h (90 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus3}}|{{sort|0950|950 hPa (28.05 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} none || Olwyn tracked the [[Western Australian]] coast from [[Exmouth, Western Australia]] to [[Shark Bay]], passing directly over Carnarvon. It caused heavy damage of infrastructure & crops at [[Carnarvon, Western Australia|Carnarvon]]. One person had sustained life-threatening injuries in a related car incident. |- |[[2014-15 Australian region cyclone season|Quang]] || 2015 || {{sort|2015|1 May}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|185|185 km/h (115 mph)}} ||bgcolor="#{{Storm colour|Aus4}}|{{sort|0950|950 hPa (28.05 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} minimal || Quang made landfall in [[Exmouth, Western Australia]] on the night of 1st May and brought minimal damage. |- |[[Cyclone Stan|Stan]] || 2016 || {{sort|2016|29 January}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}|{{sort|110|110 km/h (70 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}|{{sort|0975|975 hPa(28.79 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} unknown || Stan subsequently made landfall between [[Port Hedland]] and [[Wallal]] and impacted various commodities including oil, natural gas and iron ore. However, human impacts were limited due to the low permanent population in the area. |- | [[2016-17 Australian region cyclone season|Yvette]] || 2016 || {{sort|161219|25 December}} || bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|A1}}| {{Sort|075|75 km/h (45 mph)}} || bgcolor=#{{storm color|A1}}|{{Sort|0987|987 hPa(29.15 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} None || |- |[[2016-17 Australian region cyclone season|Blanche]] || 2017 || {{sort|170302|7 March}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}| {{Sort|095|95 km/h (60 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{storm colour|Aus2}}|{{Sort|0988|988 hPa(29.17 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} None || |- |[[2017-18 Australian region cyclone season|Hilda]] || 2017 || {{sort|171226|28 December}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus2}}| {{Sort|095|95 km/h (60 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{storm colour|Aus2}}|{{Sort|0980|980 hPa(28.94 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Minor || Hilda made landfall close to Anna Plains on 28 December as a category 2 cyclone, wind and flooding damage was minor along the coast in Broome. |- |[[2017-18 Australian region cyclone season|Joyce]] || 2018 || {{sort|180106|12 January}} ||bgcolor=#{{Storm colour|Aus1}}| {{Sort|085|85 km/h (50 mph)}} ||bgcolor=#{{storm colour|Aus1}}|{{Sort|0982|982 hPa(29.00 inHg)}} ||align="right"| {{nts|0}} ||align="right"| {{ntsh|0}} Unknown || |}

page.title: List of air show accidents and incidents in the 20th century

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}}
{{Dynamic a-list}}
This is a year-by-year '''list of aviation accidents''' that have occurred at '''[[air show|airshows]]''' worldwide in the 20th century. [[Image:F-89 Scorpion Crash IAE Detroit 1952.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Northrop F-89 Scorpion]] disintegrating at Detroit, Michigan in 1952]] __NOTOC__

[[#1927|1927]] || [[#1928|1928]] || [[#1929|1929]] || [[#1930|1930]] |- style="background:#ddd;" || [[#1911|1911]] || [[#1912|1912]] || [[#1913|1913]] || [[#1914|1914]] || [[#1915|1915]] || [[#1916| [[#1907| ]] || [[#1908|1908]] || [[#1909|1909]] || [[#1910|1910]] |- | style="background:#ddd; text-align:center;" colspan="10"| [[#See also|See also]] — [[#References|References]] — [[#External links|External links]] |} <!--end compact toc-->
==2000== * August 18 – [[Airbourne (air show)|Airbourne]] 2000 show ([[Eastbourne]], [[East Sussex]], England) – Former [[Red Arrows]] pilot Ted Girdler was killed when his [[Aero L-29 Delfín]] jet failed to pull up from a diving roll and crashed into the [[English Channel]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Airshow crash: No wreckage found|work=BBC News Online: UK|publisher=BBC News|date=August 19, 2000 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/uk_news/886064.stm|accessdate=July 6, 2008}}</ref> * June 18 – Willow Grove 2000 Sounds of Freedom Air Show ([[Willow Grove, Pennsylvania]]) – Two crew members of a [[F-14 Tomcat]] were killed when their aircraft lost altitude and crashed into a wooded area. They were demonstrating a low speed "landing wave-off maneuver" at the time of the accident.<ref>{{cite news|title=2 Die In F-14 Air Show Crash|publisher=CBS News US|date=June 18, 2000 |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2000/06/18/national/main207042.shtml |accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref> * March 18 – Wings Over South Texas (Kingsville NAS, Texas) – Pilot Maj. Brison Phillips was killed when his [[F-16 Fighting Falcon]] crashed at an air show while thousands of horrified spectators watched. Phillips had been attempting a split S maneuver, in which the pilot rolls the airplane until it is upside down and then drops in a dive. The plane hit the ground and exploded, scattering debris for half a mile in a field about six miles north of the naval base about 12:45 p.m.
==1999== * October 3 – California International Airshow (Salinas, California) – Pilot [[Wayne Handley]] was seriously injured when his custom built Turbo Raven crashed during maneuvers. The NTSB attributed the crash to pilot error, but Handley attributed it to an engine malfunction.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * September 18 – [[Reno Air Races]] (also known as National Championship Air Races) Pilot Gary Levitz, 61, a 30-year race veteran of Grand Prairie, Texas, was racing his highly modified Mustang P-51, which disintegrated during the Gold Unlimited race, scattering debris and damaging a house in Lemmon Valley, just east of the Stead Airport Base, where the races were being held. The NTSB had determined that the tail empenage failed in flight causing the aircraft to break apart.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * September 12 – Harriman-West Airport airshow – Both pilots were killed when a [[Cessna Skymaster|Cessna 337C]] and a [[Cessna O-1 Bird Dog|Cessna 305C]] collided in midair while conducting in-trail fly-bys.<ref>{{Cite news| title = Two pilots die in crash at air show in N. Adams| newspaper =Cape Cod Times| page =1| publisher =| date =September 13, 1999| url=http://www.capecodonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19990913/NEWS01/309139992&cid=sitesearch| accessdate =June 4, 2012}}</ref> * July 29 – [[AirVenture|EAA Airventure]] airshow ([[Oshkosh, Wisconsin]]) – Pilot Laird Doctor was seriously injured when his [[F4U Corsair]] collided with a stationary [[F8F Bearcat]] during its takeoff roll. The Corsair crashed in flames beside the runway and was destroyed. [[Howard Pardue]], the pilot of the Bearcat, was not seriously injured but his aircraft suffered major damage.<ref>{{cite web|date = July 29, 1999|title = NTSB Factual Report, Airventure Corsair crash|publisher = [[National Transportation Safety Board]]|format=PDF|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/ntsb/GenPDF.asp?id=CHI99FA266A&rpt=fa|work=NTSB Report|accessdate=November 20, 2009}}</ref> * June 12 – [[Paris Air Show]] ([[Paris, France]]) – A [[Russian Air Force]] [[Sukhoi Su-30MKI]] demonstrator '01' (with [[canard (aeronautics)|canards]] and [[thrust vectoring|vectored thrust]]), crashed at [[Le Bourget]] Airport. At the completion of a downward spiralling maneuver, the tail contacted the grass surface. With almost no forward speed the fighter was able to pull away from the ground, wings level, with an up pitch of 10–15 degrees and climb to ~150 feet (46 m), with the right jet nozzle deflected fully up and flames engulfing the left engine. Sukhoi test pilot Vyacheslav Averynov initiated ejection with navigator Vladimir Shendrikh departing the aircraft first. The [[NPP Zvezda|Zvezda]] [[K-36D-3.5]] [[ejection seat]]s worked perfectly and both crew descended on to a taxiway unhurt. The Su-30 impacted some distance from the crew.<ref>Stamford, Lincs., UK: Air Forces Monthly, Alan Dawes, "''That Crash – at Le Bourget''", August 1999, Number 137, pages 50–53.</ref> The incident was captured on video.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yh-kuztsE1s|title=Su-30MKI crash at Paris Air Show Le Bourget 1999|first=|last=Tsobanian|date=June 23, 2007|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> * June 6 – Milan Rastislav Stefanik airport airshow ([[Bratislava]], [[Slovakia]]) – [[Test pilot]] Graham Wardell was killed when his [[BAE Systems]] [[BAE Hawk|Hawk 200]] failed to pull out of a low turn and struck the ground. A woman spectator was knocked off a nearby rooftop by the force of the explosion and died of her injuries.<ref>{{cite news| last =| first =| authorlink =| title = World: Europe – Top test pilot killed in crash | work =| publisher = BBC News| date = June 7, 1999| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/362464.stm| format =| doi = | accessdate =July 6, 2008}}</ref> * May 30 – Airshow at [[Nowra, New South Wales|Nowra]], New South Wales, Australia. A vintage [[CAC Wirraway]] crashed during the display, killing pilot Owen O'Malley and observer Phil Lloyd.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adf-serials.com.au/2a20h.htm|title=ADF Serials - Wirraway|publisher=}}</ref>
==1998== * August 15 – Swanton Morley Airshow ([[East Dereham]], [[Norfolk]], England) – Pilot Christopher Wilkins was killed when his [[Druine Turbulent|Rollason D31 Turbulent]] stalled and crashed while performing with the [[Tiger Club]] display team.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title = Pilot Killed In Crash At Air Show| work =| publisher = Croydon Guardian| date = August 15, 1998 |url=http://www.croydonguardian.co.uk/news/archive/display.var.72951.0.pilot_killed_in_crash_at_air_show.php|accessdate=July 6, 2008}}</ref> * May 19 – DARE Airshow ([[Manassas, Virginia]]) – Pilot Dr. Miles Merritt was killed when his [[Sukhoi Su-29]] crashed while performing a skidding turn at too low an "[[Aircraft attitude|altitude]]".<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |authorlink= |title=12,000 children view deadly plane crash |work=Laredo Morning Times |agency=Associated Press |date=May 20, 1998 |url=http://airwolf.lmtonline.com/news/archive/052098/pagea7.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721072106/http://airwolf.lmtonline.com/news/archive/052098/pagea7.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 21, 2011 |format=PDF |doi= |accessdate=July 12, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| last = Kiser| first = Uriah A.| authorlink =| title = One still in hospital after Friday plane crash| work = | publisher = Virginia News| date = June 28, 2009| url = http://www.starexponent.com/cse/news/state_regional/article/one_still_in_hospital_after_friday_plane_crash/38342/| format =| doi =| accessdate =July 12, 2009}}</ref> * March 1 – Mount Gambier Airshow ([[Mount Gambier, South Australia|Mount Gambier]], South Australia) – An [[Air Tractor AT-802|Air Tractor AT-802A]] crashed on aerodrome whilst performing a low-level fire-fighting display. The pilot lost control after attempting a sudden steep climb at high speed and he was killed in the crash. There were no other casualties in the incident.<ref>http://www.atsb.gov.au/publications/investigation_reports/1998/aair/aair199800640.aspx</ref>
==1997== * October 12 – (Duxford, Cambridgeshire, England) – The last airworthy World War II German [[Messerschmitt Bf 109]] crashed while being flown by Air Chief Marshal [[John Allison (RAF officer)|Sir John Allison]], Commander-in-Chief of [[RAF Strike Command]]. He was unhurt despite the plane coming to rest upside down. The plane, known to be difficult to land due to poor visibility from the cockpit and its narrow-track landing gear, had overshot the runway while landing following the malfunction of its Daimler-Benz DB 605 engine.<ref>{{cite news | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/cambridgeshire/3061561.stm | title = History of Air Field Crashes | publisher = BBC News | date = July 12, 2003 | accessdate= September 18, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title = YouTube – October 12, 1997 Messerschmitt Bf109 crash at Duxford, England | work =| publisher =| url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RiYs_zqnOoQ| format =| doi = | accessdate =September 18, 2009}}</ref> * September 20 – Sixth Annual Confederate Air Force Airshow ([[San Marcos, Texas]]) An Aerotek Pitts S-2A aerobatic biplane piloted by James Kincaid crashed at the bottom of a snap roll and dive maneuver in front of a crowd of approximately 15,000. The pilot died from his injuries later that day. Witnesses reported that the plane did not have sufficient airspeed at the start of the sequence to keep from crashing at the bottom of the dive.<ref>[http://www.aopa.org/asf//ntsb/narrative.cfm?ackey=1&evid=20001208X08848 AOPA Online – ASF Accident Details]. Aopa.org. Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref><ref>http://www.ntsb.gov/aviationquery/brief2.aspx?ev_id=20001208X08848&ntsbno=FTW97LA353&akey=1</ref><ref>[http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/1997_3003506/plane-crashes-at-air-show-killing-pilot.html | Archives | Chron.com – Houston Chronicle]. Chron.com. Retrieved July 13, 2013.</ref> * September 14 – Chesapeake Air Show ([[Middle River, Maryland]]) – A [[Lockheed F-117]], ''81–793'', of the 7th Fighter Squadron, 49th Fighter Wing, at [[Holloman AFB]], [[New Mexico]], lost its port wing at 1500 hrs. during a pass over [[Martin State Airport]], and crashed into a residential area of [[Bowleys Quarters, Maryland|Bowley's Quarters, Maryland]] damaging several homes. Four people on the ground received minor injuries and the pilot, Maj. Bryan "B.K." Knight, 36, escaped with minor injuries after ejecting from the aircraft. A month-long Air Force investigation found that four of 39 fasteners for the wing's structural support assembly were apparently left off when the wings were removed and reinstalled in January 1996, according to a report released on December 12, 1997.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} * July 26 – Ostend Airshow ([[Ostend]], [[Belgium]]) – Captain Omar Hani Bilal of the [[Jordanian Air Force]] display team, the [[Royal Jordanian Falcons]], was killed when he lost control of his [[Extra 300|Walter Extra EA300s]]. His plane crashed at the end of the runway and burst into flames near a [[Red Cross]] tent and spectator stands. On the ground, eight were killed and forty injured.<ref>{{cite news|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=9 die when plane crashes at Belgian air show |work=World News Story Page |publisher=CNN Online |date=July 26, 1997 |url=http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/9707/26/belgium.aircrash/ |doi= |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208043752/http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/9707/26/belgium.aircrash/ |archivedate=December 8, 2008}}</ref> * June 22 – Wings Over Long Island Airshow – ([[Westhampton, New York]]) – Two planes racing collided over [[Francis S. Gabreski Airport]] in front of 15,000 spectators. Pilot Dick Goodlett died when his aircraft crashed and burst into flames. The second plane crash-landed, critically injuring pilot Chris Kalishek.<ref>{{cite news| last = Tuma| first = Debbie |author2=Jere Hester |author3=Miguel Garcilazo |author4=John Roca| title = Airshow Collision; 1 Dead 2D Pilot Injured On L.I |publisher = The Daily News| date = June 23, 1997| url = http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1997/06/23/1997-06-23_airshow_collision__1_dead_2d.html| doi = | accessdate =21 August 2009 | location=New York}}</ref> * June 1 – Air Show Colorado 1997 ([[Broomfield, Colorado]]) – Ret. Colonel "Smiling Jack" Jack M. Rosamond was killed when he lost control of his restored [[F-86|F-86 Sabre Jet]] during an acrobatic loop at the [[Rocky Mountain Metropolitan Airport|(then known as) Jefferson County Airport]]. Unseasonably high temperatures combined with the natural high elevation (5,673 ft) of the airport was thought to make the air less dense than expected, leading to poor effectiveness of flight control surfaces. Nobody else was injured in the accident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planecrashmap.com/plane/co/N86EX|title=Maps and details of plane crashes - PlaneCrashMap.com|publisher=}}</ref>
==1996== * September 14 – Bob Heale of Spokane was killed while performing at Spokane's [[Fairchild Air Force Base]] when his French [[CAP-10]] crashed on its belly onto a dirt field in windy, rainy conditions at the annual Aerospace Days show. Investigators focused on possible mechanical problems with the 21-year-old plane. Bob Heale had been a regular performer at the [[Silverwood Theme Park]] in Athol, Idaho.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1996-09-16/news/9609160201_1_air-show-crash-plane-pilot | work=Chicago Tribune | title=Stunt Pilot Dies Of Injuries From Air Show Crash | date=September 16, 1996}}</ref><ref>Spokane Spokesman-Review 9/15/1996 pages A1 and A11.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=0klj8wIChNAC&dat=19960915&printsec=frontpage|title=The Spokesman-Review - Google News Archive Search|publisher=}}</ref> * August 4 – [[Three Rivers Regatta]] ([[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]]) – Pilot Clarence Speal was killed when the left hand wings on his biplane folded back which caused him to lose control and crash into the [[Ohio River]].<ref>{{Cite news| last =| first =| title = Pittsburgh Air Show Crash| newspaper =The New York Times| location =| pages =| publisher =The New York Times Archives |date=August 5, 1996 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/05/us/pittsburgh-air-show-crash.html |accessdate=December 26, 2010}}</ref> * July 21 – [[Barton Aerodrome]] air show ([[Barton-upon-Irwell]], [[Greater Manchester]], England) – The last [[de Havilland Mosquito]] known to be airworthy (serial number RR299), a T Mk III built by D.H. at Leavesden in Spring 1945, crashed with the loss of both crew after suffering loss of engine power when performing a wing-over manoeuvre. The incident was captured on video.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ag5ut3tP3ZM|publisher=YouTube|date=July 21, 1996|title= de Havilland Mosquito crash at Barton Aerodrome, England}}</ref> * July 14 – [[Flying Legends]] Air Display (Duxford, Cambridgeshire, England) – Pilot Michael "Hoof" Proudfoot was killed when his [[Lockheed Corporation|Lockheed]] [[P-38 Lightning]] aircraft crashed and cartwheeled while performing a roll maneuver. Several aircraft on the ground were damaged or destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|title=P-38 Crashes at Air Show|publisher=AircraftGuru.com|date=August 17, 2006 |url=http://www.aircraftguru.com/aircraft-videos/video.php?v_id=62|accessdate=July 6, 2008}}</ref> * June 2 – Bartlesville Biplane Exposition (Bartlesville, Oklahoma) – Two Biplanes clipped wings on landing, all four aboard killed: William Watson, 71; John Halterman, 51; Rodney Bogan, 41; and Annette Delahay, 45.<ref>{{Cite news| last =Liefer| first =Richard| title = 4 Die As Biplanes Collide At Air Show| newspaper =Chicago Tribune|date=June 2, 1996| url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1996-06-02/news/9606020168_1_biplanes-collide-air-show|}}</ref> * May 4 – Sertoma Cajun Air Festival ([[Lafayette, Louisiana]]) – Pilot Joe Hartung, 44, perished when the Canadian-built Harvard Mk. II he was flying hit the runway while performing a low altitude roll.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/05/us/air-show-crash-kills-pilot.html|title=Air Show Crash Kills Pilot|publisher=AP via New York Times| date=May 5, 1996|accessdate=Nov 19, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/aviationquery/brief.aspx?ev_id=20001208X05745&key=1|title=NTSB report FTW96FA200|publisher=NTSB}}</ref> * April 27 – Shiloh Airshow ([[Stoneville, North Carolina]]) – Pilot Lindsey Hess escaped injury when his [[Pitts Special|Pitts S2 A]] crashed inverted on the runway following his attempt to cut a ribbon with the plane.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1454&dat=19960429&id=F1ZIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NhUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6627,5582797&hl=en|title = Pilot Vows To Continue After Air Show Disaster |date = April 29, 1996 |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |newspaper = Wilmington Morning Star|page = 3B}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.asias.faa.gov/pls/apex/f?p=100:17:0::NO::AP_BRIEF_RPT_VAR:MIA96LA132|title = NTSB Aviation Accident and Incident Data System (NTSB) Brief Report(s)|date = |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |publisher = Federal Aviation Administration}}</ref> * April 16 – [[Experimental Aircraft Association|EAA]] [[Sun 'n Fun]] ([[Lakeland, Florida]]) – Pilot [[Charlie Hillard]] was killed when his [[Hawker Sea Fury]] flipped over while landing in a crosswind.<ref name=STPETE1>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uLsMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1F4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5768,1027000|title=Stunt pilot dies in flip after show|publisher=St. Petersburg Times (via Google News Archive)|date=April 17, 1996|accessdate=Sep 22, 2009}}</ref>
==1995== * September 9 – ([[Johannisthal Air Field|Johannisthal, Germany]]) – A [[DaimlerChrysler Aerospace|DASA]]-operated [[Messerschmitt Bf 108|Messerschmitt Bf 108 Taifun]], ''D-EFPT'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.airliners.net/search/photo.search?aircraft_genericsearch=Messerschmitt%20Bf-108%20Taifun|title=Aviation Photo Search|publisher=}}</ref> crashed during an airshow, killing pilot Gerd Kahdemann and passenger [[Reinhard Furrer]], a former astronaut who had flown in space for Germany in 1985 during the [[STS-61A]] mission aboard the [[Space Shuttle Challenger]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/furrer-r.html|title=Payload Specialist Astronaut Bio: Reinhard Furrer|publisher=}}</ref> After completing an aerobatic display, the Bf 108 was seen to climb and attempt an aileron turn with increased pitch which developed into a barrel-roll into the ground at a ~90 degree angle. A piece of the airframe that came loose while the aircraft was inverted was found to be the starboard wing leading edge slat.<ref>News, "''Messerschmitt destroyed''", FlyPast, Stamford, Lincs., UK, Number 172, November 1995, page 19.</ref> * September 2 – [[Canadian International Air Show]] (Toronto, Ontario) – Seven [[Royal Air Force]] crew members were killed when their [[Hawker Siddeley Nimrod|Hawker Siddeley Nimrod MR.2P]] stalled during a low altitude turn and crashed into [[Lake Ontario]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Accident Description British Aerospace Nimrod MR.2P | work=Aviation Safety Network | publisher=Flight Safety Foundation | date=September 19, 2004 | url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19950902-0 | doi= | accessdate=July 6, 2008}}</ref>
==1994== * June 11 – Ray Mabery was killed at [[Selfridge Air National Guard Base]] in [[Mount Clemens]], [[Michigan]] when his [[Canadair]] [[Canadair CT-133 Silver Star|T-33]] crashed during an unplanned roll.<ref>{{cite web | title=N12418 plane crash in MI details | url=http://www.planecrashmap.com/plane/mi/N12418 | doi= | accessdate=June 18, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=ASN Wikibase Occurrence # 36205 | work=Aviation Safety Network | publisher=Flight Safety Foundation | url=http://aviation-safety.net/wikibase/wiki.php?id=36205 | accessdate=June 18, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=YouTube Selfridge Airshow | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lrwC2kw_4Gs | accessdate=June 18, 2011}}</ref>
* April 3 — Ian Reynolds died at a [[Warbirds Over Wanaka]] display in [[Wanaka]], [[New Zealand]] when his [[de Havilland Canada DHC-1 Chipmunk|22A]] crashed after he misjudged the arch of his dive.<ref>{{Accident de Havilland Canada DHC-1 Chipmunk 22A ZK-TNR, 03 Apr 1994 | ASN Wikibase Occurrence # 32402 | work=Aviation Safety Network | publisher=Flight Safety Foundation | url=http://aviation-safety.net/wikibase/wiki.php?id=32402 | accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref>
==1993== * October 3 – Lanseria Air Show, [[Lanseria International Airport]], [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]] – Silver Falcon 5, an [[Atlas Impala]] Mk1 no 489 piloted by Charles Rudenick, crashed at Lanseria Airport after structural failure. The pilot initiated the ejection sequence half a second before impact. He came out horizontally with the fuselage vertical and a high downward velocity. He was killed when "sucked" into the crash fireball.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * August 22 – Prairie Air '93 Air Show – ([[Bloomington, Illinois]]) – A [[Pitts Special]] flown by Charlie Wells crashed while performing a [[Lomcevak]]. Wells was killed instantly when the plane hit the ground. No one on the ground was injured, and the airshow continued despite the accident, however no more aerobatic planes performed for the remainder of the day.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * August 8 – [[Stockholm Water Festival]] ([[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]) – A [[JAS 39 Gripen]], ''39102'', crashed on the central Stockholm island of [[Långholmen]], near the [[Västerbron]] bridge, during a slow speed manoeuver. Lars Rådeström, the same pilot as in the 1989 incident [[Ejection seat|ejected]] safely. Despite large crowds standing by watching, no one on the ground was seriously injured. This crash was caused by a [[pilot-induced oscillation|PIO]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} * July 24 – [[Lebanon, New Hampshire]] – A biplane collided with a parachutist in the opening act of the Lebanon Airshow. Both the pilot and the parachutist died as a result of the collision. No other injuries were sustained.<ref>[http://dms.ntsb.gov/aviation/AccidentReports/1tnjb3ettg5lr045sm1iba551/S09172011120000.pdf], NTSB report for N90BC</ref> * July 24 – [[Royal International Air Tattoo]] – (Fairford, Gloucestershire, England) – Two MiG-29s of the Russian Air Force [["Test Pilots" (aerobatic team)|"Test Pilots"]] aerobatic team collided in mid-air and crashed away from the public. No one was hurt on the ground, and both pilots (Alexander Beschastonov and Sergey Tresvyatsk)<ref>[http://www.ejection-history.org.uk/Aircraft_by_Type/mig-29.htm MiG-29 midair at RIAT airshow in Fairford] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017035011/http://www.ejection-history.org.uk/Aircraft_by_Type/mig-29.htm |date=October 17, 2007 }}, ejection-history.org.uk</ref> ejected safely. Investigators later determined that pilot error was the cause; one pilot did a reverse loop and disappeared into the clouds, the other one lost sight of his wingman and aborted the routine.<ref>[http://www.sirviper.com/index.php?page=div/mig29_crash MiG-29 midair at RIAT airshow in Fairford], sirviper.com</ref> The incident was captured on video.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-tIcWObSk8I|title=RAF Fairford Mid Air Collision|first=|last=crashstarvideos|date=October 1, 2007|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> * June 27 – [[Concord, New Hampshire]] – Ron Shelly and his daughter Karen Shelly Duggan, who performed a father daughter [[wing walking]] act, were killed when their plane crashed after failing to come out of a roll.<ref>{{cite news| last =| first =| title = Stunt plane crashes during show| newspaper =Times Daily| location =| page = 3| agency = Associated Press| date =June 27, 1993| url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HdUdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=a8cEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6319,3574823&dq=airshow+crash&hl=en |accessdate=December 26, 2010}}</ref> * May 2 – ([[Marine Corps Air Station El Toro]], California) – A vintage [[F-86 Sabre]] crashed and exploded in the middle of a runway after civilian pilot James A. Gregory failed to come out of a vertical loop several hundred feet in front of spectators. The impact killed the pilot and sent flaming debris along the runway. No one on the ground was injured.<ref>[http://www.ntsb.gov/NTSB/GenPDF.asp?id=LAX93LA199&rpt=fa], NTSB report for May 2, 1993 F-86 crash at MCAS El Toro.</ref> The incident was captured on video.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MOFb8xtd4UM|title=F-86 El Toro Crash|first=|last=micfre|date=June 2, 2009|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==1992== * June 29 – Quad City Airshow ([[Davenport, Iowa]]) – An AV-8B Harrier leaving the airshow crashed on take off, killing pilot Maj. Jeffrey Smith.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pulitzer.org/archives/6724 |title=The Pulitzer Prizes |first= |last= |publisher=www.pulitzer.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090723081230/https://www.pulitzer.org/archives/6724 |archivedate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> * June 27 – Woodford Airshow ([[Woodford, Greater Manchester]], England) – David Moore was killed when his [[Supermarine Spitfire]] Mk.XIV crashed into the runway at [[Woodford Aerodrome]] during a low level loop.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.militaryairshows.co.uk/spitcrash.htm|title=Supermarine Spitfire Photographs 1 - Military Airshows|publisher=}}</ref> * April 5 – Valiant Air Command Warbird Air Show ([[Titusville, Florida]]) – Harry Doan 62, landed [[Douglas A-1 Skyraider|Skyraider]] taxied and went off the runway flipping in soft sand, nose end first crushing and killing pilot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1992-04-05/news/9204050050_1_doan-daytona-beach-quinla|title=Plane Flips, Kills Air Show Pilot|publisher=}}</ref>
==1991== *August 11 – Byron's Original Aviation Expo ([[Ida Grove, Iowa]]) – Pilot Mack Stevens Orr, a member of the [[Commemorative Air Force|Confederate Air Force]], died following the crash of his [[North American T-6 Texan|T-6 Texan]] during a reenactment of the bombing of Pearl Harbor.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=932&dat=19910811&id=l9lPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iFMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2983,5145997&hl=en|title = Plane Crashes During Airshow |date = August 11, 1991 |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = Kingsman Daily Miner}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.asias.faa.gov/pls/apex/f?p=100:17:0::NO::AP_BRIEF_RPT_VAR:CHI91DCD02|title = NTSB Aviation Accident and Incident Data System (NTSB) Brief Report(s) |accessdate=August 23, 2015 |publisher=Federal Aviation Administration}}</ref> *August 5 – Northeast Flight '91 Airshow (Schenectady, New York) – Five crew members of a Canadian forces [[Sikorsky SH-3 Sea King|Sea King H-3]] helicopter were injured when their craft lost altitude while hovering, crashed and flipped on its side.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1914&dat=19910805&id=aT0pAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yGUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1968,794712&hl=en|title = Five Injured In Airshow Crash |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = Sun Journal|page = 14}}</ref> *June 23 – Quad City Air Show ([[Davenport, Iowa]]) – Pilot Rick Leonard was killed during an air race when the wing of his [[Monnett Sonerai|Monnett Sonerai I]] separated while making a turn.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1243&dat=19910624&id=qkZTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=a4YDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6851,5825292&hl=en|title = Stunt Pilots Crash, Die At Air Shows |date = June 24, 1991 |accessdate = August 29, 2015 |publisher = The Associated Press|newspaper = The Bulletin|page = 4}}</ref> *June 22 – Redding Airshow, California. Pilot Gordy Drysdale, 43, of Stockton was killed when his T-34 failed to complete a low altitude roll and impacted the ground near spectators. Two were hospitalized in serious condition. A 34-year-old man suffered back injuries when hit by debris and a woman, 30, sustained several fractures as a result of the crash. Drysdale was the tail pilot of the four-member Brew Angels aerobatic team, which was performing a stunt called an end-tail roll.<ref>{{cite web|title=Air Show Continues After Fatal Crash|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1991-06-24/news/mn-813_1_redding-air-show}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=NTSB Identification: LAX91FA270|url=https://www.ntsb.gov/about/employment/_layouts/ntsb.aviation/brief.aspx?ev_id=20001212X17287&key=1|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref> *May 26 – [[RAAF Station Schofields|Schofields Airport]] ([[Blacktown]], New South Wales, Australia) – The pilot of a [[American Champion Decathlon|Bellanca Decathlon]] was killed when his aircraft stalled and crashed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pilot Dies In Air Show|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/122365880?searchTerm=air+show+crash|accessdate=5 June 2017|publisher=The Canberra Times|date=27 May 1991}}</ref>
==1990== * September 23 – ([[Baltimore County, Maryland]]) – 62-year-old pilot Jack B. Poage died after crashing his red-and-white [[Pitts Special|Pitts S-2B]] during an air show at [[Martin State Airport]] after he added a fourth corkscrew maneuver to three that were expected during a nosedive. He pulled the aircraft out of the corkscrew but had insufficient altitude and the Pitts Special hit the ground on its belly. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.apnews.com/e9e3b53db71e714dbeb75fc88e501b13|title=Stunt Pilot Dies At Air Show|publisher=AP News}}</ref> [[Carroll County Regional Airport]], which he managed at the time, was given the additional name Jack B. Poage Field in his honor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.carrollcountyairport.com/history.htm|title=History of the Carroll County Regional Airport|publisher=}}</ref> * September 16 – ([[Pápa]], Hungary) – A Hungarian [[MiG-23|MiG-23MF]] "04" crashed during an aerobatic display. The pilot, Major Károly Soproni died.<ref>http://www.plasticwings.hu/mig23/mig23.htm</ref> * September 9 – ([[Salgareda]], Italy) – A Soviet Su-27 coded "14 Red" crashed during an aerobatic display, killing its test pilot [[Rimantas Stankevičius]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4wlnnZZsx2k|title=Su-27 crash Salgareda Airshow 1990|first=|last=Tsobanian|date=July 23, 2007|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> * August 2 – ([[Oshkosh, Wisconsin]]) – pilot John Lewkowicz died after crashing his Boeing Stearman A75N-1 during an air show at the annual EAA National Convention [[Wittman Field]]. The aircraft was engaged in performing aerobatic maneuvers, entered a slow roll to the left, and at approximately the inverted position, the aircraft departed controlled flight. It then entered into an uncommanded snap roll to the left. The aircraft completed three-quarters of the roll, stopped in knife-edge flight and descended approximately 200 to 300 feet into the terrain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aircraftone.com/aircraft/accidents/20001212X23929.asp|title=Aircraft Accidents and Incidents - Oshkosh, Wisconsin 54903 Wittman Field Airport Thursday, August 2, 1990 16:42 CDT|publisher=}}</ref> * July 2 – [[Friendship Festival]] ([[Buffalo, New York]]) – Pilot Giff Foley was killed when his [[North American T-6 Texan|AT-6]] lost altitude and crashed into the [[Niagara River]].<ref>{{cite news| last =| first =| title = Air show pilot killed in crash |newspaper=Sun Journal |page=4 |agency=Associated Press |date=July 2, 1990 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iQ0gAAAAIBAJ&sjid=P2UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1327,26915&dq=airshow+crash&hl=en |accessdate=December 26, 2010}}</ref> * July 1 – National Capital Air Show ([[Ottawa, Ontario]], Canada) – Harry E. Tope was killed when his [[P-51 Mustang]] crashed into a golf course.<ref>{{cite web | title=Warbird Registry | url=http://www.warbirdregistry.org/p51registry/p51-4511586.html | accessdate=September 18, 2009}}</ref> * June 30 – Groton Air Show ([[Groton, Connecticut]]) – Russell Gage was killed while attempting to roll his aircraft on takeoff.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19900701&slug=1079910 | title=Stunt Pilot Killed in Air Show Crash | date=July 1, 1990 | work=Newspaper article | publisher=Seattle Times | accessdate=May 4, 2009}}</ref> * June 17 – ([[Will Rogers World Airport|Oklahoma City, US]]) – A small aircraft piloted by aerobatic champion Tom Jones crashed while performing during the Oklahoma City air show "Aerospace America." He was killed in the crash that was attributed to a low altitude stall.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ntsb.gov/aviationquery/brief.aspx?ev_id=20001212X23417&key=1 |title=Aircraft: SUKHOI SU-26MX, registration: N26TJ | date=December 15, 1992 | work=NTSB report | publisher=NTSB | accessdate=December 3, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.newsok.com/article/2321859?searched=tom%20jones%20killed&custom_click=search | title=City Flier Killed |date=June 24, 1990 |work=Newspaper article | publisher=The Daily Oklahoman | accessdate=July 24, 2010}}</ref> * May 27 – Memorial Day Air Show (Tuskegee, Alabama) – Pilot Albert Butler was killed while attempting a rollover at a low altitude.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1290&dat=19900528&id=hQdPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bI0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2605,5491276&hl=en|title = Stunt Pilot Dies In Air Show Crash |date = May 28, 1990 |accessdate = August 29, 2015 |newspaper = The News|page = 2}}</ref>
==1989== * October 8 – Indian Air Force Day ([[New Delhi|New Delhi, India]]) – Wing Commander Ramesh Bekshi of the Indian Air Force was killed when his [[Dassault Mirage 2000|Mirage 2000]] crashed while performing a series of downward rolls. A dozen spectators were injured, one fatally, from the explosions and fire.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/eyewitness-account-of-indian-air-force-aerobatics-tragedy/1/324035.html|title = Disastrous Display|last = Gupta|first = Shekhar|date = October 31, 1989 |accessdate=August 25, 2015 |publisher = India Today}}</ref> * September 3 – [[Canadian International Air Show]] (Toronto, Ontario) – Captain Shane Antaya, flying for the [[Canadian Forces Snowbirds]] team died after a mid-air collision during a demonstration when his Tutor crashed into [[Lake Ontario]]. During the same accident, team commander Major Dan Dempsey safely ejected from his aircraft.<ref>{{cite web | title=Two Snowbirds Crash over Lake Ontario | publisher=The Eugene Register Guard | date=Sep 4, 1989 | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HfNVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=y-EDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3304,979474&dq=snowbird&hl=en | accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> * June 8 – Paris Air Show (Paris, France) – During a low-speed, high angle-of-attack portion of Mikoyan's test pilot [[Anatoly Kvochur]]'s routine display flight, a bird sucked into the [[turbofan]] of his [[MiG-29]]'s right engine caused it to malfunction. After steering the MiG away from spectators, Kvochur managed to eject from the MiG seconds before his aircraft hit the ground.<ref>{{cite web |last=Johnson |first=Reuben |title=The Paris Air Show, Twenty Years On |publisher=The Weekly Standard |date=June 18, 2007 |url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/013/788wbhgw.asp | accessdate=September 18, 2009}}</ref> The incident was captured on video.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YL1FblthxQ0|title=Mig-29 crash at Paris Air Show Le Bourget 1989|first=|last=Tsobanian|date=June 23, 2007|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==1988== * September 5 – Farnborough Air Show (Farnborough, England) – A Soviet [[Antonov An-124 Ruslan|Antonov 124]] suffered engine failure and aborted its takeoff.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1309&dat=19880906&id=7BBZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=S5ADAAAAIBAJ&pg=5863,1349419&hl=en|title = Soviet Plane Aborts Takeoff At Air Show |date=September 6, 1988 |accessdate=August 30, 2015 |newspaper=New Straits Times |page=7}}</ref> * August 28 – Kleine Brogel Air Base ([[Peer, Belgium]]) Pilot Ari Piippo was killed when the [[Aermacchi M-290 RediGO|Aermacchi M-290 RediGo]] he was demonstrating failed to come out of a spin.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=336&dat=19880829&id=VVNTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=K4QDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5435,5893380&hl=en|title = Hours Later, A 2nd Air Show Crash |date = August 29, 1988 |accessdate = August 25, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = The Deseret News|others = |pages = |page = 2}}</ref> * August 28 – [[Ramstein airshow disaster]] ([[Ramstein-Miesenbach|Ramstein]], [[Germany]]) – Three members of Italy's [[Frecce Tricolori]] Air Force Display Team flying [[Aermacchi MB-339]]'s were involved in a mid-air collision. Three pilots, Lt. Col. Ivo Nutarelli, Lt. Col. Mario Naldini and Cap. Giorgio Alessio were killed, wreckage from the collision landed on the spectators, killing 67 people and seriously injuring 346.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * August 7 – [[Leopoldsburg|Leopoldsburg, Belgium]] – A Belgian Air Force pilot was killed when his [[Dassault Mirage 5|Mirage 5]] jet crashed at an air show organized by the Belgian Air Force.<ref name=":0" /> * June 26 – [[Air France Flight 296]] ([[Mulhouse-Habsheim Airport|Mulhouse]], [[Alsace]], [[France]]) – While performing a gear down low speed pass, a chartered [[Air France]] [[Airbus A320 family|Airbus A320]] lost altitude and crashed into a treeline. Three of the 136 persons aboard were killed.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * May 31 – Warwickshire Air Pageant ([[Baginton|Baginton, England]]) – RAF Flight Lieutenant Peter Stacey was killed when his [[Gloster Meteor|Meteor T.7]] lost altitude and crashed during a descending turn. Lieutenant Stacey was said to have stayed with the aircraft and steered it away from a residential area prior to the crash.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19880531&id=8DpAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=U1kMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4241,8538727&hl=en|title = Pilot Of Death Crash Fighter Hailed As Hero |date=May 31, 1988 |accessdate=August 30, 2015 |newspaper=The Glasgow Herald|page = 5}}</ref> *April 24 – Marine Corps Air Station El Toro, California – Marine Corps Colonel Jerry Cadick, then commanding officer of [[MAG-11]], was performing aerobatics before a crowd of 300,000 when he crashed his [[F/A-18 Hornet]] at the bottom of a loop that was too close to the ground. The aircraft was in a nose-high attitude, but still carrying too much momentum toward the ground when it impacted at more than 300 mph (480 km/h). Col. Cadick was subjected to extremely high G forces that resulted in his face making contact with the control stick, sustaining serious injuries. He broke his arm, elbow and ribs, exploded a vertebra and collapsed a lung. Col. Cadick survived and retired from the Marine Corps. The F/A-18 remained largely intact but was beyond repair.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/59818251.html?dids=59818251:59818251&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Apr+25%2C+1988&author=RICHARD+BEENE&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&edition=&startpage=1&desc=300%2C000+Watch+in+Horror+as+Fighter+Crashes+Spectators+Say+F%2FA-18+Jet+Appeared+to+Stall+as+Pilot+Was+Making+a+Loop | title=F/A-18 Hornet crash at MCAS El Toro Air Show, 1988 | publisher=LA Times | first=Richard | last=Beene | date=April 25, 1988}}</ref> *April 11 – Sun 'N Fun Fly in Lakeland, Florida – Pilot Ron Cox was injured after making a hard landing due to an onboard fire that occurred during a stunt presentation.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2202&dat=19880412&id=WAUmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8fwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2974,6909001&hl=en|title = Stunt Crash Injures Pilot |date = April 12, 1988 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = Gettysburg Times|page = 3}}</ref>
==1987== * September 6 – Mammoth Lakes Air Show – Civilian stunt pilot Gary Loundagin, 42, of Livermore, California, was killed when his vintage T-34B aircraft crashed, he had executed a loop maneuver with insufficient altitude for recovery. The aircraft impacted next to the runway but did not explode. The high elevation of the airport was probably not accounted for by Loundagin, contributing to the mishap.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-09-07/news/mn-4120_1_military-training-plane | work=Los Angeles Times | title=The State | date=September 7, 1987}}</ref> * August 8 – Fairfield County Air Show, [[Lancaster, Ohio]] – Pilot James King was killed when his biplane crashed while performing at the air show.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19870809&id=9KUeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Ns4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4200,2814988&hl=en|title = Man Dies In Stunt Crash |date = August 9, 1987 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = Spartansburg Herald-Journal|page = 3}}</ref>
==1986== * June 28 – SHAPE International Air Show, Chièvres Air Base, Belgium – After hovering a Hawker Siddeley Harrier GR.3 with a rearward movement, parallel to the public line at about 200 meters of altitude, R.A.F. Flt. Lt. Brian D. Weatherley ended with a nose down attitude that seemed steeper than usual. The aircraft nose kept going down past a recoverable angle. The pilot ejected while the aircraft was pointing straight towards the ground, still roughly stationary. He hit the ground before his parachute opened and later died from injuries sustained in the ejection. The aircraft (XW769) fell to the ground without explosion, but was deemed unrecoverable.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://aviation-safety.net/wikibase/wiki.php?id=55538 |title=ASN Aircraft accident 28-JUN-1986 Hawker Siddeley Harrier GR.3 XW769|first=Harro|last=Ranter}}</ref> * July 24 – RAF Brawdy Air Show, Wales UK. A US Phantom Jet crashed into the sea off the coast. Eye witness accounts at the time suggested something had fallen off the plane, before it rapidly headed for the sea, away from the crowds. The pilot and copilot both died. There were no injuries on the ground.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westerntelegraph.co.uk/news/9163011.25_years_since_tragic_air_crash_claimed_two_lives/|title=25 years since tragic air crash claimed two lives|publisher=}}</ref> * May 26 - Berlin Municipal Airport (Milan, New Hampshire) - Pilot Robert Weymouth, known as "The Flying Farmer", was killed when he failed to recover during a descent.<ref>{{Cite news |url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2457&dat=19860526&id=JCZfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Bk8NAAAAIBAJ&pg=4832,3676378&hl=en|title = 'Flying Farmer" Stunt Pilot Dies From Crash Injuries |date = May 26, 1986 |accessdate=August 26, 2015 |publisher=Associated Press|newspaper = Bangor Daily News|page = 18}}</ref> * May 26 - Mildenhall Air Show ([[Mildenhall, Suffolk]]) - The crew of a RAF Meteor was killed following the mid air collision with a RAF [[De Havilland Vampire|Vampire]]. The crew of the Vampire was able to parachute to safety.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19860526&id=qbZAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=t6UMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6541,6496661&hl=en|title = Two RAF Men Dies In Mid-Air Crash At Show |date = May 26, 1986 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Glasgow Herald|page = 1}}</ref>
==1985== * July 13 – Western New York Air Show '85 ([[Niagara Falls International Airport]], New York) – [[Blue Angels]] Aircraft 5, BuNo ''155029'', and 6, BuNo ''154992'', both [[Douglas A-4 Skyhawk|Douglas A-4F Skyhawk]]s, collided at the top of a loop, killing Lt. Cmdr. Michael Gershon. The other pilot, Lt. Andy Caputi, ejected safely with only minor injuries. One Skyhawk crashed in the airport grounds while the second fighter fell onto a nearby auto junkyard.<ref>Washington, D.C.: Washington Post, Associated Press, "''2 Jets in Navy Flight Team Collide; One Pilot Is Killed: Blue Angel Survivor Parachutes to Safety''", Sunday, July 14, 1985, page A-17</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://usmilitary.about.com/library/weekly/aa102899.htm|title=Aerial Demonstration Teams United States Navy and Marine Corps|publisher=}}</ref> The demonstration team resumed their show duties on July 20 at Dayton, Ohio but omitted the maneuver that resulted in the crash, and flew with five planes rather than six.<ref>Washington, D.C.: "''Around The Nation''", The Washington Post, Tuesday July 16, 1985, page A-4.</ref> * May 5 – Lemoore Naval Air Station Air Show – Civilian stunt pilot Kirk R. McKee of Sacramento, California, stalled his AT6A "Texan" aircraft after recovering from a Reverse Cuban Eight maneuver at low altitude. The aircraft crashed in an inverted, nose down attitude and exploded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aircraftone.com/aircraft/accidents/20001214X36488.asp|title=Aircraft Accidents and Incidents - Lemoore, California 93245 Lemoore Airport Sunday, May 5, 1985 12:45 PDT|publisher=}}</ref> * April 27 – An [[North American T-6 Texan|AT-6]] crashed during an air show at the [[El Toro Marine Corps Air Station]] when it apparently lost power, snagged a power line, smacked into the street and then slid into the chapel, killing the pilot Merrel Richard Gossman, 55, and passenger Robert G. Arrowsmith, 25. No one on the ground was hurt.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1985-04-28/local/me-21379_1_air-show "''2 Die as WWII Plane Crashes Into Chapel at El Toro Air Show''", April 28, 1985.] Retrieved June 5, 2012.</ref>
==1984== * November 11 – Fairview Fly-in and Air Show, Fairview, Oklahoma – Civilian stunt pilot Tom McGuire in a North American SNJ-5, [[North American T-6 Texan]], registered N91047, was recovering from a left aileron roll, the aircraft nose dropped and the aircraft turned 45 degrees to the right of the runway heading, it then impacted the ground in a shallow dive with the right wing low, killing the pilot. No one on the ground was hurt.<ref>[http://www.ntsb.gov/aviationquery/brief.aspx?ev_id=20001214X41565&key=1 NTSB Report for November 11, 1984 ground collision in Fairview, Oklahoma]</ref> * September 4 – A de Havilland Canada DHC-5D Buffalo plane, registered C-GCTC, was damaged beyond repair in an accident during the 1984 Farnborough Airshow. Following a STOL display, the aircraft performed a very steep descending right turn onto the threshold of the runway. Shortly before touchdown the rate of descent reduced slightly. The aircraft then landed very hard. The nose gear collapsed, both wings failed and the propellers disintegrated after contacting the runway. Debris caused some damage to vehicles and three aircraft in the static display area.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * August 12 - A [[PZL-104 Wilga]], registered SP-AFX, was one of three Wilgas flying in formation at an airshow at [[Fairyhouse Racecourse]].<ref name=aviation-safety-wilga>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/wikibase/wiki.php?id=176030|title=ASN Aircraft accident August 12, 1984 PZL-104 35A SP-AFX}}</ref><ref name=accident-investigation-wilga-1984>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Accident_to_PZL_104_Wilga_35A_Registrati.html?id=e90gYAAACAAJ|title=Accident to PZL-104 Wilga 35A Registration SP-AFX at Fairyhouse Racecourse on August 12, 1984: Report of the Investigation Made Under the Air Navigation (Investigation of Accidents) Regulations 1957 (S.I. No. 19 of 1957)|publisher=Irish Government Stationery Office|year=1984}}</ref> The aircraft were about to fly in front of the main stand when the aircraft stalled and crashed, killing the pilot, Jan Baran.<ref name=aviation-safety-wilga/><ref name=accident-investigation-wilga-1984/> There were no other fatalities.<ref name=aviation-safety-wilga/><ref name=accident-investigation-wilga-1984/> * June 3 – Großostheim near Aschaffenburg, Germany – A Hawker Siddeley Harrier GR3 launched vertically for a demonstration flight in front of the audience. The landing gear was extended during the Harrier was hovering. Because of a leak in the fuel supply fuel dripped onto the landing gear and ignited. The engine was sucking up smoke and lost thrust. From a height of about 90feet the Harrier crashed next to the runway and burst into flames – around 100 feet away from the audience. The pilot was able to escape with the ejection seat but the falling seat killed a spectator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.main-netz.de/nachrichten/region/aschaffenburg/aschaffenburg-land/berichte/art4012,842497|title=Tote bei Flugschau-Unglücken|publisher=}}</ref> * April 8 - Canary Islands Air Show ([[Canary Islands]]) - Pilot Augustin Gil de Montes lost control and crashed his Z-50 shortly after takeoff. He was killed along with four spectators and fourteen others were injured after his plane burst into flames and crashed through a barrier where the spectators were standing.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=943&dat=19840409&id=6y1QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=slYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5650,4341396&hl=en|title = 5 Killed In Stunt Plane Crash In Spain |date=April 9, 1984 |accessdate = August 24, 2015 |publisher=UPI |newspaper=Mohave Daily Miner |page=4}}</ref>
==1983== *September 11 – Plainview, Texas – The wings of a [[Partenavia P.68]]C separated from the root just outboard of the engine nacelles during a high-speed, high-G maneuver beyond the design parameters of the aircraft and plummeted to the ground, killing the pilot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myplainview.com/article_ccbb44dd-0be0-5bc5-a359-4ff79e22f2ff.html|title=Looking Back: Oh my God! 04-27-2008|publisher=}}</ref> *August 26 - Scarborough, UK - Lightning F3 XP753 stalled and crashed 200 yds from the shoreline, killing pilot Flt/Lt Mike Thompson whilst performing an unauthorised flying display at a seafront event.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} *July 31 – Experimental Aircraft Association (Oshkosh, Wisconsin) – Arlin Pestes was killed when his [[Van's Aircraft RV-3]] lost altitude and crashed during a formation fly over.<ref>{{cite news | title = Crash mars air show; other fatals reported| newspaper = Kingman Daily Miner| page = 2 | agency = Associated Press| date =August 1, 1983| url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=46dPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=slIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5423,3080627&dq=air+show+accident&hl=en| accessdate =January 3, 2011}}</ref> *July 9 - Gadsden Airport ([[Gadsden, Alabama]]) - Pilot Harry Claxton and passenger Dr. George Horn were killed when their [[Aeronca Chief family|Aeronca AR-7]] dove and crashed while making a turn during a mock battle. It is believed that loose tools and missing cover boots caused the control yoke to jam causing the accident.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1891&dat=19830719&id=kZ4fAAAAIBAJ&sjid=B9YEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3481,3013971&hl=en|title = Mechanical Failure Ruled Out In Crash at Airshow|last = Bolton|first = Mark|date = July 19, 1983 |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |newspaper = Gadsden Times|page = B1}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.asias.faa.gov/pls/apex/f?p=100:17:0::NO::AP_BRIEF_RPT_VAR:ATL83FKJ05|title = NTSB Aviation Accident and Incident Data System (NTSB) Brief Report(s)|date = |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |publisher = Federal Aviation Administration}}</ref> *May 22 – ([[Rhein-Main Air Base]], [[Frankfurt, Germany]]) – A Canadian Forces [[F-104 Starfighter|CF-104 Starfighter]], ''104813'', of 439 Sqn., exploded in mid-air. Wreckage falling on a nearby road hit the car of priest Martin Jürges and killed three adults and two children. The sixth passenger in the car, Jürges' niece, died months later from her burns. A Canadian Forces spokesman said that the CF-104, flown by Capt. Alan J. Stephenson, 27, was in a formation of five Starfighters, and that he was to do a solo display. He had done two complete circuits and had leveled off for a low-speed fly-past when the plane malfunctioned. He ejected safely.<ref>Washington, D.C., "''5 Die When Jet Crashes at Air Show''", Washington Post, Monday May 23, 1983, Page A-22, Column 1.</ref> *May 15 - Barton Airfield ([[Manchester|Manchester, England]]) - Stunt pilot Mike Watkins was killed when he lost control of his P-51 Mustang, entered a corkscrew spin, and crashed.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19830516&id=4BshAAAAIBAJ&sjid=F2EEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6604,33381&hl=en|title = Stunt Pilot Killed In Airshow Crash |date = May 16, 1983 |accessdate = August 29, 2015 |publisher = UPI|newspaper = The Pittsburgh Press|page = 4}}</ref>
==1982== *November 14 – ([[Hamamatsu|Hamamatsu, Japan]]) – Captain Takashima Kiyoshi was killed and 12 spectators were injured when the [[Mitsubishi T-2|Mitsubishi T-2B]] he was flying, as part of the [[Blue Impulse]] aerobatic demonstration team, failed to pull out of a vertical dive and crashed into a building.<ref>{{cite web|title=Japan Investigates Fatal Air-Show Accident|work=Reading Eagle |publisher=UPI|date=November 15, 1982|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19821115&id=6RsiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=H6cFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5098,4488287|accessdate=March 16, 2015}}</ref> *September 11 – ([[Mannheim, Germany]]) – A United States Army [[CH-47 Chinook]] (serial number 74-22292) crashed while carrying British, French, and German [[parachuting|parachutists]] who planned to jump when the helicopter reached an altitude of {{convert|12000|ft|m|abbr=on}}. All 46 aboard were killed. The crash was later found to be caused by an accumulation of ground [[walnut]] shells that had been used to clean the machinery.<ref>[http://www.chinook-helicopter.com/history/aircraft/C_Models/74-22292/74-22292.html Description of crash of Chinook 74-22292], Chinook-helicopter.com.</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/world/europe/2156004.stm Air show safety in the spotlight], BBC, July 27, 2002.</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20081201062955/http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F2/769/769.F2d.115.84-1446.html ''Ursula J. Schoenborn v. The Boeing Company'', 769 F.2d 115 (3d Cir. 1985) – a case in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit]</ref> *May 16 - Shelby County Air Show ([[Alabaster, Alabama]]) Pilot Don Smith was killed when his [[Piper J-3 Cub]] failed to pull out of a spin.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1891&dat=19820518&id=QQ8qAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PNYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1380,3244534&hl=en|title = Airplane Stunt Turns To Tragedy |date = May 18, 1982 |accessdate = August 25, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = Gadsden Times|page = 1}}</ref> *January 18 – ([[Indian Springs Air Force Auxiliary Field]]) – All 4 USAF Thunderbirds pilots were killed in the [[1982 Thunderbirds Indian Springs Diamond Crash|Diamond crash]].{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
==1981== *May 9 – ([[Hill Air Force Base|Hill Air Force Base, Utah]]) – A [[U.S. Air Force Thunderbirds]] Northrop [[T-38 Talon]] crashed while performing the Hi-Lo Maneuver, killing pilot Captain David "Nick" Hauck.<ref>[http://thunderbirdsalumni.org/news/documents/TR_vol2_spring02.pdf Janett, Jim (Spring 2002). ''ThunderRolls, The USAF Thunderbirds Alumni Association Newsletter''. Vol 2, p. 3] (PDF)</ref> Capt. Hauk, in Thunderbird 6, crashed while attempting to land his ailing T-38 after an engine malfunctioned and caught fire. With black smoke billowing from the exhaust and the aircraft losing altitude in a high nose-up attitude, the safety officer on the ground radioed Capt Hauck: "You’re on fire, punch out", to which he responded: “Hang on... we have a bunch of people down there”. The aircraft continued to fight to stay airborne for about half a mile before hitting a large oak tree and a barn, then sliding across a field and flipping as it traversed an irrigation canal ultimately erupting into a fireball just a few hundred feet from the runway's end. No one on the ground was injured even though the accident occurred adjacent to a roadway packed with onlookers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wingsoverkansas.com/features/article.asp?id=662|title=U.S. Air Force Thunderbirds -|publisher=}}</ref>
==1980== *September 21 - Joliet Park District Airport ([[Joliet, Illinois]]) - Three United States Marine service members were killed and one injured when their [[Bell UH-1 Iroquois|Huey H-1]] helicopter stalled and crashed when it pulled up from a low high speed pass.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=799&dat=19800922&id=Q6dPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mFEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4194,6796366&hl=en|title = Three Air Show Tragedies Kill 12 |date = September 22, 1980 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = UPI|newspaper = The Byran Times|page = 1}}</ref> *September 21 – ([[London Biggin Hill Airport|Biggin Hill, London, England]]) – A Douglas [[A-26 Invader]] crashed during an air display. The aircraft was attempting to carry out a climbing roll in front of the crowd when the nose dropped sharply, and the aircraft continued rolling until it dropped vertically into a valley. The pilot and seven passengers were killed.
