The [[Civil Aviation Authority of the United Kingdom|Civil Aviation Authority]] subsequently introduced rules preventing passengers from being carried during air displays.<ref>{{cite web|title=B-26 crash at Biggin Hill|url=http://napoleon130.tripod.com/id250.html}}</ref> *June 15 – (Shannon Airport, [[Fredericksburg, Virginia]]) – Sgt. 1st Class Tom Johnson, a parachute jumper with the [[U.S. Army]] [[United States Army Parachute Team|Golden Knights]], fell over 10,000 feet to his death when both of his parachutes (main and reserve) failed to deploy.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YskaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AUcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3027%2C3157377|title = Army Parachutist Plunges to Death |date=June 16, 1980 |accessdate = May 1, 2017 |publisher = News Publishing, LLC.|newspaper = Daily News|page = 6}}</ref> *April 17 - American Samoan Flag Day ([[Pago Pago|Pago Pago, American Samoa]]) - The seven member crew of an American Navy [[Lockheed P-3 Orion|P-3 Orion]] were killed when their plane struck a cable car wire, lost its right wing and tail, and cartwheeled into a local hotel causing a fire. Five hotel staff and one guest were injured in the accident which destroyed one wing of the hotel.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1916&dat=19800418&id=aOkgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=H24FAAAAIBAJ&pg=3148,3748426&hl=en|title = Navy Plane Crashes Into Hotel |date=April 18, 1980 |accessdate = August 29, 2015 |publisher = UPI|newspaper = The Hour|page = 21}}</ref>
==1979== * May 27 - Capt. Pier Gianni Petri of the Frecce Tricolori crashed and died at the RAF Mildenhall Airshow. Capt. Petri was flying a Fiat G91 which failed to recover from its dive during a “Bomb Burst” maneuver and crashed near the village of Beck Row. No one on the ground was injured during the accident. * July 6 - Chicksands Royal Air Force Base ([[Chicksands|Chicksands, England]]) - An unidentified United States Air Force pilot was killed when his [[Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II|A-10A]] crashed while doing low-level aerobatics. It was reported that he stayed with his plane and steered it away from the crowds.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1842&dat=19790708&id=9RQsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CskEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2472,1594183&hl=en|title = American Pilot Dies In Crash |date = July 8, 1979 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = UPI|newspaper = Times Daily|page = 7}}</ref> * September 3 - ([[Dillon, Montana]]) - Captain Joel Rude, 32 years old, of Great Falls, Montana, was a flight training instructor for the Montana Air National Guard was killed when his U.S. Air Force [[F-106 Delta Dart]] from the 186th Fighter-Interceptor Squadron was making a low flight over a Labor Day parade on Dillon's main street, crashed into a grain elevator and exploded, killing the pilot and setting a bulk oil storage plant on fire. Much of the city's electrical power was knocked out, the police reported. At least eight other persons on the ground were injured, four of them severely enough to be admitted to hospitals.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1979/09/04/archives/jet-flying-over-labor-day-parade-hits-a-grain-elevator-in-montana.html?_r=0 |title=Jet Flying Over Labor Day Parade Hits a Grain Elevator in Montana |date=September 4, 1979 |accessdate=January 24, 2017 |publisher=New York Times - ARCHIVES}}</ref>
==1978== *November 8 – One of the solo Skyhawks of the [[Blue Angels]] struck the ground after low roll during arrival maneuvers at [[MCAS Miramar|NAS Miramar]]. Navy Lieutenant Michael Curtin was killed. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blueangels-usn.org/accident_history.html|title=Welcome blueangels-usn.org - Hostmonster.com|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160614012518/http://www.blueangels-usn.org/accident_history.html|archivedate=June 14, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The accident was caught on film. *August 12 – ([[Glenview, Cook County, Illinois|Glenview, Illinois]]) – [[Avro Vulcan|Avro Vulcan B2]] ''[[United Kingdom military aircraft serials|XL390]]'' of [[No. 617 Squadron RAF|617 Squadron]] [[Royal Air Force]] crashed during an air display at [[Naval Air Station Glenview]], just north of [[Chicago]]. All four Royal Air Force crew members were killed. Their delta-winged bomber apparently stalled during a wing-over and then crashed into a landfill just north of Willow Road.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Unger |first=Robert |author-link=Robert Unger |last2=Benjamin |first2=Robert |author2-link=Robert Benjamin |title=Glenview Jet Crash 4 Die |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |page=S1 |date=August 12, 1978}}</ref> * May 3 – ([[Grande Prairie, Alberta]]) – Captain Gordon de Jong of the [[Canadian Forces Snowbirds]] died when the horizontal stabilizer failed, rendering the aircraft uncontrollable. Although ejection was initiated, it was not successful.<ref>Dempsey, Daniel V. ''A Tradition of Excellence: Canada's Airshow Team Heritage''. Victoria, BC: High Flight Enterprises, 2002. p. 569. {{ISBN|0-9687817-0-5}}</ref> *February 25 - [[Dubbo|Dubbo Airshow]] ([[New South Wales|New South Wales, Australia]]) - Pilot Bryan Hindle was killed when his motorized hang glider crashed during an air show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Death Crash|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/110885345?searchTerm=air+show+crash|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=The Canberra Times|date=1 March 1978}}</ref>
==1977== * October 9 – Lanseria Airport, near Johannesburg, South Africa – Demonstration Pilot Peter Philips flying a Britten-Norman Trislander in flying display performed a second wing-over and had insufficient altitude to recover. Impacted the runway and bounced into the air and came to rest some 500m further off to the side of the runway. The flying controls were disabled and main gear detached. One wing engine detached. Philips was accompanied by Mike Wrigly – both survived with minor injuries although had to spend a few days in hospital. Aircraft written off.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} *September 23 – Suffolk Air Fair press preview ([[Westhampton Beach, New York]]) – Stunt pilot Edward H. Mahler was killed at [[Suffolk County Airport]] when the tail section of his biplane separated at an altitude of 300 feet. An hour before the accident he had repaired a loose strut on the tail section of his plane.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title = Stunt pilot repairs plane, then crashes| work = The Byran Times| publisher = UPI| date = September 24, 1977| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=El4RAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FYgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3837,6982174&dq=air+show+disaster | archive-url = https://archive.is/20120722234958/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=El4RAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FYgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3837,6982174&dq=air+show+disaster | dead-url = yes | archive-date = July 22, 2012 |accessdate=July 15, 2009}}</ref> *September 2 – [[Canadian International Air Show]] (Toronto, Ontario, Canada) – Pilot Alan Ness was killed when his [[Fairey Firefly]] lost altitude and crashed in Lake Ontario while taking part in a formation flight.<ref>{{Cite news| title =160,00 at air show watch fatal crash| newspaper =The Montreal Gazette| page =4| publisher =CP| date =September 3, 1977| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=t5AjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=i6EFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2247,380064&dq=air+show+accident&hl=en| accessdate =January 3, 2011}}</ref> *June 3 – Paris Air Show (Paris, France) – Test pilot Howard W. "Sam" Nelson was killed when his [[A-10 Thunderbolt II]] crashed after coming out of a loop at low altitude.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title = U.S. jet pilot fatally injured at Paris show| work = Eugene Register-Guard| publisher = UPI| date = June 3, 1977| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZLITAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mdkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5388,596671&dq=air+show+disaster | archive-url = https://archive.is/20120716204325/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZLITAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mdkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5388,596671&dq=air+show+disaster | dead-url = yes | archive-date = July 16, 2012 |accessdate=July 15, 2009}}</ref> *May 15 – Biggin Hill Air Show ([[Biggin Hill]], London, England) – Five persons were killed and one injured when a sightseeing helicopter struck the underside of a [[de Havilland Tiger Moth]] biplane at an altitude of 200 feet. The biplane, with "its undercarriage sheared off", was able to land safely with no injuries to the pilot or passenger.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
==1976== *September 26 – Weyers Cave Air Show ([[Weyers Cave, Virginia]]) – Flight instructor Jerry Pressen was killed when his plane stalled as he pulled out of a climb and crashed.<ref>{{cite news| last = | first =| authorlink =| title = Stunt flier dies in crash| work = The Free-Lance Star| agency = Associated Press| date = September 27, 1976| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_Q4QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=A4wDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4581,3411483&dq=air+show+disaster | archive-url = https://archive.is/20120713105650/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_Q4QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=A4wDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4581,3411483&dq=air+show+disaster | dead-url = yes | archive-date = July 13, 2012 |accessdate=July 15, 2009}}</ref> *August 28 – Gathering of Warbirds ([[Fresno, California]]) – Pilot Cliff Anderson was killed when his home built Stolp Starduster I SA100 aerobatic biplane crashed and burned after he was unable to recover from an [[Spin (flight)|inverted spin]].<ref>{{cite web |title=From Aerial Applications to Aerobatics August 28, 1976 Fresno, California |publisher=Check-Six.com |year=2002 |url=http://www.check-six.com/Crash_Sites/Anderson-N8581.htm |accessdate=December 26, 2010}}</ref>
==1975== *September 13 – [[Reno Air Races]] – M.D. Washburn, 40, of Houston, Texas, died when the wing of his [[North American T-6 Texan]] clipped a pylon and crashed while in a tight formation at the start of the race.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} *September 13 – [[Reno Air Races]] – While [[wing walking]], Gordon McCollom of Costa Mesa, Calif. was hanging under a plane piloted by Joe Hughes. It suddenly dropped too close to the runway in what one official called a "freakish downdraft" and McCollom scraped his upper head on the runway, dying instantly. Hughes was able to regain control of the plane and land. The accident occurred directly in front of the grandstand just 15 minutes after Washburn's fatal accident.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} The accident was caught on film.
==1974== *September 8 – [[Naval Air Station South Weymouth|South Weymouth Naval Air Station]] ([[Massachusetts]]) – A [[Bellanca]] 8KCAB ''N86589'' crashed nearly vertically into the ground while performing a controlled, acrobatic, half-twist maneuver. Fire after impact. Misjudged altitude and clearance, killing its pilot.<ref>[http://www.ntsb.gov/aviationquery/brief.aspx?ev_id=39138&key=0]</ref> *September 1 - Farnborough Airshow (Hampshire, United Kingdom) - Co-pilot Stewart Craig was killed instantly and pilot Kurt Cannon died nine days after their [[Sikorsky S-67 Blackhawk]] helicopter crashed during low level maneuvers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pilot Dies|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/136985006?searchTerm=air+show+crash|accessdate=5 June 2017|publisher=The Canberra Times|date=12 September 1974}}</ref> *July 28 - [[General Mitchell International Airport]] (Milwaukee, Wisconsin) - United States Marine Captain Stephen Torrent suffered minor injuries after ejecting from his [[Hawker Siddeley Harrier|Hawker Harrier]] that dove and crashed while demonstrating vertical takeoffs.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19740729&id=LEBSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=SHkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6309,3028269&hl=en|title = Pilot Lives After Fiery Plane Crash |date = July 29, 1974 |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |publisher = UPI|newspaper = St. Petersburg Times|page = 1}}</ref>
==1973== *June 3 – Paris Air Show (Paris, France) – The first production [[Tupolev Tu-144]] supersonic airliner [[1973 Paris Air Show crash|crashed]] after it disintegrated in mid-air during a flight demonstration, killing all six on board and eight on the ground. The cause of the crash remains controversial and the focus of several conspiracy theories.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} *July 8 – Lake Charles, LA – Lt. Steve Lambert, flying a Blue Angels F-4J Phantom II s/n 153876, had a mechanical issue and had to eject from his aircraft during that Sunday's performance. Lt. Lambert survived with only minor scratches, his aircraft was destroyed.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
==1972== *September 24 – Golden West Sport Aviation Show ([[Sacramento, California]]) – A privately owned [[F-86 Sabre]] jet piloted by Richard Bingham failed to take off while leaving the show. The jet went through a chain link fence at the end of the runway, across Freeport Boulevard, crushed a parked car and then [[1972 Sacramento Canadair Sabre accident|crashed]] into a local [[Farrell's Ice Cream Parlour]]. Twenty-two people were killed, including twelve children and two people in the parked car.<ref>{{cite web| last = | first = | authorlink = | title = The Crash at Farrell's Ice Cream Parlor in Sacramento, CA – September 24, 1972| work = | publisher = Check Six| year = 2002 | url = http://www.check-six.com/Crash_Sites/Sabrejet_crash_site.htm| doi = | accessdate = June 25, 2008}}</ref> * June 10 – Trenton Air Show at [[CFB Trenton]], [[Ontario]] – Canadian air force [[Snowbirds]] solo Captain Lloyd Waterer died after a wingtip collision with the other solo aircraft while performing an opposing solo manoeuvre.<ref>Dempsey, Daniel V. ''A Tradition of Excellence: Canada's Airshow Team Heritage''. Victoria, BC: High Flight Enterprises, 2002. p. 546. {{ISBN|0-9687817-0-5}}</ref> *June 4 – [[Transpo 72]] Airshow ([[Washington, D.C.]]) – Major Joe Howard of the [[US Air Force Thunderbirds]] flying Thunderbird 3 was killed at [[Dulles International Airport]] when his [[F-4 Phantom II|F-4E-32-MC Phantom II]], ''66-0321'', lost power during a vertical maneuver. The pilot broke out of formation just after he completed a wedge roll and was ascending at around 2,500 feet [[Above ground level|AGL]]. The aircraft staggered and descended in a flat attitude with little forward speed. Although Major Howard ejected and descended under a good canopy, winds blew him into the ascending fireball. The parachute melted and the pilot plummeted 200 feet, sustaining fatal injuries.<ref>USAF Aircraft Accidents – Life Sciences Aspects, April–June 1972, Directorate of Aerospace Safety, Air Force Inspection and Safety Center, Norton AFB, California, pages 59–60.</ref>
==1971== *August 22 - [[Seething|Seething, Norfolk]] - Pilot Neville Browning was killed while inverted during a "Flying Farmer" performance.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1301&dat=19710824&id=-whFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fuUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5085,8887006&hl=en |title = Stunt Crash |date= August 24, 1971 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Sydney Morning Herald|page = 3}}</ref> *June 6 - Robertson Airfield ([[Plainville, Connecticut]]) - Pilot Gilbert Gillete was killed when his biplane entered a spin at low altitude.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1898&dat=19710607&id=oAUhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=73UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5919,989728&hl=en|title = Pilot Dives To Death; Eight Fatalities In State |date = June 7, 1971 |accessdate=August 30, 2015 |publisher = UPI|newspaper = The Norwalk Hour|page = 1}}</ref> *June 5 – Quonset Point Air Show ([[Quonset Point]], [[Rhode Island]]) – J.W. "Bill" Fornof flying an [[F8F Bearcat]] died after losing a wing to metal fatigue.<ref>{{cite web| last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Courier reports on death of local aviator| work = | publisher = Daily Comet| year = 2011| url = http://www.dailycomet.com/article/20110608/ARTICLES/110609498/| doi = | accessdate = December 26, 2014}}</ref>
==1970== *September 26 - St. Paul, Minnesota - Mechanic Sgt. Foster G. Crump was killed and pilot Col. Robert Leighton was injured when their replica 1919 biplane crashed shortly after takeoff.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rider Dies In Crash Of Replica 1919 Plane|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1970/09/28/page/3/article/rider-dies-in-crash-of-1919-replica-plane|accessdate=30 May 2017|publisher=UPI|date=28 September 1970}}</ref> *September 11 – Farnborough Air Show (Hampshire, England) – A Wallis WA-117 Gyrocoptor was being demonstrated at the Society of British Aerospace Companies (SBAC). After a high-speed downwind run parallel to the runway, the aircraft first pitched rapidly nose-up, then nose-down, and went out of control, the rotor blades striking the propeller, fin and rudder as it fell to the ground. The pilot was killed instantly.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} *August 30 – ([[Cedar Rapids, Iowa]]) – One of the members of the US Navy [[Blue Angels]] belly-landed at [[Eastern Iowa Airport]] with one engine stuck in afterburner. The pilot ejected safely, the aircraft ran off the runway.<ref>{{cite web |title=Blue Angels Losses & Ejectees |publisher=ejection-history.org |url = http://www.ejection-history.org.uk/AEROBATIC/Blue_Angels/Blue_Angels.htm |accessdate=September 17, 2009}}</ref> *June 1970 – Woodford airshow Cheshire, Hornet Gyrocoptor crashed killing the pilot, rotor broke smashing the rudder causing the gyrocoptor to lose control.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} *February 15 - Wellsford Airstrip ([[Bendigo|Bendigo, Australia]]) - Pilot Donald Busch was killed when his P-51 Mustang crashed after it gained altitude and rolled over following a fly past of the show grounds.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1300&dat=19700216&id=PTFVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4pADAAAAIBAJ&pg=3746,2981907&hl=en|title = Fly-past Pilot Dies In Gala Day Crash |date = February 16, 1970 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Age|page = 1}}</ref>
==1969== *August 8 – Abbotsford Air Show ([[Abbotsford, British Columbia]]) – At noon a Boeing 747 airliner made its Canadian debut with a low flypast to open the first day of the three-day airshow. This was followed a few minutes later by an inverted pass of a much smaller aircraft along the same flight line. Nearing midfield the Mini Mustang N9N suddenly dove vertically into the ground killing the pilot, 20-year-old flight instructor Scott Nelskog from Washington State.<ref>http://www.ntsb.gov/aviationquery/brief.aspx?ev_id=5658&key=0</ref><ref>http://abbotsfordairshow.com/index.php?p=1_9_HISTORY</ref> *June 4 – Reading Air Show ([[Reading, Pennsylvania]]) – Captain Dick Schram, a Naval Reserve Aviator "billed as the Flying Professor", was killed when his [[Piper J-3|Piper Cub]] failed to pull out of a dive during a comedy flying routine. His son, a public affairs officer with the United States Navy Blue Angels, was announcing the routine at the time of the crash.<ref>{{Cite news| title = Stunt Pilot Killed At Local Airport | newspaper = Reading Eagle| page =1| publisher =| date = June 5, 1969| url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3JQtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cKAFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4225,2600684&dq=air+show+accident&hl=en| accessdate =January 3, 2011}}</ref>
==1968== *September 20 – Farnborough Air Show ([[Hampshire]], England) – Six members of the French Air Force were killed when their [[Breguet Atlantic|Breguet 1150 Atlantic]] crashed while performing a single engine demonstration.<ref>{{cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=British Air Show Crash Kills 6 |work= |publisher=St. Petersburg Times |date=September 21, 1968 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ohoMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KFwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1483,58909&dq=airshow+crash |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120716163710/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ohoMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KFwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1483,58909&dq=airshow+crash |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 16, 2012 |format= |doi= |accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref> *May 17 - Armed Forces Day Air Show ([[Holloman Air Force Base]], New Mexico) - A United States Air Force [[General Dynamics F-111 Aardvark|F-111]] experienced a [[tailstrike]] and skidded to a stop 100 yards from 2,000 spectators while landing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Inquiry On F-111 Crash Begins|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/107053060?searchTerm=air+show+crash|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=The Canberra Times|date=21 May 1968}}</ref>
==1967== *October 21 – Thunderbirds F-100D piloted by Tony McPeak crashed at Laughlin AFB, Texas, United States. The accident occurred during the "Bomb Burst" maneuver when the solo aircraft piloted by McPeak shed its wings during a vertical rolling climb. The accident was attributed to failure of the wing structure due to fatigue. McPeak successfully ejected from the aircraft.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} *June 4 – A member of the Patrouille de France Display Team, died when his [[Fouga Magister]] went out of control during the display at the 1967 Paris Air Show at Le Bourget, France.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Two jets crash at Paris show |day_of_week=Monday |date=5 June 1967 |page_number=1 |issue=56959 |column= }}</ref>
==1966== *September 2 – [[Canadian International Air Show]] (Toronto, Ontario) – US Navy Blue Angels pilot Lt. Cmdr. Dick Oliver was killed when he crashed his [[F-11 Tiger]] into a breakwater at [[Toronto Island Airport]].<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink = | title = Richard Carl Oliver Lieutenant Commander, United States Navy| work = Arlington National Cemetery Website| publisher =| url = http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/richard-carl-oliver.htm| doi = | accessdate = July 21, 2009}}</ref> *August 13 – Aviation Day ([[Amarillo Air Force Base]], Texas) – Shelby M. Kritser, chairman of the Texas Aeronautics Commission, was killed when his [[F8F Bearcat]] crashed during an attempted hammerhead stall.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title = Crash Kills Texas Chief Of Aviation| work =| publisher = The Victoria Advocate| date = August 13, 1966| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WT0OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TH8DAAAAIBAJ&dq=amarillo&pg=4580%2C1670718 |accessdate=September 17, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=NTSB Identification: FTW67A0024 |publisher=NTSB |date=August 13, 1966 |url=http://www.ntsb.gov/ntsb/brief.asp?ev_id=23955&key=0 |accessdate=September 17, 2009}}</ref> *July 23 - Porter County Municipal Airport ([[Valparaiso, Indiana]]) - Stunt pilot Bill Adams was killed when the wing separated from his biplane during an outside snap roll.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19660724&id=gLIhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IpwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4480,4384483&hl=en|title = Stunt Pilot Dies In Crash |date = July 24, 1966 |accessdate = August 29, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = Reading Eagle|page = 12}}</ref>
==1965== *June 15 – Paris Air Show (Paris, France) – United States Air Force Lt Colonel Charles D. Tubbs was killed and two other crewmen injured when their [[B-58 Hustler]] bomber crashed. The plane landed short of the runway, struck the "instrument approach beacons" and burst into flames.<ref>{{cite news| last = Hudgins| first = Garven| authorlink =| title = U.S. Air Crash Mars Paris Air Show| work = Pittsburgh Post-Gazette| agency = Associated Press| date = June 16, 1965| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WD8NAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hGwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7679,2416672&dq=air+show+accident| format =| doi =| accessdate =July 12, 2009}}</ref>
==1964== *September 13 – [[Farnborough Airshow|Farnborough Air Display]], [[Farnborough, Hampshire]], UK) – Bristol Bulldog Mk.IIA G-ABBB / `K2227' (registered new in 1930) crashed at the [[Society of British Aerospace Companies|SBAC]] Farnborough show. After several slow loops at low altitude the engine cut out at the top of a loop, possibly due to magneto failure. The pilot had little chance of recovery and the aircraft crashed through the crowd barrier from the outside, the pilot, Ian Williamson, escaping with cuts and bruises.<ref name="RAF Museum">http://www.rafmuseum.org.uk/documents/collections/1994-1386-A-Bristol-Bulldog.pdf</ref> *May 9 – ([[Hamilton AFB]], California) – United States Air Force Capt. Eugene J. Devlin was killed when a [[Republic F-105 Thunderchief|Republic F-105B Thunderchief]], ''57-5801'', Thunderbird 2, delivered to the [[US Air Force Thunderbirds]] demonstration team in April 1964, suffered structural failure and disintegrated during 6G tactical pitch-up for landing after an air display. The failure of the fuselage's upper spine caused the USAF to ground all F-105s and retrofit the fleet with a structural brace, but the air demonstration team reverted to the [[F-100 Super Sabre]] and never flew another show in F-105s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.att.net/~jbaugher/1957.html |title=1957 USAF Serial Numbers |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991008201958/http://home.att.net/~jbaugher/1957.html |archivedate=October 8, 1999 |df= }}</ref><ref>Thompson, Warren E., "''F-105 Thunderchief''", Combat Aircraft, Ian Allan Publishing, Hersham, Surrey, UK, February–March 2009, Volume 10, Number 1, page 68.</ref> * May 3 – Armed Forces Day exhibition ([[Bremerhaven|Bremerhaven, Germany]]) – Major Thomas Eugene Perfili, an American flight instructor attached to the West German Air Force, was killed in the crash of his [[Lockheed F-104 Starfighter|Starfighter]] after losing power while demonstrating rolls. He guided his plane away from spectators but was unable to eject.<ref>{{Cite news| title =Pilot Killed Guiding Jet From Crowd| newspaper =The Montreal Gazette| page =44| publisher =UPI| date=May 4, 1964| url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Bp4tAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oJ8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=4378,741926&hl=en| accessdate=January 3, 2011}}</ref>
==1963== * September 9 - Kent Air Display ([[Rochester, Kent|Rochester, England]]) - Pilot Neville Browning suffered minor injuries following the crash of his [[De Havilland Tiger Moth|Tiger Moth]] aircraft.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19630909&id=s2JAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hKMMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3047,1200482&hl=en|title = Crash At Kent Air Display |date=September 9, 1963 |accessdate=August 30, 2015 |newspaper=The Glasgow Herald |page=13}}</ref> * July 21 - Caselle Airport ([[Turin|Turin, Italy]]) - While skimming the ground during an airshow Italian Air Force pilot Mario Pisano struck a parked automobile, veered into a crowd of people killing one from the propeller and injuring three and finally struck an empty bus. He was not injured in the crash.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19630722&id=sB9OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5EoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4393,2275636&hl=en|title = Stunt Plane Crash Kills Italian Girl |date = July 22, 1963 |accessdate=August 24, 2015 |publisher=Associated Press |newspaper = The Victoria Advocate|page = 2}}</ref> * July 14 - Naval Air Display ([[Lossiemouth|Lossiemouth, Scotland]]) The pilot of a [[Fairey Gannet|Gannet]] aircraft was unhurt following a crash landing caused by an engine failure.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19630715&id=jm5AAAAAIBAJ&sjid=i6MMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2226,2164684&hl=en|title = Crash At Air Display |date = July 15, 1963 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Glasgow Herald|page = 4}}</ref> *July 4 - [[Moline, Illinois]] - Skydiver John Talbott was killed and three others injured when their plane crashed during takeoff, in rainy conditions, while heading to perform during Fourth of July festivities.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sky Diver Dies In Take-Off Of Plane; 3 Hurt|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1963/07/05/page/21/article/sky-diver-dies-in-take-off-of-plane-3-hurt|accessdate=30 May 2017|publisher=UPI|date=5 July 1963}}</ref>
==1962== *October 2 – Public Air Display, [[Sydney, New South Wales|Sydney]] Harbor, Australia – Two [[De Havilland Sea Venom]]s of the Royal Australian Navy collided during an air display over the Harbor. Lieutenant Albert 'Albie' Riley ejected from his aircraft at only 500 feet and survived with minor injuries. His aircraft crashed into the water close to what would be the site of the Sydney Opera House. The second Venom piloted by Lieutenant B. Roberts, although badly damaged, managed to make it back to its base at [[Nowra, New South Wales|Nowra]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ejection-history.org.uk/country-by-country/australia.htm|title=Australia|publisher=|access-date=January 28, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070218194225/http://www.ejection-history.org.uk/Country-By-Country/Australia.htm|archive-date=February 18, 2007|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *September 3 - National Air Show ([[Chino, California]]) - Stunt pilot Cliff Winters was killed when his engine failed during a roll.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1243&dat=19620905&id=TDpYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=V_cDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6853,785857&hl=en|title = He Died The Way He Said He Would |date=September 5, 1962 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = UPI|newspaper = The Bulletin|page = 8}}</ref> *April 21 - [[Century 21 Exposition|Seattle World's Fair]] (Seattle, Washington) - Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Smith were killed in their residence after a [[Convair F-102 Delta Dagger|F-102 fighter]], that was part of a ten plane F-102 flyover for the opening ceremonies of the fair, suffered a flameout at 1,500 feet. The pilot safely ejected but the plane overshot Lake Washington, where the pilot intended to ditch the plane, and crashed in a residential neighborhood.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Burke|first1=Katie|title=50 years later, family still looking for closure following Seattle World’s Fair tragedy|url=http://mltnews.com/50-years-later-family-still-looking-for-closure-following-seattle-worlds-fair-tragedy/|accessdate=30 May 2017|publisher=MLT News|date=19 April 2012}}</ref>
==1961== *September 24 – ([[Wilmington, North Carolina]]) – Three servicemen were killed and twelve survived when an Air Force [[C-123 Provider]] carrying members of the [[United States Army Parachute Team|Army Golden Knights]] crashed and burned on take-off at an airshow.<ref>{{cite news| last = | first =| authorlink =| title = 3 Killed as Plane Crashes in Air Show| work =| publisher = The New York Times| date = September 25, 1961| url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0D15FD3F5B147A93C7AB1782D85F458685F9 | format =| doi =| accessdate = September 17, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last = | first =| authorlink =| title = 100,000 See 3 Die in Crash at Air Show |publisher = The Los Angeles Times| date = September 25, 1961| url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/448025052.html?dids=448025052:448025052&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Sep+25%2C+1961&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=100%2C000+See+3+Die+in+Crash+at+Air+Show&pqatl=google |accessdate=September 17, 2009}}</ref> *June 3 - A [[United States Air Force]] [[Convair B-58 Hustler]] ''58-2451'', named ''The Firefly'', crashed a few miles north of Paris during the 1961 Paris Air Show, all three onboard were killed.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename= U.S. Supersonic Aircraft crashes - Hustler's Crew of Three Killed|day_of_week=Monday |date=5 June 1961 |page_number=11 |issue=55099 |column= }}</ref>
==1959== *December 5 - [[Palm Desert, California]] - All four occupants of a twin engine Beechcraft Bonanza were kill after the tail section of their aircraft was sheared off in a mid-air collision with a single engine Beechcraft during an air show. The single engine Beechcraft crash landed killing one occupant, severely injuring another and left a third occupant unharmed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Air Show Crash Kills 5 Persons On West Coast|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252023%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%25201959%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%25201959%2520c%2520-%25204246.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D57c921c0%26DocId%3D1917912%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cDISK%2520S%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D1c%2B1d%2B1e%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252023%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%25201959%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%25201959%2520c%2520-%25204246.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D57c921c0%26DocId%3D1917912%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cDISK%2520S%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D1c%2B1d%2B1e%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=31 May 2017|publisher=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=6 December 1959}}</ref> *April - A pilot was killed during an aerobatic display at Deniliquin air pageant in Australia.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Telegrams in Brief - Sydney |day_of_week=Monday |date=6 April 1959 |page_number=9 |issue=54427 |column= }}</ref>
==1958== * August 2 – ([[Buffalo Niagara International Airport]]), [[Buffalo, NY]], [[Blue Angels|Blue Angel]] number 6 made an emergency landing at the airport before sliding into traffic outside the airport after experiencing afterburner trouble while participating in the [[Clarence, NY]] Sesquicentennial celebration. Lt. John R. Dewenter was credited with saving many lives by landing at the [[Buffalo Niagara International Airport]] despite the runway deemed too short to stop. Flying a [[Grumman F-11 Tiger]] he was able to bring the plane down and stop without injury to others.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} * September 20 – Prototype [[Avro Vulcan]] ''VX770'' in an airshow at [[RAF Syerston]] suffers total collapse of the plane's right wing. The craft spirals out of control and crashes, killing the entire aircrew and 3 people on the ground.<ref>TNA file BT 233/403.</ref> ''VX770'' was known to have had a weaker wing structure than production aircraft. The aircraft had been testing the [[Rolls-Royce Conway]] installation and was returning from a test flight via Syerston. See [[1958 Syerston Avro Vulcan crash|here]] for more details.
==1957== *September 5: [[Canadian International Air Show]] (Toronto, Ontario, Canada) – Royal Canadian Air Force Avro Canada CF-100 Mk.4B 18455 pulled up, flamed out, went into inverted spin and crashed. F/O's H.R. Norris and R.C. Dougall were killed.<ref>[http://airforce.ca/awards.php?search=1&keyword=&page=560&mem=&type=rcaf Air Force Association of Canada (Search "Norris")] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331030631/http://airforce.ca/awards.php?search=1&keyword=&page=560&mem=&type=rcaf |date=March 31, 2012 }}</ref> *July 20 - A pilot was killed when his [[Miles Magister]] crashed during at display at Burnaston Airport, near Derby, England.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Pilot Killed During Aerobatic Display |day_of_week=Monday |date=22 July 1957 |page_number=8 |issue=53899 |column= }}</ref> *June 8 – [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] [[Avro Canada CF-100]] Mk.5 of [[433 Tactical Fighter Squadron|No. 433 Squadron]], [[CFB North Bay|North Bay]], crashed at a London, Ontario air show after both wings separated from the aircraft. F/O's C.A. Sheffield and Les Sparrow died. Post crash film analysis suggested that the aircraft pulled more g's than it was designed for.<ref>[http://www.ody.ca/~bwalker/RCAF_18551_18600_detailed.html Canadian Military Aircraft Serial Numbers RCAF 18551 to 18600 Detailed List] search serial no. 18562</ref> *June 7 – ([[NAS Dallas|Hensley Field]], [[Dallas, Texas]], United States) – [[Vought|Chance Vought Aircraft]] pilot James P. Buckner is killed while performing a high-speed flight demonstration in a [[Vought F8U-1 Crusader]] for a graduating class from the [[Naval Postgraduate School]]. Executing a zoom climb after his low-altitude pass, he apparently overstresses the fighter and it disintegrates before he can eject.<ref>Pace, Steve, "''Crusader With A Cause''", Wings, Granada Hills, California, August 1987, Volume 17, Number 4, page 34.</ref> The aircraft's wreckage violently explodes at low altitude over Main Street in adjacent [[Grand Prairie, Texas|Grand Prairie]], Texas, inflicting minor injuries to several bystanders, and pieces of the fighter are scattered throughout the floodplain of the nearby [[Trinity River (Texas)|Trinity River]]; Buckner's body is recovered a few hours after the crash.<ref name="dmn_06-08-57">{{cite news |author=Scott, John|title=Test Pilot Killed in Explosion|work=[[The Dallas Morning News]] |date=June 8, 1957}}</ref>
==1956== *June 9 – [[Royal Air Forces Association|RAFA]] Air Display at [[Short Brothers|Shorts]], [[George Best Belfast City Airport|Sydenham Airport]], ([[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]]) – Shorts Senior Test Pilot [[Squadron Leader|Sqn Ldr]] [[Walter J. "Wally" Runciman]], flying the fourth [[Short Seamew]] prototype,<ref>Editors, "Short Seamew: A Camel Amongst Race Horses?", ''Jets'', January / February 2014, Kelsey Publishing, Cordham, Kent, UK, page 22.</ref> was killed when the aircraft "appeared to start a slow roll", the nose falling and there being "insufficient height for recovery". The aircraft avoided crashing into the crowd, hitting the runway "practically nose first".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukserials.com/losses-1956.htm|title=UK Military Aircraft Losses|publisher=}}</ref><ref>1956 Belfast Airshow crash [http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1956/1956%20-%200762.html Flight International archive: Report of the accident]</ref><ref>1956 Belfast Airshow crash [http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1956/1956%20-%200851.html Flight International archive: An Appreciation]</ref><ref>1956 Belfast Airshow crash [http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1956/1956%20-%200796.html Flight International archive: Report on inquest]</ref> *May 22 - Whitsun Air Display (Liverpool, England) - Parachutist and "Birdman" Leo Valentin fell to his death after his wooden wings were damaged after colliding with his jump plane and both of his parachutes failed to deploy.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19560522&id=o_sSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tQAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7184,291654&hl=en|title = 'Birdman' Drops 9,000 Feet To Death |date = May 22, 1956 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = Toledo Blade|page = 10}}</ref> *May 19 – A Royal Canadian Air Force CF-100 Mk. 5 of [[No. 428 Squadron RCAF|428 Squadron]] crashed after the starboard wing separated during a high-speed low-level pass during an air show at [[Kinross AFB]], Michigan. One RCAF and one USAF fatality.<ref>[http://www.ody.ca/~bwalker/RCAF_18551_18600_detailed.html Canadian Military Aircraft Serial Numbers RCAF 18551 to 18600 Detailed List] search serial no. 18575</ref>
==1955== *July 7 - [[Farnborough, Hampshire|Farnborough, England]] - The pilot of a [[Hawker Hunter]] was killed during an 18 plane flyby review witnessed by [[Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon|Princess Margaret]] and an estimated 4,000 spectators.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2194&dat=19550707&id=4t0wAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Td0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=4904,947924&hl=en|title = Princess Watches Jet's Death Dive |date = July 7, 1955 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = Reuters|newspaper = Ottawa Citizen|month = |page = 1}}</ref> *May 30 - [[Akron–Canton Airport]] ([[Green, Ohio]]) - Pilot Paul Anderson was killed when his plane crashed while performing low altitude loops during an air show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stunt Flier Is Killed In Crash|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%25208%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201955%2520Grayscale%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201955%2520Grayscale%2520-%25203929.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D26bdfa71%26DocId%3D2946300%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D15%26hits%3D2eb%2B313%2B31a%2B345%2B382%2B3c2%2B3e1%2B883%2B8a7%2Bb22%2Bb27%2Bb97%2Bb9d%2Bdd5%2Bdff%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%25208%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201955%2520Grayscale%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201955%2520Grayscale%2520-%25203929.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D26bdfa71%26DocId%3D2946300%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D15%26hits%3D2eb%2B313%2B31a%2B345%2B382%2B3c2%2B3e1%2B883%2B8a7%2Bb22%2Bb27%2Bb97%2Bb9d%2Bdd5%2Bdff%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=3 June 2017|work=Schenectady Gazette|publisher=United Press|date=31 May 1955}}</ref> *May 15 – Air Display at [[Griffith, New South Wales|Griffith]], New South Wales, Australia. Two [[Hawker Sea Fury|Hawker Sea Furies]] of the Royal Australian Navy were written off in a collision on the runway. Neither pilot was hurt in the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adf-serials.com.au/seafury.htm|title=Hawker Sea Fury|publisher=}}</ref>
==1954== *September 5 – National Aircraft Show ([[Dayton, Ohio]]) – Major John L. Armstrong was killed when he crashed his [[F-86H Sabre]] while trying to match or break the speed record he had set two days earlier.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jet Pilot Killed In Crash After Setting Speed Mark |agency=Associated Press |date=September 6, 1954| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BPkNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jHoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4435,2377751&dq=air+show+accident |accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref>
==1953== *October 15 - [[Christchurch International Airport|Harewood Airport]] ([[Harewood, New Zealand]]) - Seven members of the [[Royal New Zealand Air Force]] were killed when two of their planes crashed following a mid-air collision during a ceremonial flyover.<ref>{{cite news|title=7 Killed in Air Show Crash|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252024%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Evening%2520News%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Evening%2520News%25201953%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Evening%2520News%25201953%2520a%2520-%25203079.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D1467c59d%26DocId%3D4531275%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cDISK%2520X%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D61b%2B61c%2B61d%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252024%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Evening%2520News%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Evening%2520News%25201953%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Evening%2520News%25201953%2520a%2520-%25203079.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D1467c59d%26DocId%3D4531275%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cDISK%2520X%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D61b%2B61c%2B61d%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=31 May 2017|work=Buffalo Evening News|publisher=Reuters|date=15 October 1953}}</ref> *September 19 – [[Canadian International Air Show]] Royal Canadian Air Force Canadair Sabre 4, piloted by S/L W.R. Greene crashed into Lake Ontario. Greene, who had replaced the originally slated pilot Gordon Bennett, was killed. A T-33 formation team also performing in the show truncated their performance due to low cloud and rain and had entered clouds during looping maneuvers. One aircraft attempted loop recovery without sufficient altitude and hit Lake Ontario.<ref>Dempsey, Daniel V. ''A Tradition of Excellence: Canada's Airshow Team Heritage''. Victoria, BC: High Flight Enterprises, 2002. p. 86. {{ISBN|0-9687817-0-5}}.</ref> *September 19 - Battle of Britain Air Display [[RAF Wyton]] - ''WA927'' a Royal Air Force Gloster Meteor F.8 of [[No. 56 Squadron RAF|56 Squadron]] broke-up during a low-level run over the airfield, pilot killed.<ref name="times52732">{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Two Pilots killed in Air Displays - Accidents to Meteors |day_of_week=Monday |date=September 21, 1953 |page_number=3 |issue=52732}}</ref><ref name="Halley150">Halley 1999, p. 150</ref> *September 19 - Battle of Britain Air Display [[RAF Coningsby]] - ''WA836'' a Royal Air Force Gloster Meteor F.8 of [[No. 74 Squadron RAF|74 Squadron]] broke-up during a high-speed run over the airfield, pilot killed and two women in the crowd injured by debris.<ref name="times52732" /><ref name="Halley150" /> *September 6 – National Aircraft Show (Dayton, Ohio, United States) – Marine pilot Major William T. Tebow was injured when the Sikorsky helicopter he was flying "brushed rotor blades" with another helicopter and crash-landed. Tebow was flying in formation when the accident occurred.<ref>{{cite web |title=Copter Crash, Jet Race Mark Dayton Show |publisher=The Toledo Blade |date=September 7, 1953 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=toYTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dAAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5677,2536573&dq=air+show+crash |accessdate=July 15, 2009}}</ref> *May 3 - [[Venice|Venice, Italy]] - Parachutist Salvatore Cannarozzo was killed when his parachute failed to open after he jumped from a height of 9,000 feet at an air show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Daredevil Dies|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=MT19530504.2.94&srpos=1&e=-------en--20--1--txt-txIN-air+show+death-------1|accessdate=11 June 2017|work=Madera Tribune|publisher=United Press|date=4 May 1953}}</ref>
==1952==
*October 19 - [[Westfield-Barnes Regional Airport|Barnes Municipal Airport]] ([[Westfield, Massachusetts]]) - United States Air Force Pilots Lt. Robert H. Danell and Capt. Fred H. Stevens were killed when their [[North American F-86 Sabre|F-86E Saberjets]] were involved in a mid-air collision while performing during an air show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Memorial dedicated to Air Force pilots killed in 1952 air show at Barnes Regional Airport in Westfield|url=http://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2012/10/memorial_dedicated_to_air_forc.html|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=Masslive.com|date=20 October 2012}}</ref> * August 30 – International Aviation Exposition ([[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]) – One of a pair of [[Northrop F-89 Scorpion]]s disintegrated in flight during a display, killing the Scorpions pilot and radar operator.<ref>''Aeroplane Monthly magazine'' – May 1975 "Fighters of the Fifties – Northrop Scorpion"</ref> *September 6 – [[1952 Farnborough Airshow DH.110 crash|Farnborough Airshow DH.110 crash]] ([[Farnborough, Hampshire|Farnborough]], UK) – Pilot [[John Derry]] and flight test observer Anthony Richards flying a [[de Havilland Sea Vixen|DH.110]] were killed when the outer starboard wing, immediately followed by the outer port wing, broke off when the aircraft was pulled into a climb. Wreckage crashed into the spectators, killing 29 and injuring 60. The incident was captured on film.<ref>[http://www.britishpathe.com/record.php?id=30303 "The Farnborough Tragedy"] from [[British Pathe]] – newsreel footage of the 1952 Farnborough disaster</ref> *September 20 – [[Canadian International Air Show]] Royal Canadian Air Force [[Avro Canada CF-100 Canuck]] Mk.3T piloted by S/L R.D. Schultz made a 500-knot high-speed pass with vertical pull up. This maneuver overstressed the aircraft but the aircraft recovered to [[CFB North Bay]] successfully.<ref>Dempsey, Daniel V. ''A Tradition of Excellence: Canada's Airshow Team Heritage''. Victoria, BC: High Flight Enterprises, 2002. p. 89. {{ISBN|0-9687817-0-5}}.</ref>
==1951== *September 15 - Three separate accident in the United Kingdom during Royal Air Force displays to celebrate the Battle of Britain:<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Three Killed at Air Displays|day_of_week=Monday |date=15 September 1051 |page_number=4 |issue=52108 |column= }}</ref> **Two of four [[Gloster Meteor]]s of [[No. 63 Squadron RAF|63 Squadron]] collided during a formation aerobatic display at [[RAF Waterbeach]], Cambridgeshire, one pilot of ''WE869'' was killed. **A pilot was killed at [[RAF Thornaby]] in North Yorkshire when his [[North American Harvard]] ''FX428'' crashed after the wing hit the ground while rolling the aircraft back from an inverted flypast. **A pilot was killed at [[RAF St Athan]], Wales when his North American Harvard ''KF937'' crashed while landing after his display. *September 15 – Fall Festival Day ([[Flagler, Colorado]], United States) – Twenty people, including the pilot and 13 children, were killed when a [[Timm N2T Tutor]] training plane piloted by Air Force 1st Lt. Norman Jones of Denver flew in low over the crowd and attempted a loop. The pilot had reportedly arrived late and missed the safety briefing which prohibited flying at less than 500 feet above the ground and banned any stunts near the crowd. Lt. Jones was at an approximate altitude of 200 feet when he began his maneuver. Depending on the account, the maneuver was either a loop<ref>{{cite web| last = Miniclier| first =Kit | authorlink = | title = Air-show crash a vivid memory 50 years later| work =Denver Post.com| publisher = The Denver Post| date =September 9, 2001| url =http://proairshow.com/Flagler%20Lions%20Club%20Airshow.htm |accessdate=February 7, 2009}}</ref> or a slow roll.<ref>{{cite web| last = Beitler| first =Stu | authorlink = | title = Flagler, CO Disaster At Air Show, Sep 1951| work =GenDisasters.com| publisher = GenDisasters| date = March 10, 2009 | url =http://www3.gendisasters.com/colorado/11797/flagler-co-disaster-air-show-sep-1951 |accessdate=January 11, 2012}}</ref> *September 3 - Minnesota State Fair ([[Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul, Minnesota]], United States) - Biplane pilot Carl Ferriss and his assistant Kitty Middleton, who was strapped to the upper wing, were killed when their plane failed to pull out of a power off dive.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1873&dat=19510905&id=spcpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VMgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4807,467901&hl=en|title = Stunt Plane Crash Kills Fliers |date = September 5, 1951 |accessdate = August 24, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|page = 2|newspaper = Daytona Beach Morning Journal}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.parkbugle.org/1951-tragedy-ended-stunt-flying-at-minnesota-state-fair/|title = 1951 tragedy ended stunt flying at Minnesota State Fair|date = August 25, 2014|accessdate=August 24, 2015 |last = Bergerson|first = Roger}}</ref> *May 7 - Lexington Airport (Lexington, Oregon) - Pilot Elmar Payne was killed when his [[Stearman Aircraft|Boeing-Stearman]] crashed while attempting a slow roll.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1243&dat=19510507&id=k1JYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hvcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1550,149970&hl=en |title=Airplane Stunt Man Dies In Crash |date=May 7, 1951 |accessdate=August 26, 2015 |publisher=UPI |newspaper=The Bulletin|page = 3}}</ref>
==1950== *October 29 - Norfolk Lions Club Airshow (Norfolk, Virginia) - Pilot Charles Edward Bailey was killed when the wing of his specially built eleven and a half foot long stunt plane struck the ground while attempting a low altitude roll.<ref>{{cite news|title=Flyer Killed Doing Stunt in 11 1/2 Ft. Plane|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1950/10/30/page/1/article/flyer-killed-doing-stunt-in-11-1-2-ft-plane|accessdate=30 May 2017|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=30 October 1950}}</ref> * July 7 – ([[Naval Air Station Patuxent River]], Maryland) – The third prototype of three [[Vought]] [[F7U Cutlass|XF7U-1 Cutlass]] twin-tailed fighters, BuNo ''122474'', suffered an engine explosion during a flight exhibition. Vought test pilot Paul Thayer ejected and parachuted into two feet of water; the airframe impacted on a [[Patuxent River]] island. Thayer was returned safely to the admiral's reviewing stand, where the show announcer asked "What will you do for an encore Mr. Thayer?" The pilot had fractured a small bone at the base of his spine – he later told Vought management that he was the only manager who actually "broke his ass for the Company."<ref>Moran, Gerard P., "The Corsair, and other – Aeroplanes Vought", Aviation Heritage Books, Sunshine House, Inc., Terre Haute, Indiana, 1978, Library of Congress card number 77-91434, {{ISBN|0-911852-83-2}}, page 106.</ref>
==1949== * September 11 - Catskill Airport (New York) - Pilot Earl Newton Jr. was killed when his aircraft stalled and nosedived while performing during an air show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Air Show Crash Fatal to Flier|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%25204%2FAmsterdam%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Democrat%2520and%2520Recorder%2FAmsterdam%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Democrat%2520and%2520Recorder%25201949%2520Sep-Oct%2520Grayscale%2FAmsterdam%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Democrat%2520and%2520Recorder%25201949%2520Sep-Oct%2520Grayscale%2520-%25200149.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffdff09060%26DocId%3D179505%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D3b3%2B3b4%2B3b5%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%25204%2FAmsterdam%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Democrat%2520and%2520Recorder%2FAmsterdam%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Democrat%2520and%2520Recorder%25201949%2520Sep-Oct%2520Grayscale%2FAmsterdam%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Democrat%2520and%2520Recorder%25201949%2520Sep-Oct%2520Grayscale%2520-%25200149.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffdff09060%26DocId%3D179505%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D3b3%2B3b4%2B3b5%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=31 May 2017|work=Evening Recorder|publisher=UPI|date=12 September 1949}}</ref> *August 14 - [[Lodgepole, Nebraska]] - Parachutist Jimmy F. Taylor was killed when his parachute failed to open when he jumped from a height of 600 feet during an airshow.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chute Doesn't Open|url=https://texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth283745/m1/6/zoom/?q=airshow%20crash&resolution=4&lat=6179.509579534342&lon=2899.826676381112|accessdate=18 June 2017|work=The Sweetwater Reporter|publisher=United Press|date=15 August 1949}}</ref> * July 24 – Junior Chamber of Commerce air show ([[Sandusky, Ohio]]) – Lt. Richard H. Glenn received minor injuries when his [[F-80 Shooting Star]] crash-landed. The F-80's auxiliary wingtip fuel tanks collapsed when Lt. Glenn pulled out of a dive and he belly-landed the plane in a field.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title = 8,000 Watch Jet Crash at Sandusky Air Show| work =| publisher =The Toledo Blade| date = July 25, 1949| url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UnoTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FQAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1504,5733556&dq=air+show+accident |accessdate =July 12, 2009}}</ref> * July 4 – Otesgo Airfield ([[Otsego, Michigan]]) – Former Navy flight instructor, John Jakus, was killed after his [[BT-13 Valiant]] crashed while performing a low altitude roll during an air show performance.<ref>{{cite news | last =| first =| authorlink =| title = Former Navy Pilot Killed| work =| publisher = Ludington Daily News| date = July 5, 1949| doi =<!--| accessdate =July 12, 2009-->}}</ref> * April 25 - Jackson, Mississippi - Pilot Billy Fischer was killed when his stunt plane lost a wing while performing during an air show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Flier Dies In Air Show Crash|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252010%2FKingston%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Freeman%2FKingston%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Freeman%25201949%2520Grayscale%2FKingston%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Freeman%25201949%2520Grayscale%2520-%25201727.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D51840cd4%26DocId%3D656947%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D11%2B12%2B13%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252010%2FKingston%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Freeman%2FKingston%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Freeman%25201949%2520Grayscale%2FKingston%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Freeman%25201949%2520Grayscale%2520-%25201727.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D51840cd4%26DocId%3D656947%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D11%2B12%2B13%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=31 May 2017|work=The Kingston Daily Freeman|publisher=Associated Press|date=26 April 1949}}</ref> * January 7 – All-American Air Show ([[Miami, Florida]]) – Air Force First Lt. James M. Hall was killed when his [[P-80 Shooting Star]] failed to pull up during a low altitude dive.<ref>{{cite news|title = All-American Air Show Marred by Crash of Jet| work = The Deseret News| agency = Associated Press| date = January 8, 1949| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8F8OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ln8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5192,1520104&dq=air+show+accident| format =|accessdate =July 12, 2009}}</ref>
==1948== *September 27 - Hales Corners, Wisconsin - Aerial stuntman Dick Powell was killed after falling from an airplane while dangling from his knees over the leading edge of the wing. He was unable to pull himself back up onto the wing and the pilot was unable fly to a nearby lake before he fell.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19480927&id=69IbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MVEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2627,4554699&hl=en|title = Old-Time Wing-Walker Dies As Grip Fails In New Stunt |date = September 27, 1948 |accessdate = August 29, 2015 |publisher=UPI |newspaper = The Pittsburgh Press|page = 9}}</ref> *September 22 - Spalding County Fair ([[Griffin, Georgia]]) - Pilot Charlie Rife was killed when his aircraft crashed while doing low altitude stunts. He was a member of an air circus that was part of the fair.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19480923&id=13ssAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KcsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7212,2281720&hl=en|title = Stunting Pilot Plunges To Death |date = September 23, 1948 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = Spartanburg Herald Journal|page = 10}}</ref> *September 19 - Randolph Air Force Base ([[Universal City, Texas]]) - The pilot and co-pilot of a [[North American F-82 Twin Mustang|F-82 Twin Mustang]] were killed in a crash following a flyover of the airfield during an airshow.<ref>{{cite news|title=2 Fliers Killed In Air Show Crash|accessdate=31 May 2017|publisher=The Philadelphia Inquirer|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252023%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%25201948%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%25201948%2520b%2520-%25200203.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D1d75c336%26DocId%3D1438926%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cDISK%2520S%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D522%2B523%2B524%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252023%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%25201948%2FPhiladelphia%2520PA%2520Inquirer%25201948%2520b%2520-%25200203.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D1d75c336%26DocId%3D1438926%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cDISK%2520S%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D522%2B523%2B524%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|date=20 September 1948}}</ref> *September 18 – a RAF [[de Havilland Mosquito]] crashed during an air show being held at [[RAF Manston]], killing both crew and ten members of the public.<ref name="Times200948">{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=12 Killed at Air Display |day_of_week=Monday |date=September 20, 1948 |page_number=4 |issue=51181 |column=F}}</ref><ref name="Ingleton">{{cite book|first=Roy |last=Ingleton |title=Kent Disasters |year=2010 |publisher=Pen & Sword |location= Barnsley |pages=117–19}}</ref>
==1947== *August 10 - Penn Yan Air Show ([[Penn Yan, New York]]) - Pilot Chester Rodney Angell was killed when his plane crashed shortly after takeoff to participate in a balloon bursting contest during the air show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Penn Yan Air Show Crash Victim Dies|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252011%2FCorning%2520NY%2520Evening%2520%2520Leader%2FCorning%2520NY%2520Evening%2520%2520Leader%25201947%2520%2520%2520Grayscale%2FCorning%2520NY%2520Evening%2520%2520Leader%25201947%2520%2520%2520Grayscale%2520-%25201449.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D334f82ac%26DocId%3D6714231%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520U%252dF%252dP%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D7bb%2B7bc%2B7bd%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252011%2FCorning%2520NY%2520Evening%2520%2520Leader%2FCorning%2520NY%2520Evening%2520%2520Leader%25201947%2520%2520%2520Grayscale%2FCorning%2520NY%2520Evening%2520%2520Leader%25201947%2520%2520%2520Grayscale%2520-%25201449.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D334f82ac%26DocId%3D6714231%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520U%252dF%252dP%26HitCount%3D3%26hits%3D7bb%2B7bc%2B7bd%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=31 May 2017|publisher=The Evening Leader|date=12 August 1947}}</ref> *July 20 - Wilson-King Air Show ([[Twin Falls, Idaho]]) - Pilot Billy Lear Jr. escaped injury when he crash landed his P-38 after experiencing engine problems following a slow roll maneuver.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stunt Pilot, 18, Escapes Injury in Crash-Landing|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FTwin%2520Falls%2520ID%2520Times%2520News%2FTwin%2520Falls%2520ID%2520Times%2520News%25201947%2FTwin%2520Falls%2520ID%2520Times%2520News%25201947%2520-%25201899.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffcff03ec6%26DocId%3D5367001%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D18%26hits%3D68a%2B69b%2B6b5%2B6d9%2B6df%2B6e7%2B6f0%2B705%2B72a%2B918%2B92d%2B967%2B97e%2Bab7%2Bc1d%2Bc64%2B123a%2B1253%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FTwin%2520Falls%2520ID%2520Times%2520News%2FTwin%2520Falls%2520ID%2520Times%2520News%25201947%2FTwin%2520Falls%2520ID%2520Times%2520News%25201947%2520-%25201899.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffcff03ec6%26DocId%3D5367001%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D18%26hits%3D68a%2B69b%2B6b5%2B6d9%2B6df%2B6e7%2B6f0%2B705%2B72a%2B918%2B92d%2B967%2B97e%2Bab7%2Bc1d%2Bc64%2B123a%2B1253%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=2 June 2017|publisher=Times News|date=21 July 1947}}</ref> *July 13 - Sportmen's Pilot Air Show ([[Seaside, Oregon]]) - A stunt parachutist had to be rescued after being blown off course into the ocean.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stunt Parachute Jumper Saved At Sea|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FProcess%2520Small%2FNewspapers%2FUtica%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Press%2FUtica%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Press%25201947.pdf%2FUtica%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Press%25201947%2520-%25202902.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D4c7142c0%26DocId%3D5777586%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D9%26hits%3D17%2B83%2B90%2Be6%2B1dc%2B1fc%2B284%2B2f4%2Bae4%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FProcess%2520Small%2FNewspapers%2FUtica%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Press%2FUtica%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Press%25201947.pdf%2FUtica%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Press%25201947%2520-%25202902.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D4c7142c0%26DocId%3D5777586%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D9%26hits%3D17%2B83%2B90%2Be6%2B1dc%2B1fc%2B284%2B2f4%2Bae4%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=3 June 2017|work=Utica Daily Press|publisher=Associated Press|date=14 July 1947}}</ref> * July 4 – Decorah air show ([[Decorah, Iowa]])- Pilot and former [[Women Airforce Service Pilots|WASP]] [[Marge Hurlburt]] was killed when her [[T-6 Texan]] crashed while performing a slow roll. At the time she was performing with the "Flying Tigers" aerial circus troupe.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title = Marge Hurlburt Is Killed While Stunting In Air Show| work =| publisher = St. Petersburg Times| date = July 5, 1947| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ib0KAAAAIBAJ&sjid=304DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6109,1451195&dq=airshow+crash |accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref> * June 22 – Wilson-King Sky Show ([[St. George, Utah]]) – A teenage spectator was killed, her mother and infant sister were injured, when a light plane involved with the airshow experienced brake failure on landing and crashed into cars parked at the edge of the airfield. The pilot, Bernadine Lewis King, was also injured.<ref>{{cite web |title = Plane Hits Cars, Kills Girl |publisher=The Deseret News| date = June 23, 1947| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=o9MNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kXcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6775,6657198&dq=airshow+crash |accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref> * June 4 – [[Veterans of Foreign Wars]] Airshow ([[Atlantic Beach, North Carolina]]) – A [[U.S. Marine Corps]] [[Vought F4U-4 Corsair]] crashed in the surf at [[Atlantic Beach, North Carolina]] during a [[VFW]] airshow, and pilot Lt. Gene Dial, of [[MCAS Cherry Point]], North Carolina, walked some 15 feet to shore unhurt. The pilot, with four and a half years of service, said that he crashed once before during a carrier take-off.<ref>Associated Press, "Airplane Hits Surf In Beach Air Show", ''The State'', Columbia, South Carolina, Thursday June 5, 1947, No. 20,435, p. 6-B.</ref> * May 18 – Municipal airport air show ([[Burlington, Iowa]]) – Lt. John Peeler was killed when his Navy [[F4U Corsair]] crashed into a sandlot baseball game and caught fire a few blocks from the airport. Two teenagers on the ground were killed and seven others injured.<ref>{{cite web| title = Three Killed in Plane Crash| work = The Eugene Register-Guard| publisher =United Press| date = May 19, 1947| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zUQVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EwgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6948,3239729&dq=airshow+crash| format =|accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref>
==1946== * November 10 – Tulsa police air patrol show ([[Tulsa, Oklahoma]]) – Former Army Air Force instructor Wesley W. Cunningham was killed when his aircraft failed to pull out of a low altitude spin. At the time Cunningham was involved in a skit playing the part of a woman spectator who is chosen from the crowd to fly the airplane.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title = Pretender Pilot Killed in Crash| work =| publisher = Spokane Daily Chronicle| date = November 11, 1946| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=A4gSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=l_UDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5402,2478940&dq=airshow+crash |accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref> * September 16 – Twin Falls Air Show ([[Twin Falls, Idaho]]) – Four crew members were killed when their A-26 Invader crashed while performing a loop during a local airshow.<ref>{{cite news |title=Four Are Killed In Plane Crash |work=Spokane Daily Chronicle |agency = Associated Press| date = September 17, 1946| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5BgVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=g_UDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6573,3589197&dq=airshow+crash |accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref> * September 15 - Flying Tiger Air Circus ([[Bowling Green, Ohio]]) - Army veteran Gordon Lahman was killed when his parachute failed to open during a 1,500 foot delayed jump at the start of the circus.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2206&dat=19460916&id=LQotAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OdYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5124,264680&hl=en|title = Vet Paratrooper Dies As 'Chute Fails |date = September 16, 1946 |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|page = 30|newspaper = The Miami News}}</ref> * August 9 – North Montana State Fair ([[Great Falls, Montana]]) – Seven were killed when two [[A-26 Invader]] attack bombers, part of a low-flying three-plane formation, collided in mid-air 750 feet in front of a grandstand filled with 20,000 spectators. The wing from one bomber sheared off the tail section of another. The tail-less plane crashed into a horse barn, killing three crew members, three people on the ground and twenty thoroughbred horses; the other bomber managed to continue flying for one or five miles (sources differ) before crashing in a field, killing one of the crew. The third bomber in the formation landed safely.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title = Crowds See Fatal Crash / Seven Bodies Found After Plane Collision| work = The Spokane Daily Chronicle| publisher = United Press | date = August 10, 1946| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IDUVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hfUDAAAAIBAJ&dq=montana%20fair&pg=4362%2C2194974 | format =| doi =| accessdate =September 21, 2009}}</ref> *August 5 - Pittsburgh Airport (Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania) - [[United States Army Air Forces]] pilot Major Leonard Weihardt suffered minor injuries when his jet fighter crashed during an air show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pilot's Escape In Plane Crash|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/48475913?searchTerm=air+show+crash|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=The Barrier Miner|date=6 August 1946}}</ref>
==1945== * May 27 – Army Air Forces Fair ([[Wright Field]], [[Dayton, Ohio]]) – The third prototype Curtiss [[XP-55 Ascender]], ''42-78847'', crashed during an exhibition, killing the pilot William C. Glasgow and two to four civilians (sources differ) on the ground. The pilot attempted a slow roll after a low pass in formation with a [[P-38]] and a [[P-51]] on each wing, but lost altitude and crashed, sending flaming debris into occupied civilian vehicles on a highway near the airfield.<ref>Scott, Roland B., "''Air Mail''", Wings, Granada Hills, California, October 1978, Volume 8, Number 5, page 10.</ref> <!-- Editors: For more about this incident, see: http://www.daytonairshowbook.com/blog/files/tag-curtiss-xp-55.php -->
==1944== *July 23 - Spokane Air Show (Spokane, Washington) - Four United States Army Air Forces aviators, pilots Second Lt.'s William R. Scott and George Chrep along with Capt. Ford K. Sayre and an unidentified sergeant, were killed when their two [[Curtiss SB2C Helldiver|A-25 Shrike]] bombers were involved in a mid-air collision while ascending from a dive.<ref>{{cite news|title=100,000 at Spokane Air Show See 4 Die as Bombers Crash|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252015%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%25201944%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%25201944%2520a%2520-%25204009.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffff881c6815%26DocId%3D12529488%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D13%26hits%3D31%2B32%2B39%2B97%2Bdc%2B101%2B187%2B3a4%2B49d%2B4ad%2B4cc%2B4de%2B521%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252015%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%25201944%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%25201944%2520a%2520-%25204009.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffff881c6815%26DocId%3D12529488%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D13%26hits%3D31%2B32%2B39%2B97%2Bdc%2B101%2B187%2B3a4%2B49d%2B4ad%2B4cc%2B4de%2B521%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=1 June 2017|work=Syracuse Herald-Journal|publisher=Associated Press|date=24 July 1944}}</ref>
==1943== *September 4 – Defense forces public air display, [[Flemington Racecourse]], [[Melbourne, Australia.|Melbourne]], Australia. A Royal Australian Air Force [[Vultee Vengeance]] became inverted at low level after pulling up from a mock bomb dive and went out of control. The aircraft crashed in a nearby industrial suburb, setting fire to a grain mill and narrowly missing a nearby crowded railway station. The plane's occupants, Flight-Lieutenant Richard Roe and his wireless air-gunner James Harris, were both killed. There were no casualties on the ground.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article46768414|title=BOMBER CRASHES. - Two R.A.A.F. Officers Killed. - The West Australian (Perth, WA : 1879 - 1954) - September 7, 1943|publisher=}}</ref> *August 1 – [[Lambert–St. Louis International Airport|Lambert Field]], [[St. Louis|St. Louis, Missouri]], USA – [[Waco CG-4|Waco CG-4A-RO]] ''42-78839'', built by St. Louis contractor [[Robertson Aircraft Corporation]], loses its right-hand wing immediately after being released over the airfield by the tow airplane. Several thousand people had gathered to watch the first public demonstration of the St. Louis-built [[military glider|troop-carrying glider]], which was carrying 2 [[United States Army Air Forces|USAAF]] crewmen, St. Louis mayor [[William D. Becker]], Robertson Aircraft and Lambert Field co-founder Maj. [[William B. Robertson]], and 6 other VIP passengers; all 10 perish in the ensuing crash.<ref>Associated Press, "Mayor and 9 Die in St. Louis Glider Crash", ''The Dallas Morning News'', Dallas, Texas, Monday August 2, 1943, Number 306, page 1.</ref> The accident is attributed to the failure of a defective wing strut fitting.<ref>Gero, David B. "Military Aviation Disasters: Significant Losses Since 1908". Sparkford, Yoevil, Somerset, UK: Haynes Publishing, 2010, {{ISBN|978-1-84425-645-7}}, pp. 24–25.</ref> *May 17 – [[Waxahachie, Texas]] – Flight Instructor Lieutenant William S. Farrish and Sergeant Jasper J. DeMaria, Jr. were killed when their military trainer, from the Army Flying School in Waco, Texas, went into a spin and crashed during an air show.<ref>{{cite news| last =| first = | title = Two Fliers Killed in Air Show Crash| newspaper = Reading Eagle| location = | page = 18| agency =Associated Press| date = May 17, 1943| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lZMhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MZgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5171,2195361&dq=airshow+crash&hl=en| accessdate =December 26, 2010}}</ref> *April 14 – [[Jervis Bay]], New South Wales, Australia. Two Royal Australian Air Force [[Bristol Beaufort]]s collided whilst pulling up from a dummy bomb run during an air display for war correspondents on board a nearby vessel. All eight crew on board the two aircraft were killed. A Fox Movietone News cameraman caught the incident on film.<ref>Page, Charles. ''Wings of Destiny''. Rosenberg Publishing Pty Ltd, Australia. 2008. p-294.</ref>
==1940== * October 20 – Marianna airshow ([[Marianna, Arkansas]]) – A parachutist and five people on board a sightseeing plane were killed when the plane became entangled in the parachute. The plane had been circling the parachutist during his descent prior to the accident.<ref>{{cite news |title=Starts Sift of 6 Killed in Crash| work = Kentucky New Era| agency =Associated Press |date=October 21, 1940 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iY4JAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lEADAAAAIBAJ&pg=5354,4094909&dq=airshow+crash |accessdate=July 12, 2009}}</ref>
==1939== * July 10 - Brussels, Belgium - German Air Force Captain Wille was killed in a crash during a multi-country military aircraft display.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19390710&id=C0ZAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uYgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4062,1343644&hl=en|title = Fatal Crash At Air Display |date = July 10, 1939 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Glasgow Herald|page = 12}}</ref> * January 14 – Havana airdrome ([[Havana|Havana, Cuba]]) – Captain Manuel Orta, a Cuban Army flier, was killed when his [[Curtiss P-36 Hawk|Curtis Hawk]] failed to pull up from a high speed dive and crashed on top of a parked Beechcraft airplane.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Cuban Ace Is Killed |newspaper=The News and Courier |page=1 |publisher=INS |date=January 15, 1939 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rzxJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WAkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5871,5686338&dq=air+show+accident&hl=en |accessdate=January 3, 2011}}</ref>
==1938== * July 24 – (Campo de Marte, Santa Ana, [[Usaquén]], [[Colombia]]) – A pilot performing an aerobatic display [[Santa Ana air show disaster|crashed]] a [[Curtiss F11C Goshawk|Curtiss Hawk II]] into a crowd attending a military review. Sources differ on the number killed and injured; up to 75 died and 100 or more were injured. According to ''Time'' magazine, the pilot, Flight Lt. Cesar Abadia of the [[Colombian Air Force]], disregarded standing orders not to fly below 500 feet and attempted to dive through a narrow gap between two grandstands. The pilot misjudged his approach and a wingtip hit the Diplomatic stand; the plane then smashed against the Presidential stand and exploded, raining flaming debris down on spectators located between the two grandstands.<ref>{{cite news | title = COLOMBIA: Death & Bolivar | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,771144,00.html | work = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date = August 1, 1938 | accessdate = September 20, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title = Plane Dives in Crowd| work = The Evening Independent | agency = Associated Press | date = July 25, 1938| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=j44LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wVQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4552%2C1776720| accessdate = September 20, 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://lablaa.org/blaavirtual/revistas/credencial/febrero2006/pausa.htm Biblioteca Luis Angel Arango "La gran pausa de Eduardo Santos"] {{sp icon}}</ref> * May 1 - [[Bonlee, North Carolina]] - Pilot Seldon Hunna was killed when he lost control of his plane while in a corkscrew spin and crashed into three parked cars.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19380502&id=MFkmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WE0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=771,283422&hl=en|title = Stunting Aviator Crashes To Death |date = May 2, 1938 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = St. Petersburg Times|page = 6}}</ref>
==1937== *December 4 – Miami Air Show (Miami, Florida) – Rudy Kling and Frank Haines were killed in separate crashes, within seconds of each other, during a speed race. It was speculated that "Kling lost speed in a low altitude turn and Haines was caught in Kling's [[Spiral slipstream|propeller wash]]" causing him to crash 150 yards beyond Kling's wreckage.<ref>{{Cite news| title =Two Flyers Killed In Crash At Miami Show| newspaper =Painsville Telegraph| page = 1| date = December 4, 1937| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=e3ZZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2EgNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4035,5476360&dq=air+show+accident&hl=en| accessdate =January 3, 2011}}</ref> *September 4 -
