Cleveland Airport (Cleveland, Ohio) - German Count Otto Hasenburg suffered minor injuries when the aircraft he was piloting crashed while flying inverted during an air show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ace Pleads Anew To Fly Again|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201937%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201937%2520-%25207537.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffff49170e%26DocId%3D4280231%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D16%26hits%3D24%2B372%2B468%2B59a%2B5b7%2B5bc%2B5c2%2B5e3%2B60f%2B63a%2B646%2B64f%2B664%2B7be%2B7dc%2Ba10%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201937%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201937%2520-%25207537.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffff49170e%26DocId%3D4280231%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D16%26hits%3D24%2B372%2B468%2B59a%2B5b7%2B5bc%2B5c2%2B5e3%2B60f%2B63a%2B646%2B64f%2B664%2B7be%2B7dc%2Ba10%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=2 June 2017|work=Times-Union|publisher=API|date=5 September 1937}}</ref> *June 27 - Westchester Airport ([[Armonk, New York]]) - Parachutist Waldo Fraser was killed when his parachute failed to properly deploy during a demonstration jump.<ref>{{cite news|title=3,000 Watch Stunt Death|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FMount%2520Vernon%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Argus%2FMount%2520Vernon%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Argus%25201937%2FMount%2520Vernon%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Argus%25201937%2520-%25203020.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D4c992c2b%26DocId%3D3083318%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3D18%2B41%2B146%2B1fe%2B616%2B64d%2B6e4%2B75e%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FMount%2520Vernon%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Argus%2FMount%2520Vernon%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Argus%25201937%2FMount%2520Vernon%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Argus%25201937%2520-%25203020.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D4c992c2b%26DocId%3D3083318%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3D18%2B41%2B146%2B1fe%2B616%2B64d%2B6e4%2B75e%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=2 June 2017|publisher=The Daily Argus|date=28 June 1937}}</ref> *May 29 - Isle of Man Air Race ([[Hanworth|Hanworth, England]]) - Pilot S.W. Sparkes, his passenger and the occupant of a home were killed when his [[Percival Gull]] struck a home and burst into flames.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1301&dat=19370531&id=4OVaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=D5IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5598,4806504&hl=en|title = Sick Woman In Burning House |date = 31 May 1937 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Sydney Morning Herald|page = 6}}</ref> *May 29 - A number of separate accidents in the United Kingdom during air displays to celebrate Empire Air Day:<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Empire Air Day Accidents |day_of_week=Monday |date=31 May 1937 |page_number=14 |issue=47698 |column= }}</ref> **Two pilots were killed at Farnborough, Hampshire when [[Hawker Audax]] ''K3066'' crashed **One pilot was killed at Old Sarum when [[Hawker Audax]] ''K3698'' stalled and crashed. **One pilot was killed at Tangmere, Sussex when [[Hawker Fury]] ''K2086'' spun in during the display. **One pilot was killed at Waddington, Lincolnshire when [[Hawker Fury]] ''K8228'' crashed during a slow roll. **Pilot and three passengers were killed when [[Airspeed Envoy]] ''G-ACSZ'' crashed during a pleasure flight at Doncaster.
==1936== *July 18 - Canfield Flying Circus at [[Noonan, North Dakota]] - Pilot Dorotha Canfield and passenger Albert Lee were killed when their plane nosedived and crashed following an aborted landing attempt. It was undetermined whether Canfield or Lee, a former pilot, was in control of the dual control biplane at the time of the crash.<ref>{{cite news|title=One of Famed N. D. Flying Pair Killed in Plane Crackup|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252010%2FLima%2520NY%2520Recorder%2FLima%2520NY%2520Recorder1935-1936%2520Grayscale%2FLima%2520NY%2520Recorder1935-1936%2520Grayscale%2520-%25200722.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffc07e9437%26DocId%3D809671%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3D870%2B871%2B984%2B985%2Bb82%2Bb83%2Bbe0%2Bbe1%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252010%2FLima%2520NY%2520Recorder%2FLima%2520NY%2520Recorder1935-1936%2520Grayscale%2FLima%2520NY%2520Recorder1935-1936%2520Grayscale%2520-%25200722.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffc07e9437%26DocId%3D809671%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3D870%2B871%2B984%2B985%2Bb82%2Bb83%2Bbe0%2Bbe1%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=1 June 2017|publisher=The Lima Recorder|date=18 September 1936}}</ref>
==1935== * November 22 - [[Roseboro, North Carolina]] - Parachutist Tommy Gibbons was killed when his chute opened late during a jump at an air circus.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19351123&id=3qVQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JiIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4659,2118487&hl=en|title = 'Chute Jumpers Forecast Of Own Death Fulfilled |date = November 23, 1935 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = The Milwaukee Journal|page = 2}}</ref> * September 7 - [[Blackpool|Blackpool, England]] - While demonstrating formation flying, Captain Stewart's [[Avro]] passed underneath another plane and had its tail cut off by the other plane's propeller. He and two passengers, sisters Lillian and Dorothy Barnes, were killed in the crash.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1300&dat=19350909&id=EuxjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yZUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7418,748307&hl=en|title = Air Circus Tradegy |date = September 9, 1935 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Age|others = |page = 5}}</ref> * July 30 - Sir Alan Cobham's Air Circus ([[Huntingdonshire|Huntingdonshire, England]]) - Pilot G.E. Collins was killed when his glider crashed after losing a wing during a demonstration.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19350731&id=dppAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VaUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4693,4809467&hl=en|title = Glider Pilot Killed |date = July 31, 1935 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Glasgow Herald|page = 11}}</ref> * July 21 - [[Chambersburg, Pennsylvania]] - Pilot Herbert Foreman along with passengers Glenn Calhoun and Charles Light were killed when their aircraft went into a spin during an airport dedication show. The passengers had won their places on the flight by selling tickets to the show.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19350721&id=SgoxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=teEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4354,4158739&hl=en|title = Three Die In Crash During 'Air Circus' |date = July 22, 1935 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = U.P.|newspaper = Reading Eagle|page = 21}}</ref> * May 31 - Woodford Aerodrome ([[Woodford, London|Woodford, England]]) - Parachutist Ivor Price was killed when his parachute failed to open during a two-person jump display.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1300&dat=19350601&id=TetjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QZUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1483,3183935&hl=en|title = Parachutist Killed |date = June 1, 1935 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Age|page = 8}}</ref> * May 18 – [[Moscow]], USSR – a crash of a giant propaganda plane [[Tupolev ANT-20]] ''Maxim Gorky'' during a demonstration flight over Moscow. As a result of a poorly executed loop manoeuvre around the plane performed by an accompanying I-5 fighter (pilot – Nikolai Blagin), both planes collided. Forty-six people aboard both planes were killed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Giant Ship Collides With Stunt Plane|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%25205%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201935%2520Grayscale%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201935%2520Grayscale%2520-%25206279.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Df40d0b5%26DocId%3D6772433%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D20%26hits%3D49%2B324%2B77d%2B7ef%2B823%2B835%2B847%2B859%2B8a7%2B8a8%2Baa8%2Bc20%2Bcd2%2Bd04%2Bd3d%2Bd8c%2B1099%2B10eb%2B111e%2B1208%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%25205%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201935%2520Grayscale%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201935%2520Grayscale%2520-%25206279.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Df40d0b5%26DocId%3D6772433%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D20%26hits%3D49%2B324%2B77d%2B7ef%2B823%2B835%2B847%2B859%2B8a7%2B8a8%2Baa8%2Bc20%2Bcd2%2Bd04%2Bd3d%2Bd8c%2B1099%2B10eb%2B111e%2B1208%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=2 June 2017|work=Brooklyn Daily Eagle|publisher=Associated Press|date=19 May 1935}}</ref> * March 23 - Jackson, Mississippi - Pilot Herb Bassett was killed when his airplane failed to come out of a tailspin and his parachute became entangled in the aircraft when he tried to jump.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1817&dat=19350324&id=wOk-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=x0wMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6352,3598460&hl=en|title = Stunt Aviator Loses Life As Plane Falls |date=March 24, 1935 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = U.P.|newspaper = The Tuscaloosa News|page = 2}}</ref>
==1934== *August 28 – [[Warsaw]], Poland – during an opening ceremony of the [[Challenge International de Tourisme 1934]], a [[PZL P.7]]a fighter of Sgt. Dłuto, performing aerobatics at low altitude, crashed into a ground. The pilot was seriously injured.<ref>Krzyżan, Marian, ''Międzynarodowe turnieje lotnicze 1929–1934'', Warsaw 1988, {{ISBN|83-206-0637-3}} {{pl icon}}, p.103.</ref> *August 5 - Women's National Air Meet (Dayton, Ohio) - Pilot Frances Harrell Marsalis was killed when she lost control of her biplane while banking to avoid other aircraft during a race.<ref>{{cite news|title=Plane Crash Kills Famous Avatrix|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1934/08/06/page/1/article/plane-crash-kills-famous-aviatrix|accessdate=30 May 2017|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=6 August 1934}}</ref> *July 1 - [[Hornell, New York]] - Pilot Merriell S. McHenry was killed when he bailed out of his plane at too low an altitude. His plane had stalled and entered a nosedive following a parachutist successfully jumping from the plane.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hornell Stunt Flier Killed In Plane Crash|accessdate=2 June 2017|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201934.pdf%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201934%2520-%25203554.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D3eac76a1%26DocId%3D10882804%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3D927%2B92b%2B92c%2B9aa%2B9b5%2B9eb%2Ba1e%2Bbb8%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201934.pdf%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201934%2520-%25203554.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D3eac76a1%26DocId%3D10882804%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3D927%2B92b%2B92c%2B9aa%2B9b5%2B9eb%2Ba1e%2Bbb8%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|work=The Poughkeepsie Eagle-News|publisher=Associated Press|date=2 July 1934}}</ref> *June 30 - Royal Air Force [[Hawker Hart]] ''K2983'' crashed during a display at [[RAF Hendon]] killing the passenger.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The Air Display Accident - Squadron Leader Collett's Death |day_of_week=Tuesday |date=24 July 1934 |page_number=11 |issue=46814 |column= }}</ref> *June 25 - [[Osijek|Esseg, Serbia]] - Eight spectators were killed and thirteen injured when a stunt pilot was unable to recover from a dive and crashed into a crowd of spectators.<ref>{{cite news|title=Eight Die Crash At Air Circus|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=MT19340625.2.7&txq=stunting+crash|accessdate=10 June 2017|work=Madera Tribune|publisher=United Press|date=25 June 1934}}</ref> *May 20 - [[Wink, Texas]] - Pilot Harry Lynch and three passengers were killed when their aircraft struck power lines while stunting during an airport dedication ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|title=Four Persons Killed In Stunting Plane|url=http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn84031094/1934-05-21/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=01%2F01%2F1914&index=2&date2=12%2F31%2F1940&searchType=advanced&SearchType=prox5&sequence=0&words=death+stunting&proxdistance=5&to_year=1940&rows=20&ortext=&from_year=1914&proxtext=stunting+death&phrasetext=&andtext=&dateFilterType=range&page=1|accessdate=29 October 2017|work=Plattsburg Daily Press|publisher=Associated Press|date=21 May 1934}}</ref>
==1933== *October 30 – Four members of a flying circus troupe were killed after a mid-air collision over Amarillo, Texas, United States. The planes were flying through streamers dropped by a third aircraft when the collision occurred.<ref>{{cite news|title=Plane Crashes Take 8 Lives|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gW8hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4YcFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4426,5338646&dq=air+circus+accident&hl=en|accessdate=June 1, 2012|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=October 30, 1933}}</ref> *October 1 - [[Drogheda|Drogheda, Ireland]] - Captain K. Rose was killed and two passengers were injured while taking part in an air circus.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1300&dat=19331003&id=4f1hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lJUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5916,3050025&hl=en|title = Air "Circus" Crash In Ireland |date=October 3, 1933 |accessdate=August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Age|page = 5}}</ref> *September 25 - Newport, Vermont - Parachutist Robert Keating was killed when he misjudged his jump height and struck the water at Derby Pond before a crowd of 3,000 spectators.<ref>{{cite news|title=Parachute Jumper Of Champlain Killed As He Falls In Pond|url=http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn86033359/1933-09-29/ed-1/seq-7/#date1=01%2F01%2F1914&sort=relevance&date2=12%2F31%2F1940&searchType=advanced&SearchType=phrase&sequence=0&index=5&words=Circus+Flying&proxdistance=&to_year=1940&rows=20&ortext=&from_year=1914&proxtext=&phrasetext=flying+circus&andtext=&dateFilterType=range&page=5|accessdate=29 May 2017|publisher=Lake Placid News|date=29 September 1933}}</ref> *July 4 - [[Century of Progress|Century of Progress World's Fair]] (Chicago, Illinois) - Parachutist Joe Wilson was killed when he failed to open his parachute during a nighttime jump when a fireworks display was occurring. It was speculated that he may have been knocked unconscious during the jump.<ref>{{cite news|title=Body Of Stunt Man, Killed In Leap, Recovered|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201933%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201933%2520-%25204798.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D78d1f357%26DocId%3D4236209%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D12%26hits%3D124%2B1de%2B1e1%2B201%2B21f%2B220%2B222%2B7a2%2B7af%2B7c7%2B820%2Ba0a%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201933%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201933%2520-%25204798.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D78d1f357%26DocId%3D4236209%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D12%26hits%3D124%2B1de%2B1e1%2B201%2B21f%2B220%2B222%2B7a2%2B7af%2B7c7%2B820%2Ba0a%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=3 June 2017|work=Albany Times-Union|publisher=Associated Press|date=5 July 1933}}</ref> *June 18 - An aircraft crashed during aerobatics on a hangar during a flying display at Essey near Nancy, France during a display killing the pilot and a spectator and injuring 40 others.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=French Air Display Accident - 40 Person injured|day_of_week=Tuesday |date=20 June 1933 |page_number=15 |issue= |column= }}</ref> *May 27 - Welland Municipal Airport ([[Welland|Welland, Ontario, Canada]]) - Parachutist Elsie Storrow was killed when she delayed deploying her parachute during a demonstration jump as part of the dedication ceremonies for the airport.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fatality Mars Dedication of County Airport|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201933%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201933%2520-%25203361.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffcd081bc4%26DocId%3D8217557%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D9%26hits%3D43%2B10c%2B362%2B50f%2B5a5%2B5b8%2B5ea%2Baf1%2Bd0e%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201933%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201933%2520-%25203361.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffcd081bc4%26DocId%3D8217557%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D9%26hits%3D43%2B10c%2B362%2B50f%2B5a5%2B5b8%2B5ea%2Baf1%2Bd0e%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=3 June 2017|publisher=Buffalo Courier Express|date=28 May 1933}}</ref> *May 13 - American Air Races (Oklahoma City, Oklahoma) - Pilot Art Killips was killed when his aircraft stalled and crashed while performing multiple snap roll maneuvers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Memorial Today Will Pay Honor to Chicago Flyer|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1934/05/12/page/16/article/c-c-julian-u-s-oil-swindler-is-buried-a-pauper|accessdate=30 May 2017|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=12 May 1934}}</ref>
==1932== *September 5 - Cleveland National Air Races (Cleveland, Ohio) - Pilot [[Al Wilson (pilot)|Al Wilson]] was killed when he was involved in a collision with an [[Autogyro]] while performing stunts. John Miller, the pilot of the autogyro, was injured but his passenger was uninjured.<ref>{{cite news|title=Miller Crash Proves Fatal|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201932%2520a%2520pdf%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201932%2520a%2520-%25201708.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dfffffffff9258060%26DocId%3D10873650%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D17%26hits%3D39b%2B6a5%2B6de%2B9d7%2Ba40%2Ba52%2Ba99%2Baa3%2Bb39%2Bb76%2B106f%2B1073%2B107b%2B1348%2B1398%2B13de%2B13ff%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201932%2520a%2520pdf%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201932%2520a%2520-%25201708.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dfffffffff9258060%26DocId%3D10873650%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D17%26hits%3D39b%2B6a5%2B6de%2B9d7%2Ba40%2Ba52%2Ba99%2Baa3%2Bb39%2Bb76%2B106f%2B1073%2B107b%2B1348%2B1398%2B13de%2B13ff%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=3 June 2017|publisher=The Poughkeepsie Eagle-News|date=6 September 1932}}</ref> *August 7 - [[Fairfax Municipal Airport]] (Kansas City, Kansas) - Pilot Mildred Kauffman was killed when her plane was involved in a mid-air collision in which the wings of both aircraft struck and locked together during an opposite direction flyby with both planes crashing from an approximate height of seventy-five feet. Don Moss, the pilot of the other plane, along with his passenger and Kauffman's passenger were not injured.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wings Lock In Air, Aviatrix Killed|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252011%2FNew%2520York%2520Evening%2520Post%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Post%25201932%2520Grayscale%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Post%25201932%2520Grayscale%2520-%25206070.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.fultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffc996baa7%26DocId%3D5504465%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520U%252dF%252dP%26HitCount%3D4%26hits%3D2b2%2B2b3%2B39d%2B39e%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252011%2FNew%2520York%2520Evening%2520Post%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Post%25201932%2520Grayscale%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Post%25201932%2520Grayscale%2520-%25206070.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffc996baa7%26DocId%3D5504465%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520U%252dF%252dP%26HitCount%3D4%26hits%3D2b2%2B2b3%2B39d%2B39e%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=3 June 2017|work=New York Evening Post|publisher=Associated Press|date=8 August 1932}}</ref> *May 22- American Legion Air Circus ([[Delano, California]],United States) – Pilot Fred Larson, flying the sister ship of the [[Spirit of St. Louis]], was killed and passenger William Simmons was injured after their plane lost altitude while making a turn. The plane's wing struck the ground causing the plane to flip over and burst into flames.<ref>{{cite news| title =One Killed In Air Circus| newspaper = The Spokesman-Review| agency =Associated Press| date = May 22, 1932| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=s_AUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hOMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2657,1862633&dq=air+circus&hl=en| accessdate =December 18, 2011}}</ref> *October 5 - [[Avro 504|Avro 504K]] ''G-AAUJ'' crashed while performing an aerobatic display at the National Aviation Day display at Plompton, near Harrogate, Yorkshire, England, killing one of the two passengers.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Crash at Air Display |day_of_week=Thursday|date=6 October 1932 |page_number=10 |issue=46257 |column= }}</ref>
==1931== * June 13 - [[Avro Avian]] ''G-AAHJ'' crashed during a display at Cambridge Airport during an air display killing the pilot. The starboard wing broke up during a steep dive.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Air Display Accident - Report on Wing Failure|day_of_week=Thursday |date=24 December 1931 |page_number=9 |issue=46014 |column= }}</ref> * May 17 - Omaha, Nebraska - Pilot [[Charles W. Holman|Charles W. "Speed" Holman]] was killed while performing before a crowd of 20,000 spectators at the opening of a new airport.<ref>{{cite news|title=Death Overtakes Noted Stunt Flier Before Thousands|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FLockport%2520NY%2520Union%2520Sun%2520Journal%2FLockport%2520NY%2520Union%2520Sun%2520Journal%25201931%2FLockport%2520NY%2520Union%2520Sun%2520Journal%25201931%2520-%25202073.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffd9a3adcd%26DocId%3D2053909%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D11%26hits%3D11%2B89%2Ba7%2Bac%2Bdc%2Ba31%2Ba35%2Ba4a%2Ba64%2Ba8e%2Bb80%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FLockport%2520NY%2520Union%2520Sun%2520Journal%2FLockport%2520NY%2520Union%2520Sun%2520Journal%25201931%2FLockport%2520NY%2520Union%2520Sun%2520Journal%25201931%2520-%25202073.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffd9a3adcd%26DocId%3D2053909%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D11%26hits%3D11%2B89%2Ba7%2Bac%2Bdc%2Ba31%2Ba35%2Ba4a%2Ba64%2Ba8e%2Bb80%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=2 June 2017|work=Lockport Union-Sun and Journal|publisher=Associated Press|date=18 May 1931}}</ref> * April 30 - Lynchburg, Virginia - Pilot Clarence M. Ellicock was killed when the aileron on his plane loosened while performing a demonstration during the dedication ceremonies of the municipal airport.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stunt Flier Dies In Crash|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%25201931%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%25201931%2520-%25204813.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffd06f2800%26DocId%3D2709292%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D10%26hits%3D10%2B1f%2B4f%2B7e%2B84%2Bbf%2Bf8%2B131%2B143%2B308%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%25201931%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%25201931%2520-%25204813.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffd06f2800%26DocId%3D2709292%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D10%26hits%3D10%2B1f%2B4f%2B7e%2B84%2Bbf%2Bf8%2B131%2B143%2B308%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=2 June 2017|work=The New York Sun|publisher=Associated Press|date=30 April 1931}}</ref>
==1930== *November 2 - [[Preakness, New Jersey]] - Pilot Alden H. Russell was injured and his passenger was killed when his aircraft went into a tailspin and crashed while stunting before a crowd of 5,000 at the local airport.<ref>{{cite news|title=Danger From The Air|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBallston%2520Spa%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%2FBallston%2520Spa%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%25201930%2FBallston%2520Spa%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%25201930%2520-%25200678.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffd263b98b%26DocId%3D6714526%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D7%26hits%3Df%2B292%2B2b0%2B2b2%2B2f6%2Bc0e%2Bc14%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBallston%2520Spa%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%2FBallston%2520Spa%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%25201930%2FBallston%2520Spa%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%25201930%2520-%25200678.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffd263b98b%26DocId%3D6714526%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D7%26hits%3Df%2B292%2B2b0%2B2b2%2B2f6%2Bc0e%2Bc14%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=10 June 2017|publisher=Ballston Spa Daily Journal|date=5 November 1930}}</ref> *September 18 - [[Stuttgart|Stuttgart, Germany]] - Acrobat Fritz Schindler along with three pilots were killed when two planes crashed while attempting to transfer Schindler from one plane to the other via a rope ladder.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19300919&id=CGMeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ao4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4369,5250678&hl=en|title = Four Die In Stunt Crash |date = September 19, 1930 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Pittsburgh Press|page = 2}}</ref> *September 14 - [[Binghamton, New York]] - Sixteen year old Ciara Lechner was killed while attempting her first parachute jump at an air circus. Neither chute was opened and the professional parachutist on board failed to follow her after she left the plane.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1928&dat=19300915&id=Y4wgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fWYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5027,5780359&hl=en|title = Falls To Death In First Parachute Jump Attempt |date = September 15, 1930 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = The Lewiston Daily Sun|page = 1}}</ref> *August 28 - [[Iowa State Fairgrounds]] (Des Moines, Iowa) - Four people were critically injured when two aircraft were involved in a mid-air collision while stunting. One of the crafts crash landed on a tent and the other was able to land.<ref>{{cite news|title=Two Planes Collide|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201930%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201930%2520-%25204913.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dfffffffff55b134b%26DocId%3D8058619%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3Da%2B109%2B8d2%2B9c0%2Bf79%2B10f3%2B14ff%2B1504%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201930%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201930%2520-%25204913.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dfffffffff55b134b%26DocId%3D8058619%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3Da%2B109%2B8d2%2B9c0%2Bf79%2B10f3%2B14ff%2B1504%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=10 June 2017|work=Buffalo Courier-Express|publisher=Associated Press|date=29 August 1930}}</ref> *August 27 - Chicago - Navy pilot Lieutenant J.P. Deshazo was killed during the national air races when he lost control while attempting a barrel roll during a 50-mile speed race with 16 Navy planes. He crashed in front of the bleachers killing concessionaire Louis Weiner and injuring seven others from shrapnel from the exploding fuel tank or burning oil from the aircraft.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19300828&id=tRBWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=huIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5234,6067388&hl=en|title = Stunting Plane Demon Of Death |date = August 28, 1930 |accessdate = August 24, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = The Spokesman-Review|page = 1}}</ref> * July 11 - [[National Cherry Festival|Michigan Cherry Festival]] ([[Traverse City, Michigan]]) -Pilot Lieutenant A.H. Coleman was killed and passenger George Watson was seriously injured when their aircraft failed to pull out of a dive while performing stunts.<ref>{{cite news|title=9 Killed In Airplane Crashes|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252017%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%25201930%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%25201930%2520-%25205745.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D42a131d5%26DocId%3D3430104%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520U%252dF%252dP%26HitCount%3D33%26hits%3D25%2Bbc3%2Bbc9%2Bc47%2Bd27%2Bd46%2Bff9%2B1036%2B10ff%2B118b%2B11d3%2B1212%2B1226%2B139e%2B15b7%2B15c5%2B15c9%2B1634%2B17cd%2B17f9%2B1874%2B1a06%2B1ae1%2B1af5%2B1b0b%2B1b83%2B1c09%2B1c1e%2B1cf8%2B1d7e%2B1e1f%2B1eb2%2B1eb6%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252017%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%25201930%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Journal%25201930%2520-%25205745.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D42a131d5%26DocId%3D3430104%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520U%252dF%252dP%26HitCount%3D33%26hits%3D25%2Bbc3%2Bbc9%2Bc47%2Bd27%2Bd46%2Bff9%2B1036%2B10ff%2B118b%2B11d3%2B1212%2B1226%2B139e%2B15b7%2B15c5%2B15c9%2B1634%2B17cd%2B17f9%2B1874%2B1a06%2B1ae1%2B1af5%2B1b0b%2B1b83%2B1c09%2B1c1e%2B1cf8%2B1d7e%2B1e1f%2B1eb2%2B1eb6%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=10 June 2017|work=Syracuse Journal|publisher=I.N.S.|date=11 July 1930}}</ref> *July 4 - Neosho Airport ([[Neosho, Missouri]]) During a wing walking performance an unidentified pilot and wing walker were killed when the wing collapsed on their aircraft sending it into a tailspin.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1917&dat=19300705&id=-V0hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7YUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5390,536594&hl=en|title = 2 Stunt Fliers Killed In An Airplane Crash |date = July 5, 1930 |accessdate=August 26, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = Schenectady Gazette|page = 1}}</ref> *May 30 - Memorial Day display ([[Arnettsville, West Virginia]]) - Pilots Loren Scott and Everett Arnholtt were killed after colliding with a tree during a memorial day flying display.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=998&dat=19300605&id=GNgpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YPkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2392,2385353&hl=en|title = "Scotty" Killed In Crash Of Plane Near Fairmont |date = June 5, 1930 |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |newspaper = Roane County Reporter|page = 1}}</ref> *April 27 – ([[Fayetteville, Tennessee]]) – At least nine air show spectators were killed and about twenty injured when pilot Milton P. Covert's plane lost altitude and crashed while approaching the landing area. The victims were standing on a railroad embankment as the plane approached at a low altitude. At the time there were claims that the pilot was deliberately trying to scare the spectators off the embankment. The pilot and his two passengers escaped unhurt, but Covert was later arraigned on charges.<ref>{{cite news | last =| first =| authorlink =| title =Airplane Falls on Crowd, Seven Killed | work = The Frederick Post| agency =Associated Press| date = April 28, 1930| url = http://www3.gendisasters.com/tennessee/9225/fayetteville-tn-flying-circus-airplane-crash-apr-1930| format =| doi =| accessdate =July 12, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =| first =| authorlink =| title =HELD FOR DEATHS IN CRASH; Pilot of Plane Which Killed Nine at Fayetteville, Tenn., Arraigned | work = The New York Times| publisher =| date = April 28, 1930| url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10715F6345A147A93C3A8178ED85F448385F9 |accessdate=September 20, 2009}}</ref> *April 27 – [[Düsseldorf]] – Aerial acrobat Willy Hundertmark was killed while attempting a plane change over via a rope ladder while in flight. After successfully getting on the ladder dangling from the upper plane he became entangled and couldn't ascend. After 45 minutes the pilot attempted a low speed landing and dragged Mr Hundertmark "over a long stretch of the field".<ref>{{cite news|title=German Ariel Acrobat Dies In View Of Throng| newspaper =The Lewiston Daily Sun| agency =Associated Press| date = April 28, 1930| url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Gx0gAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lWYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4643,2414646&dq=air+circus&hl=en| accessdate =December 18, 2011}}</ref> *March 30 - [[Buffalo Niagara International Airport|Buffalo Airport]] ([[Cheektowaga (town), New York|Cheektowaga, New York]]) - Pilot Mildred Kaufmann parachuted safely after being ejected from her aircraft while performing loops. She was using a borrowed aircraft at the time and not her modified craft that she normally used due to her small stature. The unoccupied plane crashed near a hangar at the airport.<ref>{{cite news|title=Girl Falls Out of Plane, Lives|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201931%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201931%2520-%25202506.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D3af80ccf%26DocId%3D8194978%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D18%26hits%3D65%2B4e5%2B82e%2Ba1c%2Ba6d%2Bad6%2Badd%2Bb00%2Bb39%2Be68%2Be74%2Be80%2Be93%2Beee%2Bf67%2Bf76%2Bfcf%2B1081%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201931%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201931%2520-%25202506.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D3af80ccf%26DocId%3D8194978%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D18%26hits%3D65%2B4e5%2B82e%2Ba1c%2Ba6d%2Bad6%2Badd%2Bb00%2Bb39%2Be68%2Be74%2Be80%2Be93%2Beee%2Bf67%2Bf76%2Bfcf%2B1081%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=3 June 2017|publisher=Buffalo Courier Express|date=31 March 1930}}</ref>
==1929== *November 11 - [[Marlborough, Massachusetts]] - Lieutenant William P. Leonard was killed when his aircraft nosedived and crashed while performing stunts with a second aircraft before a crowd of 7,000.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fatality Marks First Stunt Flying Exhibit|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%25208%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201929%2520Grayscale%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201929%2520Grayscale%2520-%25206677.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D52faa6ce%26DocId%3D2762597%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D15%26hits%3D5d%2Bd41%2Bd53%2Bd5b%2Be79%2Bea9%2Beac%2Bec3%2B114f%2B1194%2B11e1%2B1209%2B1234%2B144a%2B15b7%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%25208%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201929%2520Grayscale%2FSchenectady%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201929%2520Grayscale%2520-%25206677.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D52faa6ce%26DocId%3D2762597%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D15%26hits%3D5d%2Bd41%2Bd53%2Bd5b%2Be79%2Bea9%2Beac%2Bec3%2B114f%2B1194%2B11e1%2B1209%2B1234%2B144a%2B15b7%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=3 June 2017|publisher=Schenectady Gazette|date=12 November 1929}}</ref> *October 7 – Cross Keys Airport ([[Altoona, Pennsylvania]], United States) – A Parachutist was killed when his parachute failed to open while putting on a display in front of a crowd of 1,000 persons.<ref name="news.google">{{cite news| last =| first =| title = Two Killed in Plane, 'Chute Accidents| newspaper =Rochester Evening Journal| location =| pages =| agency = Associated Press| date = October 7, 1929| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hx9WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Tj8NAAAAIBAJ&pg=938,4782625&dq=air+circus&hl=en| accessdate =December 18, 2011}}</ref> *October 7 – Keystone Airport ([[Johnstown, Pennsylvania]], United States) – A pilot was killed while attempting a low altitude barrel roll. His plane went into a tail spin and crashed into a swamp.<ref name="news.google" /> *July 27 - Cohoes Airport Carnival ([[Cohoes, New York]]) - Pilot G.H. Perin was injured when his aircraft failed to recover from a low altitude dive while involved in a balloon popping contest.<ref>{{cite news|title=G.H. Perin, Cohoes Flier, Near Death In Plane Crash|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201929%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201929%2520a%2520-%25201324.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D43a020fe%26DocId%3D4194364%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D7%26hits%3D1e%2B1f%2B3d%2B3f%2B86%2B2f3%2B59b%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201929%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Times%2520Union%25201929%2520a%2520-%25201324.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D43a020fe%26DocId%3D4194364%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D7%26hits%3D1e%2B1f%2B3d%2B3f%2B86%2B2f3%2B59b%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=1 June 2017|publisher=Times-Union|date=28 July 1929}}</ref>
==1928== * November 11 - Pocatello Airport ([[Pocatello, Idaho]]) - Pilot Harry McDougall and passenger Elda Rice were killed when their aircraft went into a tailspin during an air race.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19281113&id=2qBXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vfMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4916,3851811&hl=en|title = Boise Aviator Falls To Death |date = November 13, 1928 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = The Spokesman-Review|page = 1}}</ref> * October 11 - [[Hendon|Hendon, England]] - RAF Lieutenant Somerville and Corporal Loud were killed during an air force exhibition when their aircraft lost its tail during a low altitude flyby. The Sultan of [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]] was in attendance at the time of the accident.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19281011&id=oIxQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ryEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3610,6825082&hl=en|title = Two Die When Plane Crashes |date = October 11, 1928 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |publisher = Associated Press|newspaper = The Milwaukee Journal|page = 20}}</ref> *June 28 - Vincennes Fair ([[Vincennes]], France) - Pilot Alfred Fronval was killed when his aircraft struck a parked military aircraft while landing.<ref>{{cite news|title=France Most Famous Stunt Pilots Killed|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%25208%2FNiagara%2520Falls%2520NY%2520Gazette%2FNiagara%2520Falls%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201928%2520may-Jun%2520Grayscale%2FNiagara%2520Falls%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201928%2520may-Jun%2520Grayscale%2520-%25201119.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.fultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D2003612f%26DocId%3D2244636%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D16%26hits%3D59%2Bdf%2B11c%2B135%2B158%2B182%2B394%2B398%2B3ad%2B3bb%2B3f6%2B476%2B4f0%2B98e%2Bd0c%2Bd32%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%25208%2FNiagara%2520Falls%2520NY%2520Gazette%2FNiagara%2520Falls%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201928%2520may-Jun%2520Grayscale%2FNiagara%2520Falls%2520NY%2520Gazette%25201928%2520may-Jun%2520Grayscale%2520-%25201119.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D2003612f%26DocId%3D2244636%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D16%26hits%3D59%2Bdf%2B11c%2B135%2B158%2B182%2B394%2B398%2B3ad%2B3bb%2B3f6%2B476%2B4f0%2B98e%2Bd0c%2Bd32%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=2 June 2017|work=Niagara Falls Gazette|publisher=Accociated Press|date=28 June 1928}}</ref> *May 5 - Dayton, Ohio - Pilot Harold J. Forshay and his two passengers, Walter Clark and Blair Cross, were killed when their plane crashed while performing stunts in front of hundreds of spectators.<ref>{{cite news|title=Three Victims Stunting Plane|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=MT19280505.2.5&txq=stunting+crash|accessdate=10 June 2017|work=Madera Tibune|publisher=United Press Dispatch|date=5 May 1928}}</ref> *February 15 - Southeastern Air Derby ([[Macon, Georgia]]) - Pilot Buck Steel and passenger Francis Ashcraft were killed when an explosive device that was thrown from their plane detonated prematurely either killing them instantly or rendering them unable to control the plane that then crashed in town killing a pedestrian. Eight others on the ground were injured either from the plane crash or the collapse of a sidewalk near the crash site.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bomb In Plane Kills Three, Injures Eight|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201928%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201928%2520-%25201349.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffff97b0ee5f%26DocId%3D8046015%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D23%26hits%3D38%2B18d%2B1a1%2B253%2B26c%2B495%2B4a6%2B4db%2B512%2B572%2B595%2B5c7%2B60b%2B617%2B7fa%2Ba7a%2Ba9a%2Bb23%2Bb51%2Bbc9%2Bc2c%2Bdad%2B1225%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201928%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2520Express%25201928%2520-%25201349.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffff97b0ee5f%26DocId%3D8046015%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D23%26hits%3D38%2B18d%2B1a1%2B253%2B26c%2B495%2B4a6%2B4db%2B512%2B572%2B595%2B5c7%2B60b%2B617%2B7fa%2Ba7a%2Ba9a%2Bb23%2Bb51%2Bbc9%2Bc2c%2Bdad%2B1225%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=2 June 2017|work=Buffalo Courier Express|publisher=Associated Press|date=19 February 1928}}</ref>
==1927== *November 21 – [[Santa Monica, California]] – Parachutist Miss Jean West escaped uninjured following a parachute demonstration accident. Her parachute became entangled on the wing following her jump but the pilot was able to safely land while dragging Miss West several hundred feet.<ref>{{cite news| last =| first =| title =Girl Dragged by Airplane| newspaper = The Evening News| location =| pages = | publisher = United Press| date =November 21, 1927| url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mg4vAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9qMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3485,6169736&dq=air+circus&hl=en| accessdate =December 18, 2011}}</ref> *September 12 - Gates Flying Circus at Poughkeepsie, New York - While performing loop to loops above the city a loose chain fell from the stunt planes cockpit and crashed through the roof of a local theatre landing on the stage.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stunt Costs Flier $25 When He Drops Chain|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201927.pdf%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201927%2520-%25203516.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffce1b1f20%26DocId%3D10857287%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D11%26hits%3D28%2B79%2Bb5%2Bf8%2B63c%2B833%2B969%2B100c%2B10e9%2B1125%2B11a7%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201927.pdf%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201927%2520-%25203516.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffce1b1f20%26DocId%3D10857287%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D11%26hits%3D28%2B79%2Bb5%2Bf8%2B63c%2B833%2B969%2B100c%2B10e9%2B1125%2B11a7%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=3 June 2017|publisher=Poughkeepsie Eagle-News|date=13 September 1927}}</ref> *July 4 - Preston's Field ([[Amenia (town), New York|Amenia, New York]]) - Pilot William Cooke and passenger Thomas Moawood were injured when their [[Curtiss JN-4|Curtiss Jenny]] scout plane crashed while performing stunts from an approximate height of 300 feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=2 Stunt Fliers Cheat Death In Amenia Crash|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201927.pdf%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201927%2520-%25202778.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffe19857b2%26DocId%3D10856552%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D16%26hits%3D1a%2B1cb%2B1e8%2B1fb%2B26e%2B274%2B275%2B742%2B78c%2B7a2%2B807%2B826%2B834%2B860%2B8ab%2B1232%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201927.pdf%2FPoughkeepsie%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Eagle%25201927%2520-%25202778.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffe19857b2%26DocId%3D10856552%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D16%26hits%3D1a%2B1cb%2B1e8%2B1fb%2B26e%2B274%2B275%2B742%2B78c%2B7a2%2B807%2B826%2B834%2B860%2B8ab%2B1232%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=12 June 2017|publisher=Poughkeepsie Eagle-News|date=5 July 1927}}</ref>
==1926== *August 15 - Atlanta, Georgia - Parachutist Jimmy Calhoun was killed when he lost his grip on his parachute, at too high an altitude, while preparing to dive into a lake at an amusement park while 10,000 spectators watched.<ref>{{cite news|title=10,000 See Man Killed|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%25201926%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%25201926%2520-%25203702.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D712d553b%26DocId%3D2691777%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D7%26hits%3Df%2B12b%2Bacc%2Baf9%2Bb26%2Bb3d%2Bb8f%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%25201926%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Sun%25201926%2520-%25203702.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D712d553b%26DocId%3D2691777%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D7%26hits%3Df%2B12b%2Bacc%2Baf9%2Bb26%2Bb3d%2Bb8f%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=2 June 2017|work=The New York Sun|publisher=U.P.|date=16 August 1926}}</ref> *May 24 – [[Chariton, Iowa]] – Spectator M.H. Johnson was killed and trapeze performer Eva Murphy was injured during a stunt demonstration. Mr. Murphy was trying to remove Mr. Johnson's hat during a low altitude flyby while hanging from an airplane mounted trapeze. Mr. Johnson was struck and died from a head injury.<ref>{{cite news| last =| first =| title = Four Killed, Three Hurt in the Air| newspaper = Warsaw Union| location =| pages =| agency =Associated Press| date = May 24, 1926| url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Gi5HAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TnsMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3396,6185895&dq=air+circus&hl=en| accessdate =December 18, 2011}}</ref> *April 18 - [[Vero, Florida]] - Volunteer performer Jewell Bell was killed after leaping from a low flying plane, at approximately fifty feet, into the ocean during an air circus performance.<ref>{{cite news|title=Volunteer Performer Killed At Air Circus|url=http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn84031447/1926-04-19/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=01%2F01%2F1725&index=5&date2=12%2F31%2F2016&searchType=advanced&SearchType=phrase&sequence=0&words=AIR+CIRCUS&proxdistance=&to_year=2016&rows=20&ortext=&from_year=1725&proxtext=&phrasetext=air+circus&andtext=&dateFilterType=range&page=1|accessdate=28 May 2017|work=The Post-Star|publisher=Associated Press|date=April 19, 1926}}</ref>
==1925== * August 23 – Baer Municipal Aviation Field [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] – Pilot H. Huntley was struck by the propeller of the aircraft he was attempting to start. Huntley was knocked unconscious and suffered a fractured shoulder in the mishap.<ref>{{cite news|title=One Accident Mars Air Circus, Seen By 10,000 Persons at New Flying Field Near Fort Wayne|newspaper=Warsaw Daily Times and the Northern Indianian |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LUlfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=olQNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4367,6940774&dq=air+circus+accident&hl=en|accessdate=June 1, 2012|date=August 24, 1925}}</ref> * June 7 – American Legion Flying Circus ([[Cape Girardeau, Missouri]]) – Passengers Grace Lamar and Pearl Baysinger were killed when pilot John Hunter's plane crashed into a tree and burned.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1893&dat=19250608&id=BCQrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=edIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5514,2373990&hl=en|title = Cause of Fatal Airplane Crash Killing Two, Is Not Determined |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |newspaper = The Southeastern Missourian|page = 1}}</ref>
==1924== *October 12 - Wichita, Kansas - Parachutist Ruth Garver was killed when her parachute failed to open during a performance before a crowd of 10,000 spectators.<ref>{{cite news|title=Woman Killed In Circus Stunt|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=MT19241013.2.27&srpos=17&e=--1900---1930--en--20--1--txt-txIN-stunt+plane-------1|accessdate=29 October 2017|work=Madera Tribune|issue=136|publisher=United Press Dispatch|date=13 October 1924}}</ref> *October 8 – Virginia State Fair (Richmond, Virginia) – Pilot Russell Simon was killed following a mid-air collision with another plane during an exhibition flight. His plane crashed into the roof of a building on the fairground and he was ejected from the plane.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19241009&id=jFYsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LMoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4762,742621&hl=en|title = Flying Circus Airman Is Killed At Virginia Fair |date = October 9, 1924 |accessdate = August 23, 2015 |newspaper = The Spartansburg Herald-Journal|page = 1}}</ref> *October 4 - National Air Races (Dayton, Ohio) - Captain Burt Skeel, pilot of a Curtis racing plane, was killed when the wings of his plane buckled prior to his start in the race.<ref>{{cite news|title=Racer Killed As 300 Mi. An Hour Plane Crumples|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1924/10/05/page/10/article/racer-killed-as-300-mi-an-hour-plane-crumples|accessdate=30 May 2017|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=5 October 1924}}</ref> *March 23 - Jacksonville, Florida - Stunt woman Mabel Coby was injured after she fell from an airplane while attempting to transfer to the plane from a speeding automobile.<ref>{{cite news|title=Girl Flyer Badly Hurt In Airplane Fall|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=HT19240324.2.21&srpos=7&e=--1900---1930--en--20--1--txt-txIN-stunt+plane-------1|accessdate=29 October 2017|issue=120|publisher=Healdsburg Tribune|date=24 March 1924}}</ref> *March 3 - San Antonio, Texas - Pilot Bertha Horchem was killed when her plane crashed while performing with an air circus group in front of 3,000 spectators. The left wing of her plane collapsed while performing a loop at approximately 1,200 feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Woman Flier Killed|url=http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn84031447/1924-03-04/ed-1/seq-15/#date1=01%2F01%2F1725&sort=relevance&date2=12%2F31%2F2016&searchType=advanced&SearchType=phrase&sequence=0&index=16&words=air+circus&proxdistance=&to_year=2016&rows=20&ortext=&from_year=1725&proxtext=&phrasetext=air+circus&andtext=&dateFilterType=range&page=5|accessdate=28 May 2017|publisher=The Post-Star|date=March 4, 1924}}</ref>
==1923== *November 18 – The first aerial refueling-related fatality occurs during an air show at [[Kelly Field]], Texas, when the fuel hose becomes entangled in the right wings of the refueler and the receiver aircraft. The Army Air Service pilot of the refueler, Lt. P. T. Wagner, is killed in the ensuing crash of [[Airco DH-4|DH-4B]], ''23–444''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aviationarchaeology.com/src/1940sB4/1923.htm|title=1923 US Army Air Service Accident Reports|publisher=}}</ref>
==1922==
*October 13 - Cleveland, Tennessee - Stuntwoman Eva Moss was killed after the plane she was hanging from was forced to land. She had performed a stunt of hanging by her teeth from a rope ladder and was either unable or unwilling to climb back into the aircraft. The pilot then flew low over a lake and signaled her to drop into the water but she did not follow his directions. The pilot was then forced to land which caused the fatal injuries to Ms. Moss.<ref>{{cite news|title=Girl Stunt Flier Meets Horrible Death Dangling From An Airplane|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SU19221014.2.147&srpos=91&e=--1900---1930--en--20--81--txt-txIN-stunt+plane-------1|accessdate=29 October 2017|work=Sacramento Union|issue=26143|publisher=Associated Press|date=14 October 1922}}</ref> *September 23 – [[Mitchel Air Force Base|Mitchel Field]], [[Mineola, New York]] – A [[Martin NBS-1]] bomber, ''AS-68487'', Raymond E. Davis, pilot,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accident-report.com/world/namerica/US/NY.html|title=Accident-Report.com - Accident-Report.com - USAAF/USAF Accidents for New York|publisher=}}</ref> nose dived and crashed from an estimated altitude of 500 feet on a residential street killing the six military personnel on board. At the time, the plane was involved in a night time [[Military simulation|war game]] display that was lit by [[searchlight]]s and watched by an estimated crowd of 25,000 spectators.<ref>{{cite news|title=Six Killed In Crash Of Bombing Plane At Mitchel Field|publisher=The New York Times|date=September 24, 1922|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/09/24/99077955.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=July 16, 2009}}</ref> *September 7 - [[Rutland (city), Vermont|Rutland, Vermont]] - Lieutenant Belvin W. Maynard, pilot, along with mechanic Charles Mionette and passenger Lieutenant I. R. Wood were killed when their plane nosedived while attempting a tailspin at a low altitude. Parachutist Henry A. "Daredevil" Smith was killed a few hours later when his parachute failed to properly deploy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Flying Circus Turns Tragedy|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058393/1922-09-08/ed-1/seq-3/#date1=1921&sort=relevance&date2=1924&searchType=advanced&language=&sequence=0&index=0&words=CIRCUS+circus+flying+FLYING&proxdistance=5&state=&rows=20&ortext=&proxtext=flying+circus&phrasetext=flying+circus&andtext=&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=3|accessdate=28 May 2017|publisher=The Ogden Standard-Examiner|date=September 8, 1922}}</ref> *August 19 - [[Brattleboro, Vermont]] - Passengers Evelyn Harris, James Trahan and Trahan's five-year-old son were killed when the stunt aircraft, that they were passengers in, crashed after striking a tree during takeoff during dedication ceremonies for a new airport.<ref>{{cite news|title=Three Killed In Crash Of Airplanes On New Aviation Field|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Journal%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Journal%25201922%2520pdf%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Journal%25201922%2520-%25203319.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffc413ea33%26DocId%3D10193458%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D12%26hits%3D10%2B5f%2B163%2B37a%2B3e9%2B96c%2B9b6%2B9d8%2B9f4%2Ba21%2B1aff%2B1b05%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Journal%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Journal%25201922%2520pdf%2FAlbany%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Journal%25201922%2520-%25203319.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffc413ea33%26DocId%3D10193458%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D12%26hits%3D10%2B5f%2B163%2B37a%2B3e9%2B96c%2B9b6%2B9d8%2B9f4%2Ba21%2B1aff%2B1b05%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=11 June 2017|publisher=The Albany Evening Journal|date=19 August 1922}}</ref> *August 15 – [[Puck, Poland]] – during a bombing show, an observer prematurely dropped a bomb from a [[Lübeck-Travemünde F.4]] floatplane into spectators, killing 13 persons and injuring 34.<ref>Olejko, Andrzej. ''Tragiczne pokazy'' (Tragic show) in: "Aero Magazyn Lotniczy" nr. 2(21)/2009, pp.4–7 {{pl icon}}</ref> *June 17 – [[Louisville, Kentucky]] – Army airmen Lieutenant Robert O. Hanley (also reported as Robert E. Hanley) and Sergeant Arthur Opperman are killed when their [[Airco DH.4|DH.4]], U.S. Army Air Service serial number not recorded, crashed while making a sharp banking turn. Airframe destroyed by post-crash fire.<ref name="aviationarchaeology.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.aviationarchaeology.com/src/1940sB4/1922.htm|title=1922 US Army Air Service Accident Reports|publisher=}}</ref> The men were airborne to photograph the airshow that was to shortly begin.<ref>{{cite news| last =| first =| title = Two Army Airmen Are Burned to Death After Fall at Start of Air Circus| newspaper = The New York Times| location =| pages =| publisher =| date = June 18, 1922| url =https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/06/18/107059083.pdf| accessdate = December 18, 2011}}</ref> The aircraft was assigned to the 7th Photo Section at [[Godman Army Airfield|Godman Field]], [[Fort Knox|Camp Knox]], Kentucky.<ref name="aviationarchaeology.com"/> *May 21 - [[Presidio of San Francisco]] - Stuntman Wesley May was fatally injured during a parachute jump. He misjudged his altitude and released himself from his parachute to avoid hitting a tree. Wesley fell approximately fifty feet and struck a tombstone in a cemetery and died in an army hospital.<ref>{{cite news|title=Daredevil Dies In Fatal Drop|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=MT19220522.2.17&srpos=148&e=--1900---1930--en--20--141--txt-txIN-stunt+plane-------1|accessdate=29 October 2017|work=Madera Tribune|issue=Number 19|date=22 May 1922}}</ref> *February 22 – [[San Jose, California]] – Parachutist Thorton "Jinx" Jenkins was killed when his parachute partially opened during a jump at an air circus.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1982&dat=19220223&id=xhZLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IiENAAAAIBAJ&pg=2694,2609237&hl=en|title = 20.000 Look On As Air Acrobat Falls To Death |date = February 22, 1922 |accessdate = August 30, 2015 |newspaper = The Evening News|page = |pages = 1–2}}</ref> *January 22 – [[Askersund|Askersund, Sweden]] – Parachutist [[Elsa Andersson]] was killed when her parachute failed to open during a jump.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
==1921== *October 4 – [[Long Branch, New Jersey]] – Miss Madeline Davis, a twenty-three-year-old professional stunt flier, was killed while attempting to become the first woman to transfer from a moving automobile to an airplane flying overhead via a rope ladder. She died shortly after losing her grip on the ladder and striking the ground while traveling at approximately forty-five miles per hour.<ref>{{cite news |title=Girl Dies In Stunt Boarding Airplane From Moving Auto |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 5, 1921 |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/10/05/98749441.pdf |accessdate=December 18, 2011}}</ref> *September 24 - State Fairgrounds (Oklahoma City, Oklahoma) - Lieutenant Arthur Emerson was killed while attempting to transfer from one aircraft to another mid-flight.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aviator Meets Death In 'Dare-Devil' Stunt|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SU19210925.2.7&srpos=6&e=--1900---1930--en--20--1--txt-txIN-stunt+plane-------1|accessdate=29 October 2017|issue=25756|publisher=Sacramento Union|date=25 September 1921}}</ref> *September 24- St. Louis Dispatch Flying Circus at [[Bemidji, Minnesota]] - Pilot Edward Fox and passenger John Harris were injured when their plane crashed when it failed to recover while performing a nosedive.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stunt Aviator and Passenger Badly Injured|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86063381/1921-09-24/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1921&sort=relevance&date2=1924&searchType=advanced&language=&sequence=0&index=1&words=circus+Circus+Flying&proxdistance=5&state=&rows=20&ortext=&proxtext=flying+circus&phrasetext=flying+circus&andtext=&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=6|accessdate=28 May 2017|publisher=The Bemidji Daily Pioneer|date=September 24, 1921}}</ref> *June 10 - Huntington Beach, California - One person was killed and eight injured when an airplane that was performing stunts crashed into a group of spectators on the beach.<ref>{{cite news|title=Plane Kills Spectator|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn99065839/1921-06-10/ed-1/seq-7/#date1=1919&index=6&rows=20&words=crash+stunt&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1924&proxtext=stunting+crash&y=15&x=17&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1|accessdate=25 June 2017|publisher=The Morgan County Press|date=10 June 1921}}</ref> *June 5 - Curtiss Field ([[Mineola, New York]]) - Stunt pilot Laura Bromwell was killed after her aircraft went into a tailspin and crashed when her plane's engine quit while performing loop-the-loops.<ref>{{cite news|title=Woman Holder Of The Loop-The-Loop Record Dead In Plane Crash|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84031081/1921-06-06/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1919&index=15&rows=20&words=crashed+stunt&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1924&proxtext=stunting+crash&y=15&x=17&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1|accessdate=25 June 2017|work=Albuquerque Morning Journal|publisher=Associated Press|date=6 June 1921}}</ref> *June 5 - Salisbury Beach, Massachusetts - Parachutist Jack "Daredevil Jack" Murphy drowned after landing in the ocean far from shore during a demonstration with a crowd of thousands watching.<ref>{{cite news|title=Parachute Daredevil Drowns|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1921/06/06/page/1/article/woman-flyer-falls-1-000-ft-to-her-death|accessdate=30 May 2017|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=6 June 1921}}</ref> *May 30 - Wisconsin State Fairgrounds (Milwaukee, Wisconsin) - Sixteen people were injured when a stunt plane crashed while performing a transfer of a person on an airplane to moving automobile via a ladder stunt. The ladder became hooked on the automobiles exhaust pipe and lifted the vehicle's rear end and threw it out of control. The airplane was heading toward the grandstand area when the pilot swung the plane and crashed it into the spectator boxes lining the track area.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sixteen Injured In Plane Crash|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%25206%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Telegram%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Telegram%25201921%2520May%2520-%2520Jun%2520Grayscale%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Telegram%25201921%2520May%2520-%2520Jun%2520Grayscale%2520-%25200511.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffdc653be4%26DocId%3D11866882%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D10%26hits%3D3bd%2B3be%2B3c1%2B4c2%2B4cb%2B4d4%2B4f6%2B544%2Bcb3%2Bcd5%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%25206%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Telegram%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Telegram%25201921%2520May%2520-%2520Jun%2520Grayscale%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Evening%2520Telegram%25201921%2520May%2520-%2520Jun%2520Grayscale%2520-%25200511.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffdc653be4%26DocId%3D11866882%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D10%26hits%3D3bd%2B3be%2B3c1%2B4c2%2B4cb%2B4d4%2B4f6%2B544%2Bcb3%2Bcd5%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=1 June 2017|publisher=The Evening Telegram|date=30 May 1921}}</ref> *May 15 - Grand Island, Nebraska - Stunt Pilot Warren P. Kite was killed following a mid-air collision in which the tail section of his aircraft was severed by an aircraft piloted by J.H. Smith who escaped injury.<ref>{{cite news|title="Stunt" Aviator Is Killed|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=LAH19210516.2.438&srpos=2&e=--1900---1930--en--20--1--txt-txIN-stunt+plane-------1|accessdate=29 October 2017|issue=168|publisher=Los Angeles Herald|date=16 May 1921}}</ref>
==1920== *September 18 - New York State Fair (Syracuse, New York) - Stuntman "Tex" McLauglin was injured when he was struck by the propeller of an aircraft while transferring mid-air from one aircraft to another via a rope ladder. He was able to hold onto the ladder while the aircraft landed and was dragged approximately 100 feet before the aircraft was able to stop.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Barn Stormers|journal=Flying|date=June 1966|page=82|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dUZqgpE35vkC&pg=PA82&lpg=PA82&dq=Tex%22+McLaughlin&source=bl&ots=cp4i-2nY40&sig=27OSQ6qgiVupzFXi5d4bkw7s2Dw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik7PC42ZXXAhUC6iYKHYu3BHwQ6AEINDAC#v=onepage&q=Tex%22%20McLaughlin&f=false|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref> *September 3 - Sonoma County Fair (Santa Rosa, California) - Pilot Leon Ferguson was killed when his plane went into a tailspin while he was performing a stunt in which he hung by his toes off one of the wings of the plane.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pilot's Successor Killed|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/2010270504/1920-09-03/ed-1/seq-6/#date1=1919&index=2&rows=20&words=crashed+stunts&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1924&proxtext=stunting+crash&y=15&x=17&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1|accessdate=25 June 2017|publisher=North Platte Semi-Weekly Tribune|date=3 September 1920}}</ref> *July 5 – Dundalk Flying Field, opened in [[Baltimore, Maryland]] in 1920, is almost immediately renamed [[Logan Field (Baltimore)|Logan Field]] when, on this date, Army Lt. Patrick H. Logan is fatally injured after his [[Nieuport 28]], ''F6506'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accident-report.com/world/namerica/US/MD.html|title=Accident-Report.com - Accident-Report.com - USAAF/USAF Accidents for Maryland|publisher=}}</ref> nicknamed the "Red Devil," of the [[104th Fighter Squadron|104th Observation Squadron]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aviationarchaeology.com/src/1940sB4/1920.htm|title=1920 US Army Air Service Accident Reports|publisher=}}</ref> crashes at the airport's inaugural air show following a stall/spin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.175wg.ang.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123202324 |title=Feature - Logan Field Was Home of First Maryland Flying Unit |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312152137/http://www.175wg.ang.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123202324 |archivedate=March 12, 2012 |df= }}</ref> In response to the tragedy, the airfield is renamed in his honor, with the announcement of the new name being made at the closing ceremonies of the airshow during which he died. *February 2 - Tampa, Florida - Stuntman "Freddie" Owens was injured when his right foot was severed by a propeller while transferring mid-air from one aircraft to another.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stunt Flyer's Foot Cut In Two By Plane|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=LAH19200202.2.931&srpos=21&e=--1900---1930--en--20--21--txt-txIN-stunt+plane-------1|accessdate=29 October 2017|work=Los Angeles Herald|issue=79|date=2 February 1920}}</ref>
==1919==
*August 23 – [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]] – Two crewmen, including aircraft builder Karol Słowik, were killed during a ceremonial public flight in front of Polish chief-of-state Marshal [[Józef Piłsudski]]. The plane, the first aircraft built in a newly-independent Poland, was a copy of a [[Hannover CL.II]] and crashed due to faulty cabling.<ref>Morgała, Andrzej. ''O samolocie inż. Słowika raz jeszcze'' in: "Lotnictwo z szachownicą" nr. 21(1/2007), pp.30–33 {{pl icon}}</ref> *August 15 - [[Baltimore, Maryland]] - While performing aerial stunts at [[Patterson Park]] a military aircraft crash landed through a fence and into a baseball diamond killing three children and injuring a number of others.<ref>{{cite news|title=Skidding Airplane Kills 3|url=http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn83030193/1919-08-15/ed-1/seq-7/#date1=01%2F01%2F1914&sort=relevance&date2=12%2F31%2F1940&searchType=advanced&SearchType=phrase&sequence=0&index=5&words=circus+flying&proxdistance=&to_year=1940&rows=20&ortext=&from_year=1914&proxtext=&phrasetext=flying+circus&andtext=&dateFilterType=range&page=7|accessdate=29 May 2017|publisher=The Evening World|date=15 August 1919}}</ref> *July 17 - [[Americus, Georgia]] - Sergeant Gordon Gates, of the Army Air Services, was killed when his safety belt failed while he was flying inverted during an air circus. His plane continued flying unmanned for a half a mile before finally crashing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Flushing Youth Dies In Fall As He Flies Upside Down|url=http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn83030193/1919-07-18/ed-1/seq-8/#date1=01%2F01%2F1914&sort=relevance&date2=12%2F31%2F1940&searchType=advanced&SearchType=phrase&sequence=0&index=15&words=circus+flying&proxdistance=&to_year=1940&rows=20&ortext=&from_year=1914&proxtext=&phrasetext=flying+circus&andtext=&dateFilterType=range&page=8|accessdate=29 May 2017|publisher=The Evening World|date=18 July 1919}}</ref>
==1915== *October 25 - Panama–Pacific International Exposition (San Francisco, California) - Pilot Charles Niles was injured when he crashed while landing during an exhibition flight.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aviator Breaks Nose In Making Landing|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19151026-01.2.7&srpos=566&e=-------en-20--561--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=26 October 1915}}</ref> *September 22 - Colorado State Fair (Pueblo, Colorado) - Parachutist Eddie Coy was killed when his parachute malfunctioned after he jumped from a balloon at a height of 1,800 feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Coy Falls 1,200 Feet|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=OCT19150923.2.25&srpos=7&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN-aeroplane+crash-------0-#|accessdate=18 June 2017|publisher=The Oak Creek Times|date=23 September 1915}}</ref> *March 14 – [[San Francisco]], [[California]] – Famed aerialist [[Lincoln Beachey]], performing at the [[Panama-Pacific International Exposition]] before a crowd of at least 50,000 onlookers, attempted the first exhibition of inverted flight in a monoplane. Beginning the stunt only 2000 feet above the waters of [[San Francisco Bay]], Beachey pulled sharply on the controls to resume level flight, but the resulting pressure on the wing spars caused them to snap and the plane plunged into the water. Beachey actually survived the crash but drowned as rescuers were unable to extract him for nearly two hours.<ref>{{cite news |title=Beachey Killed in a Taube Drop |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F00E2DC153AE633A25756C1A9659C946496D6CF |work=[[New York Times]] |date= March 15, 1915 |accessdate=October 10, 2016}}</ref>
==1914== *September 16 - State Fairgrounds (Pueblo, Colorado) - Aviator [[Weldon B. Cooke]] was killed when his aircraft stalled and crashed from a height of 2,000 feet during an exhibition flight.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aviator Cooke Meets Death Falls 2,000 Feet|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19140917-01.2.3&srpos=125&e=--1914---1915--en-20--121--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane%22-------2-#|accessdate=21 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=17 September 1914}}</ref>
==1913== *October 7 - [[Hammondsport, New York]] - One spectator was killed and several injured when they were knocked off a roof by the wing of an aircraft piloted by [[Lincoln J. Beachey]]. He escaped injury when he crashed following the accident.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aeroplane Kills Girl|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19131008-01.2.5&srpos=1011&e=-------en-20--1001--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=8 October 1913}}</ref> *October 1 - Randolph County Fairgrounds ([[Elkins, West Virginia]]) - Pilot Irving Conley along with several spectators were injured when his aircraft fell from a height of fifty feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aeroplane Accident|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19131002-01.2.121&srpos=607&e=-------en-20--601--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=2 October 1913}}</ref> *October 1 - Binghamton Industrial Exposition (Binghamton, New York) - Pilot Earl V. Fritts escaped injury when he glided his aircraft to earth following the failure of his propeller and crankshaft while flying at an altitude of 500 feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=His Nerve Saved Him|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19131002-01.2.96&srpos=606&e=-------en-20--601--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=2 October 1913}}</ref> *September 25 - Mesa County Fair (Grand Junction, Colorado) - Pilot H.W.
