Blakely suffered minor injuries when his aircraft crashed following an engine stall while he was flying at a height of 85 feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Junction Birdman Has Narrow Escape When His Machine Falls To Earth|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=MDP19130925-01.2.14&srpos=996&e=-------en-20--981--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|work=Montrose Daily Press|publisher=United Press|date=25 September 1913}}</ref> *September 9 - [[Carmi, Illinois]] - Pilot Tony Jannus escaped injury when he landed his aircraft after the carburetor fell off his engine while flying at an altitude of 900 feet during an exhibition flight.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aviator's Narrow Escape Quick Wit Saved Life|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19130910-01.2.22&srpos=608&e=-------en-20--601--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=10 September 1913}}</ref> *August 6 - Carnival Week (Victoria, British Columbia, Canada) - Pilot Johnny Bryant was killed when his aircraft crashed during an exhibition flight at the water carnival celebrations.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aviator Killed While Giving Exhibition|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=CCL19130811.2.88&srpos=169&e=-------en-20--161--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-|accessdate=20 June 2017|publisher=Carbonate Weekly Chronicle|date=11 August 1913}}</ref> *July 19 - [[Golden Potlatch]] (Seattle, Washington) - Parachutist Francis L. Thayer was killed when his parachute harness broke at a height of 600 feet and he fell into Puget Sound.<ref>{{cite news|title=Parachute Snap Broke|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19130720-01.2.8&srpos=953&e=-------en-20--941--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=20 July 1913}}</ref>
==1912== [[File:Clifford Turpin 1912 Meadows race-track, Fowler-Gage biplane crash.jpg|thumb|Clifford Turpin's Crash May 30, 1912]] *September 20 - Cicero Aviation Field (Chicago, Illinois) - Pilot Howard W. Gill was killed and pilot George Mestach injured when their aircraft were involved in a mid-air collision during a race.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gill Killed In Aeroplane Collision|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=TYL19120920.2.64&srpos=469&e=-------en-20--461--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|publisher=The Yampa Register|date=20 September 1912}}</ref> *September 8 - [[Gray, Haute-Saône|Gray, Haute-Saône, France]] - Four spectators were killed and ten injured when an out of control aircraft crashed into a crowd.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aeroplane Falls To Earth Killing Four Spectators|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19120909-01.2.72&srpos=522&e=-------en-20--521--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=9 September 1912}}</ref> *August 23 - Prowers County Fair (Lamar, Colorado) - Pilot [[George Thompson (aviator)|George Thompson]] was killed when his aircraft struck a tree on takeoff and he was crushed by falling debris.<ref>{{cite news|title=Plunge To Death Made By Aviator|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=SRE19120823-01.2.49&srpos=38&e=-------en-20--21--txt-txIN-%22birdman%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|work=Salida Record|publisher=Western Newspaper Union News Service|date=23 August 1912}}</ref> *July 20 - Columbia Park (Buffalo, New York) - Pilot W. F. Zehler escaped with minor injuries, when he was ejected from his aircraft, after it struck a fence during a failed takeoff attempt before a crowd of 2,000.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aviator Hurled 20 Feet But Escapes; Machine Wrecked|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201912%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201912%2520-%25204252.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffff8bf89a57%26DocId%3D6925653%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3Dc02%2Bc03%2Bc22%2B13e5%2B1458%2B14bf%2B14ef%2B14f2%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201912%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201912%2520-%25204252.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffff8bf89a57%26DocId%3D6925653%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3Dc02%2Bc03%2Bc22%2B13e5%2B1458%2B14bf%2B14ef%2B14f2%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=3 June 2017|publisher=Buffalo Courier|date=21 July 1912}}</ref> *July 1 - Third Annual Boston Aviation Meet ([[Squantum|Squantum, Massachusetts]]) - Pilot [[Harriet Quimby]], the first woman in the United States to receive a pilots license, and her passenger, event organizer William A.P. Willard, were killed when they were ejected from their aircraft when it suddenly pitched forward at an altitutde of 1,000 feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Move Under Way to Check Suicide Stunt Mania That Possesses Aviators|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252016%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Herald%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Herald%25201921%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Herald%25201921%2520-%25207091.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffe64868f9%26DocId%3D1888855%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D16%26hits%3D44%2B420%2B443%2B555%2B959%2B971%2B9cc%2Ba22%2Baf6%2Bb1a%2Bda6%2Bdb0%2Bdc8%2Be1a%2Be69%2Bead%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252016%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Herald%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Herald%25201921%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Herald%25201921%2520-%25207091.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffe64868f9%26DocId%3D1888855%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cindex%2520O%252dG%252dT%26HitCount%3D16%26hits%3D44%2B420%2B443%2B555%2B959%2B971%2B9cc%2Ba22%2Baf6%2Bb1a%2Bda6%2Bdb0%2Bdc8%2Be1a%2Be69%2Bead%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=3 June 2017|publisher=Syracuse Herald|date=16 October 1921}}</ref> *May 30 - Meadows Race Track (Seattle, Washington) - Two spectators were killed and pilot [[J. Clifford Turpin]], along with more than a dozen people, injured when a photographer stepped in front of Turpin's aircraft during his [[takeoff]] run. Turpin swerved to avoid the photographer but his aircraft's wing struck a pole and pivoted the craft into the grandstands.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Glenshaw|first1=Paul|title=Clifford Turpin, King of the Air|journal=Air & Space Magazine|date=February 2016|url=http://www.airspacemag.com/history-of-flight/from-here-to-obscurity-180957778/|accessdate=20 June 2017}}</ref> *May 14 - London, England - Pilot E.V. Fisher and passenger Victor Lewis Mason were killed when their aircraft went out of control. Mason was ejected from the aircraft mid-air and Fisher died in the wrecked craft which had caught fire.<ref>{{cite news|title=Three Victims Of Aeroplane ---American Is One Of Killed|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=MDP19120514-01.2.12&srpos=1046&e=-------en-20--1041--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=21 June 2017|work=Montrose Daily Press|publisher=United Press|date=14 May 1912}}</ref> *January 22 - Third International Aviation Meet ([[Carson, California]]) - Pilot Rutherford Page was killed when he lost control of his aircraft at a height of 150 feet and either jumped or fell from the craft when it was at a height of 60 feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aviator Was Too Daring|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19120123-01.2.14&srpos=88&e=-------en-20--81--txt-txIN-aeroplane+meet-------0-#|accessdate=19 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=23 January 1912}}</ref>
==1911== *October 19, while flying at an exhibition in [[Macon, Georgia]], [[Eugene Burton Ely]] was late pulling out of a dive and crashed. Ely jumped clear of the wrecked aircraft, but his neck was broken, and he died a few minutes later. Spectators picked the wreckage clean looking for souvenirs, including Ely's gloves, tie and cap.<ref>{{cite book|title=Skylark: the life, lies, and inventions of Harry Atwood|page=25}}</ref> *October 11, James Robert Kenney, an exposition visitor, was killed when attempting to pass in front of a biplane. Kinney crossed the path of the plane just an instant before it began to leave the ground; a corner of the elevator struck him under the chin, breaking his neck and killing him almost instantly. Darold Robinson (the pilot) reversed his engines when he saw Kinney turn directly in his path, but it was already too late. Robinson was preparing to give a demonstration and exhibition flights when the tragedy occurred.<ref>{{cite book|title=Joplin Daily Globe: Crosses Path of Air Craft: Neck Broken|date=October 12, 1911|page=1 col 6}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=13378996|title=James Robert Kenney (1845 - 1911) - Find A Grave Memorial|website=www.findagrave.com|access-date=2017-04-24}}</ref> *October 2 - Interstate Fairgrounds (Spokane, Washington) - Pilot [[Cromwell Dixon]], the youngest licensed aviator at the time, was killed after his plane crashed after encountering a [[Vertical draft|downdraft]]. *August 16 - 1911 Chicago International Aviation Meet (Chicago, Illinois) - Pilot Arthur Stone escaped injury when his [[List of aircraft (Q)|Queen Monoplane]] crashed in Lake Michigan. Pilot Howard Gill was not injured when his [[Wright Model R|Baby Wright]] aircraft crashed while landing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Saved From Like Fate|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19110817-01.2.21&srpos=270&e=-------en-20--261--txt-txIN-aeroplane+meet-------0-#|accessdate=19 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=17 August 1911}}</ref> *August 15 - [[1911 Chicago International Aviation Meet]] (Chicago, Illinois) - Two pilots were killed in separate accidents on this day. William R. Badger was killed when his aircraft's wings collapsed while in a dive and pilot St. Croix Johnstone was killed when his aircraft experienced engine failure and crashed into Lake Michigan.<ref>{{cite news|title=Death Took Double Pay|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19110816-01.2.11&srpos=217&e=-------en-20--201--txt-txIN-aeroplane+meet-------0-#|accessdate=19 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=16 August 1911}}</ref> *May 23 - Strassberg, Germany - Aviator Laemmlin was killed when he fell from a height of 200 feet during an aeroplane competition.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aviator Fell To Death|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19110524-01.2.23&srpos=85&e=-------en-20--81--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-|accessdate=19 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=24 May 1911}}</ref> *May 21 - [[1911 Paris to Madrid air race|Paris to Madrid Air Race]] (Paris, France) - The French Minister of War [[Henri Maurice Berteaux]] was killed. Aviation patron [[Henri Deutsch de la Meurthe]], Prime Minister of France [[Ernest Monis]] and Monis's son were injured when an aircraft lost power and crashed into a group of spectators at the start of the race.<ref>{{cite news|title=Monoplane Plows Through Crowd|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83035565/1911-05-25/ed-1/seq-3/#date1=1901&sort=relevance&rows=20&words=accident+aeroplane&searchType=basic&sequence=0&index=8&state=&date2=1911&proxtext=aeroplane+accident&y=8&x=17&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=7|accessdate=25 June 2017|publisher=The Greenville Journal|date=25 May 1911}}</ref> *May 20 - [[Kursk]] - One hundred spectators were injured when an aircraft crashed into a crowd.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hundred Are Injured|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038615/1911-05-22/ed-1/seq-2/#date1=1901&sort=relevance&rows=20&words=accident+aeroplane&searchType=basic&sequence=0&index=2&state=&date2=1911&proxtext=aeroplane+accident&y=8&x=17&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=11|accessdate=25 June 2017|publisher=The Times Dispatch|date=22 May 1911}}</ref> *January 10 - Aviation Field (San Francisco, California) - Pilot [[Hubert Latham]] escaped injury when his [[Antoinette (manufacturer)|Antionette monoplane]] encountered strong winds and crashed into a fence.<ref>{{cite news|title=Young French Birdman Hits Mother Earth Hard|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19110111-01.2.35&srpos=48&e=-------en-20--41--txt-txIN-%22birdman%22-------2-#|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=11 January 1911}}</ref>
==1910== *December 29 - Aviation Field (Los Angeles, California) - Pilot Glen Martin escaped injury when his aircraft was blown into a fence while landing at the end of the meet. He was trying to qualify for his pilots license at the time of the crash.<ref>{{cite news|title=Glenn Martin Loses Control Of Machine And Is Dashed Into A Fence|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19101230.2.15&srpos=20&e=01-01-1900-31-12-1910--en--20--1--txt-txIN-aeroplane+crash-------1|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=The San Francisco Call|date=30 December 1910}}</ref> *November 22 - Register Aviation Meet (Mobile, Alabama) - Pilot J.D.A. McCurdy escaped injury following a crash when his aircraft's wing struck the ground.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aero Wrecked, Birdman Unhurt|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19101123-01.2.35&srpos=11&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN-%22birdman%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=23 November 1910}}</ref> *November 17 - Reno Air Meet (Reno, Nevada) - Pilot Fred Wiseman escaped injury when his plane crashed shortly after takeoff missing the grandstand and crash landing in an irrigation ditch.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wiseman Crashes At The Reno Meet|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19101118.2.28&srpos=8&e=01-01-1900-31-12-1910--en--20--1--txt-txIN-aeroplane+crash-------1|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=The San Francisco Call|date=18 November 1910}}</ref> *November 17 - Denver Aviation Meeting (Denver, Colorado) - Pilot [[Ralph Johnstone]], world's record holder for highest altitude in an aircraft at the time, was killed when his aircraft failed to recover from a dive during an air meet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Plunges 500 Feet To Death|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201910%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201910%2520-%25206984.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffff99276af0%26DocId%3D6912284%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D6%26hits%3D65%2B17e%2B25e%2B712%2Be86%2B1036%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201910%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201910%2520-%25206984.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffff99276af0%26DocId%3D6912284%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D6%26hits%3D65%2B17e%2B25e%2B712%2Be86%2B1036%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=4 June 2017|work=Buffalo Courier|publisher=Associated Press|date=18 November 1910}}</ref> *October 29 - [[Gordon Bennett Trophy (aeroplanes)|Gordon Bennett Trophy Race]] (Belmont, New York) - French pilot [[Alfred Leblanc]] was injured when his aircraft struck a telephone pole and crashed. American pilot [[Walter Brookins]] was injured in a crash shortly after Leblanc's accident.<ref>{{cite news|title=Airship Cuts Telephone Pole When Aviator Loses Control|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=DJT19101029.2.5&srpos=74&e=-------en-20--61--txt-txIN-aeroplane+meet-------0-#|accessdate=18 June 2017|work=The Daily Journal|publisher=Associated Press|date=29 October 1910}}</ref> *October 1 - [[Milan|Milan, Italy]] - British pilot Captain Dickson was killed and a French pilot named Thomas was injured when their aircraft were involved in, what was reported at the time, the first mid-air collision between aircraft.<ref>{{cite news|title=First Crash Of Aeroplanes While In Air|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252014%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Standard%2520Union%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Standard%2520Union%25201910%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Standard%2520Union%25201910%2520-%25201320.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffd9bdf4ac%26DocId%3D4542953%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520U%252dF%252dP%26HitCount%3D2%26hits%3D3b8%2B3b9%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252014%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Standard%2520Union%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Standard%2520Union%25201910%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Standard%2520Union%25201910%2520-%25201320.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffd9bdf4ac%26DocId%3D4542953%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520U%252dF%252dP%26HitCount%3D2%26hits%3D3b8%2B3b9%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|work=The Brooklyn Standard Union|publisher=Associated Press|date=2 October 1910}}</ref> *September 16 - Wisconsin State Fair (Milwaukee, Wisconsin) - Eight spectators were injured when an aircraft piloted by [[Archibald Hoxsey]] swerved and crashed into the crowd.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aeroplane Injures Many|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19100917-01.2.20&srpos=136&e=-------en-20--121--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=19 June 2017|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=17 September 1910}}</ref> *September 10 - California State Fair (Sacramento, California) - Aviator Hamilton was injured when he lost control and crashed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hamilton Injured When Aeroplane Falls|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=DJT19100910.2.7&srpos=774&e=-------en-20--761--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|work=The Daily Journal|publisher=Associated Press|date=10 September 1910}}</ref> *August 10 - Chicago School of Aviation (Chicago, Illinois) - Seven spectators were injured when an aircraft piloted by Frank Bellai fell from a height of 100 feet onto a group of 150 spectators.<ref>{{cite news|title=Falling Plane Hurts Seven|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn95069780/1911-08-10/ed-1/seq-2/#date1=1901&index=0&rows=20&words=accident+aeroplane&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1911&proxtext=aeroplane+accident&y=8&x=17&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=5|accessdate=25 June 2017|publisher=Valentine Democrat|date=10 August 1910}}</ref> *August 10 - Interlaken Aviation Field ([[Interlaken, New Jersey]]) - Pilot [[Walter Brookins]], along with seven spectators, were injured when his aircraft inverted and crashed onto a group of spectators while attempting to land in bad weather.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aviator Brookins Endangers Lives; Injured Himself|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201910%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201910%2520-%25204815.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D44d911b4%26DocId%3D6910115%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3Da9%2Bd8%2B1be%2B1ff%2B2f1%2B316%2B33d%2B13ff%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%252021%2FBuffalo%2520NY%2520Courier%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201910%2FBuffalo%2520Ny%2520Courier%25201910%2520-%25204815.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D44d911b4%26DocId%3D6910115%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3Da9%2Bd8%2B1be%2B1ff%2B2f1%2B316%2B33d%2B13ff%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=Buffalo Courier|date=11 August 1910}}</ref> *July 12 – Hengistbury Airfield<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hengistbury-head.co.uk/history20.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920111139/http://www.hengistbury-head.co.uk/history20.htm |archivedate=September 20, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> [[Bournemouth]], United Kingdom – At the age of 32, [[Charles Rolls|Charles Stewart Rolls]] was killed when the tail of his [[Wright Flyer]] broke off during a flying display. Together with [[Henry Royce|Frederick Henry Royce]] he had co-founded the [[Rolls-Royce Limited|Rolls-Royce]] car manufacturing firm. He was the first Briton to be killed in an aeronautical accident, and the twelfth internationally. A [[Statue of Charles Rolls, Monmouth|statue in his memory]], in which he is seen holding an incomplete biplane model, was erected in Agincourt Square, [[Monmouth]]. Following the crash of Rolls, another aviator named Audumar was seriously injured when his aircraft crashed at the same show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rich Aeronaut Dives To Death|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88086023/1910-07-12/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1901&index=0&rows=20&words=Aeroplane+Crash&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1910&proxtext=aeroplane+crash&y=19&x=15&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1|accessdate=24 June 2017|publisher=East Oregonian|date=12 July 1910}}</ref> *July 9 - Coventry, England - Parachutist Viola Spencer was killed when her parachute failed to open properly during an exhibition jump.<ref>{{cite news|title=Airship Plunges Two More To Their Graves|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%25201910.pdf%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%25201910%2520-%25202364.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D7fb4b524%26DocId%3D11053172%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D6%26hits%3D24%2Be4%2B562%2B748%2B74d%2B7c8%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspapers%2520Disk3%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%25201910.pdf%2FSyracuse%2520NY%2520Daily%2520Journal%25201910%2520-%25202364.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D7fb4b524%26DocId%3D11053172%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D6%26hits%3D24%2Be4%2B562%2B748%2B74d%2B7c8%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=4 June 2017|work=Syracuse Journal|publisher=Reuters|date=15 July 1910}}</ref> *July 8 - [[Reims|Reims, France]] - Pilot [[Raymonde de Laroche]] was injured when she crashed after the engine of her aircraft stopped while she was flying at an altitude of approximately 240 feet. She was performing an exhibition flight in front of thousands of spectators at the time of the accident.<ref>{{cite news|title=Woman Air Pilot Plunges 240 Feet|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201910%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201910%2520-%25202812.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D704af3f0%26DocId%3D2628934%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D6%26hits%3Da4%2B125%2B3c4%2B86a%2Bba8%2B1130%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201910%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201910%2520-%25202812.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D704af3f0%26DocId%3D2628934%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D6%26hits%3Da4%2B125%2B3c4%2B86a%2Bba8%2B1130%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=The New York Press|date=9 July 1910}}</ref> *July 6 - Pittsburg,Kansas - Pilot Arch Hoxsey escaped injury when his aircraft crashed following an engine failure at 500 feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aviator's Machine Wrecked|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn90061308/1910-07-08/ed-1/seq-4/#date1=1901&sort=relevance&rows=20&words=aeroplane+crashed&searchType=basic&sequence=0&index=16&state=&date2=1910&proxtext=aeroplane+crash&y=19&x=15&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=4|accessdate=24 June 2017|publisher=The Monett Times|date=8 July 1910}}</ref> *July 2 - Emeryville Racetrack (Oakland, California) - Pilot Samuel Smith was injured when his aircraft crash landed on top of an aircraft piloted by Clifford O'Brien that had just crashed. O'Brien wasn't injured in the accident<ref>{{cite news|title=Aeroplanes Crash In Air|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1910-07-03/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1901&sort=relevance&rows=20&words=AEROPLANES+aeroplanes+crash+CRASH&searchType=basic&sequence=0&index=12&state=&date2=1910&proxtext=aeroplane+crash&y=19&x=15&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=3|accessdate=24 June 2017|publisher=The Washington Herald|date=3 July 1910}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Peculiar Accident At Emeryville|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058398/1910-07-02/ed-1/seq-4/#date1=1901&sort=relevance&rows=20&words=aeroplane+crashed&searchType=basic&sequence=0&index=18&state=&date2=1910&proxtext=aeroplane+crash&y=19&x=15&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=3|accessdate=24 June 2017|publisher=The Ogden Standard|date=2 July 1910}}</ref> *June 13 - Springfield, Missouri - Pilot Charles F. Willard was injured when his aircraft's engine stopped while flying at a height of 50 feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aeroplane Fell With A Crash|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025182/1910-06-13/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1901&index=9&rows=20&words=AEROPLANE+CRASH&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1910&proxtext=aeroplane+crash&y=19&x=15&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1|accessdate=24 June 2017|publisher=The Daily Gate City|date=13 June 1910}}</ref> *June 9 - [[Worcester|Worcester, England]] - While attempting an exhibition at an agricultural show an aviator lost control of his aircraft and crashed into a crowd of spectators killing one and injuring himself and several others.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aviator Swoops Down On Crowd; Kills Two|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=LAH19100610.2.13&srpos=14&e=01-01-1900-31-12-1910--en--20--1--txt-txIN-aeroplane+crash-------1|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=Los Angeles Herald|date=10 June 1910}}</ref> *May 1 - Fairgrounds (Fresno, California - Pilot Whipple S. Hall was injured when he lost control of his aircraft and crashed into a fence while giving an exhibition flight.<ref>{{cite news|title=Judge Hall's Son Hurt In Aeroplane Accident|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042462/1910-05-02/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1901&sort=relevance&rows=20&words=ACCIDENT+AEROPLANE&searchType=basic&sequence=0&index=13&state=&date2=1911&proxtext=aeroplane+accident&y=8&x=17&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=10|accessdate=25 June 2017|publisher=Los Angeles Herald|date=2 May 1910}}</ref> *April 26 - [[Issy-les-Moulineaux|Issy-les-Moulineaux, Paris, France]] - Pilot [[Émile Dubonnet]] escaped injury when his aircraft crashed in heavy winds while performing a demonstration flight for former president [[Theodore Roosevelt]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Nearly Breaks Neck In Honor Of Roosevelt|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84024827/1910-04-27/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1901&index=4&rows=20&words=AEROPLANE+CRASH&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1910&proxtext=aeroplane+crash&y=19&x=15&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1|work=Brisbee Daily Review|publisher=Associated Press|date=27 April 1910}}</ref> *February 4 - Denver, Colorado - Pilot [[Louis Paulhan]] escaped injury when his aircraft crashed into a fence during a demonstration flight.<ref>{{cite news|title=Paulhan Has A Narrow Escape From Death|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1910-02-04/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1901&index=3&rows=20&words=Aeroplane+Crashes&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1910&proxtext=aeroplane+crash&y=19&x=15&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=2|accessdate=24 June 2017|publisher=The Hawaiian Gazette|date=4 February 1910}}</ref>
==1909== *October 18 - [[Juvisy-sur-Orge|Juvisy-sur-Orge, France]] - One spectator was killed and a dozen injured when an aircraft piloted Alfred Leblanc lost control and crashed into the grandstands during an airshow.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aeroplane Crashed Into Grandstand|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84020630/1909-10-18/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1901&index=11&rows=20&words=AEROPLANE+CRASHED&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1910&proxtext=aeroplane+crash&y=19&x=15&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=2|accessdate=24 June 2017|publisher=Santa Fe New Mexican|date=18 October 1909}}</ref> *September 9 - Gray, Haute-Saône, France - Five spectators were killed and two injured when an aircraft suddenly dropped into a crowd while flying over.<ref>{{cite news|title=Auto Skids Into Crowd And Five Persons Killed|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=MDP19120909-01.2.11&srpos=598&e=-------en-20--581--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|accessdate=20 June 2017|work=The Montrose Daily Press|publisher=United Press|date=9 September 1912}}</ref> *June 15 - [[Berwyn, Nebraska]] - Blacksmith and airplane builder Ulysses Sorenson escaped injury when his personally designed aircraft crashed on its test flight. Sorenson had the craft lifted to a height of 3,500 feet via a hot air balloon, before a crowd that had gathered, and when released the craft entered into what may have been a [[Spin (aerodynamics)|flat spin]] until it crashed to the ground.<ref>{{cite news|title=Man Falls 3,500 Feet; Is Unhurt|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201909%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201909%2520-%25202246.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D56463980%26DocId%3D2623355%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D13%26hits%3D1bc%2B264%2B4f7%2B509%2B60f%2B67c%2Bd6a%2Bd80%2Bdba%2Be06%2Be75%2Bec3%2Becf%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201909%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201909%2520-%25202246.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3D56463980%26DocId%3D2623355%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D13%26hits%3D1bc%2B264%2B4f7%2B509%2B60f%2B67c%2Bd6a%2Bd80%2Bdba%2Be06%2Be75%2Bec3%2Becf%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=The New York Press|date=16 June 1909}}</ref> *May 31 - Brownsville, Texas - Pilot Newman escaped injury when his aircraft went out of control and crashed while being towed on its maiden voyage.<ref>{{cite news|title=Accident Marred Flight Of Airship|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86099906/1909-05-31/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1901&index=13&rows=20&words=aeroplane+crashing&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1910&proxtext=aeroplane+crash&y=19&x=15&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=2|publisher=The Brownsville Herald|date=31 May 1909}}</ref>
==1908== *September 17 [[London, England]] - Pilot Orville Wright was injured and passenger Lieutenant Thomas Selfridge was killed when a propeller shattered causing their aircraft to crash from an approximate height of 75 feet in front of a crowd of two thousand.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fatal Aeroplane Accident|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/61555892?searchTerm=aeroplane+fatal|accessdate=6 June 2017|publisher=The Clarence and Richmond Examiner|date=22 September 1908}}</ref> *August 13 - [[Le Mans|Le Mans, France]] - Pilot Wilbur Wright escaped injury when his aircraft crashed while attempting a [[Deadstick landing|power off, glide landing]] from a height of fifty feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wright's Aeroplane Meets With Accident|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045830/1908-08-14/ed-1/seq-1/#words=aeroplane+meet+Aeroplane+meet|accessdate=6 June 2017|work=The Daily Press|publisher=Associated Press|date=14 August 1908}}</ref> *May 2 - [[Issy-les-Moulineaux]], France - Pilot M. De Lagrange was uninjured when his aircraft swerved, missed a crowd of spectators, and crashed into an automobile.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aeroplane Skims Ground Crowd Narrowly Escapes|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19080503-01.2.32.2&srpos=143&e=-------en-20--141--txt-txIN-aeroplane+meet-------0-#|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=3 May 1908}}</ref>
==1906== *April 14 - Jacksonville, Florida - Pilot and aircraft builder Israel Ludlow was severely injured when his bamboo frame glider, that was being towed aloft by two automobiles, suffered structural failure at an approximate height of 200 feet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aeronaut Falls 200 Feet|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1906-04-15/ed-1/seq-1/#words=aeroplane+crash+Aeroplane+crash|accessdate=5 June 2017|publisher=The Sun|date=15 April 1906}}</ref>
==1905== *October 22 - Hudson River ([[Manhattan, New York]]) - Pilot and airplane builder Israel Ludlow escaped injury when his experimental glider aircraft crashed from a height of 400 feet into the Hudson River with thousands of spectators lining the riverbank. At the time the aircraft lacked an engine or steering and was being towed aloft by a tugboat which had stopped causing the aircraft to crash.<ref>{{cite news|title=400 Feet In The Air, He Falls To River|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201905%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201905%2520-%25204093.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffef449733%26DocId%3D2604322%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3D68%2B540%2B576%2B9a5%2Ba50%2Bcd2%2B1366%2B1659%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201905%2FNew%2520York%2520NY%2520Press%25201905%2520-%25204093.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffef449733%26DocId%3D2604322%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D8%26hits%3D68%2B540%2B576%2B9a5%2Ba50%2Bcd2%2B1366%2B1659%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=The New York Press|date=23 October 1905}}</ref> *July 18 - [[Santa Clara University]] (Santa Clara, California) - Pilot Daniel Maloney was killed when his aircraft, named the "Santa Clara", suffered structural collapse while at a height of approximately 2,000 feet while a crowd of thousands watched.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aeronaut Maloney Drops Half A Mile|url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FPaterson%2520NJ%2520Morning%2520Call%2FPaterson%2520NJ%2520%2520Morning%2520Call%25201905%2520Jun-Sep%2FPaterson%2520NJ%2520%2520Morning%2520Call%25201905%2520Jun-Sep%2520-%25200273.pdf%23xml%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffc8b58b93%26DocId%3D5178735%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D14%26hits%3Db44%2Bb4f%2Bd7f%2Bd9b%2Bdac%2Bdbc%2Bde6%2Be4b%2Be75%2Beac%2Bee4%2Bf3d%2Bf6a%2Bf9b%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&uri=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252018%2FPaterson%2520NJ%2520Morning%2520Call%2FPaterson%2520NJ%2520%2520Morning%2520Call%25201905%2520Jun-Sep%2FPaterson%2520NJ%2520%2520Morning%2520Call%25201905%2520Jun-Sep%2520-%25200273.pdf&xml=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FdtSearch%2Fdtisapi6.dll%3Fcmd%3Dgetpdfhits%26u%3Dffffffffc8b58b93%26DocId%3D5178735%26Index%3DZ%253a%255cIndex%2520I%252dE%252dV%26HitCount%3D14%26hits%3Db44%2Bb4f%2Bd7f%2Bd9b%2Bdac%2Bdbc%2Bde6%2Be4b%2Be75%2Beac%2Bee4%2Bf3d%2Bf6a%2Bf9b%2B%26SearchForm%3D%252fFulton%255fNew%255fform%252ehtml%26.pdf&openFirstHlPage=false|accessdate=4 June 2017|publisher=The Morning Call|date=19 July 1905}}</ref>
==1904== *October 26 - [[Louisiana Purchase Exposition|St. Louis World's Fair]] (St. Louis, Missouri) - Pilot William Avery suffered minor injuries when his aircraft crash landed following a mechanical failure.<ref>{{cite news|title=This Is Airship Week At The World's Fair|url=https://www.coloradohistoricnewspapers.org/cgi-bin/colorado?a=d&d=THD19041027-01.2.60&srpos=570&e=-------en-20--561--txt-txIN-%22aeroplane+%22-------2-#|publisher=The Herald Democrat|date=27 October 1904}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of air show accidents and incidents in the 21st century]] *[[List of accidents and incidents involving commercial aircraft]] *[[List of air shows]] *[[List of news aircraft accidents and incidents]] *[[Lists of accidents and incidents involving military aircraft]]

page.title: List of armed conflicts involving Poland against Russia

revision.text:
{{Polish-Russian Wars}} [[Armed conflicts]] between '''[[Poland]]''' (including the [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]]) and '''[[Russia]]''' (including the [[Soviet Union]]) include: {|class="wikitable" width="100%" ! {{flag|Holy Roman Empire}} *{{flag|Habsburg Monarchy|name=Austria}} *{{flagcountry|Electorate of Saxony}} *{{flag|Prussia|1701}} |Victory for forces (including Russia) supporting [[Augustus III of Poland]] |- |April 1768 – August 5, 1772 |[[War of the Bar Confederation]] |{{flagicon image|Herb Rzeczypospolitej Obojga Narodow.svg|size=24px|border=no}} Bar Confederation{{-}}{{flagcountry|Kingdom of France}} |{{flag|Russian Empire}} |Russian victory *[[First Partition of Poland]] |- |18 May – 27 July 1792 |[[Polish–Russian War of 1792]] |{{flagicon image|Herb Rzeczypospolitej Obojga Narodow.svg|size=24px|border=no}} [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] |{{flag|Russian Empire}} |Russian victory *[[Second Partition of Poland]] |- |24 March – 30 November 1794 |[[Kościuszko Uprising]] |{{flagicon image|Herb Rzeczypospolitej Obojga Narodow.svg|size=24px|border=no}} [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] |{{flag|Russian Empire}}{{-}}{{flag|Kingdom of Prussia|1750}}{{-}}{{flag|Habsburg Monarchy}} |Russian victory *[[Third Partition of Poland]] |- |29 November 1830 – 21 October 1831 |[[November Uprising]] |{{flagicon|POL}} [[Congress Poland]] |{{flag|Russian Empire}} |Russian government victory |- |22 January 1863 – 18 June 1864 |[[January Uprising]] |{{flagicon image|Flag of the Polish-Lithuanian-Ruthenian Commonwealth (January Uprising).svg}} [[Polish National Government (January Uprising)|Polish National Government]]
and multicultural insurgents
[[Garibaldi Legion]] |{{flag|Russian Empire|1858}} |Russian government victory |- |1905–1907 |[[Revolution in the Kingdom of Poland (1905–1907)]]{{note label|reference_name_A|a|2}} |{{flagicon image|Red flag.svg}} Polish revolutionaries |{{flag|Russian Empire}} |Russian government victory |- |18 November 1918 – February 1919 |[[Soviet westward offensive of 1918–19]] |{{flagcountry|Second Polish Republic}}{{-}}{{flagcountry|Ukrainian People's Republic}}{{-}}{{flagcountry|Belarusian People's Republic|name=Belarus}}{{-}}{{flagcountry|Estonia}}{{-}}{{flagcountry|Latvia}}{{-}}{{flagcountry|Lithuania}}{{-}}{{flagcountry|Kingdom of Romania}}{{-}}{{flagdeco|Russia}} [[White Movement]]{{-}}{{flagicon|German Empire}} [[Ober Ost]]{{-}}''Supported by''{{-}}{{flag|United Kingdom}} |{{flag|Russian SFSR|1918}} |Polish victory *Start of the [[Polish-Soviet War]] |- |14 February 1919 – 18 March 1921 |[[Polish-Soviet War]] |{{flagcountry|Second Polish Republic}}{{-}}{{flagcountry|Ukrainian People's Republic}}{{-}}{{flag|Latvia}} |{{flag|Russian SFSR|1918}}{{-}}{{flag|Ukrainian SSR|1927}} |Polish victory *[[Peace of Riga]] |- |17 September – 6 October 1939 |[[Soviet invasion of Poland]] |{{flagcountry|Second Polish Republic|1928}} |{{flag|Soviet Union|1936}}
{{flagcountry|Nazi Germany}} |Soviet victory |} {{note label|reference_name_A|a|1}} Originally a Polish [[civil war]] that Russia, among others, became involved in.

page.title: List of wedding guests of Prince William and Catherine Middleton

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Use British English|date=March 2015}}
The following is the '''guest list''' for the '''[[wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton]]'''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Another Royal Couple to Attend the British Royal Wedding|url=http://royalcorrespondent.com/page/4|date=27 March 2011|accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref>
==Relatives of the groom==
===[[House of Windsor]]=== * [[Elizabeth II|The Queen]] and [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|The Duke of Edinburgh]],<ref name="LIFE weddinglist">{{cite news|url=http://www.life.com/gallery/57371/image/80903641#index/0|title=Royal Wedding: Who's Invited?|work=[[Life (magazine)|LIFE magazine]]|publisher=[[Time Inc]]|year=2011}}</ref> ''the groom's grandparents'' ** [[Charles, Prince of Wales|The Prince of Wales]] and [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall|The Duchess of Cornwall]],<ref name="LIFE weddinglist" /> ''the groom's father and stepmother'' *** [[Prince Harry|Prince Henry of Wales]],<ref name="LIFE weddinglist" /> ''the groom's brother'' ** [[Anne, Princess Royal|The Princess Royal]] and [[Timothy Laurence|Vice Admiral Sir Timothy Laurence]],<ref name="Timings">{{cite web|url=http://www.officialroyalwedding2011.org/blog/2011/April/15/The-Wedding-of-HRH-Prince-William-of-Wales-and-Miss-Catherine-Middleton--An-update |title=Ceremonial Timings |work=The Royal Wedding: Prince William & Catherine Middleton |publisher=[[Clarence House]] |date=15 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110418022419/http://www.officialroyalwedding2011.org/blog/2011/April/15/The-Wedding-of-HRH-Prince-William-of-Wales-and-Miss-Catherine-Middleton--An-update |archivedate=18 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> ''the groom's aunt and uncle'' *** [[Peter Phillips|Peter]] and [[Autumn Phillips]],<ref name="Telegraph weddinglist 1">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/royal-wedding/8435045/Royal-wedding-Prince-William-and-Kate-Middletons-circle-of-friends.html|title=Royal wedding: Prince William and Kate Middleton's circle of friends|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group Limited]] |date=13 April 2011|location=London}}</ref> ''the groom's first cousin and his wife'' *** [[Zara Phillips]] and [[Mike Tindall]],<ref name="Telegraph weddinglist 1" /> ''the groom's first cousin and her fiancé'' ** [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York|The Duke of York]],<ref name="About weddinglist">{{cite news|url=http://gouk.about.com/od/royalty/ss/Royal-Wedding-Whos-Who_2.htm|title=Royal Wedding Who's Who|work=[[About.com]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|year=2011|last=Arfin|first=Ferne}}</ref> ''the groom's uncle'' *** [[Princess Beatrice of York]],<ref name="About weddinglist" /><ref name="Time weddinglist">{{cite news|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/02/21/snubbed-sarah-ferguson-not-invited-to-the-royal-wedding|title=Snubbed: Sarah Ferguson Not Invited to the Royal Wedding|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time magazine]]|publisher=Time Inc|date=21 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="theroyalweddingwilliamkate weddinglist">{{cite web|url=http://www.theroyalweddingwilliamkate.com/the-royal-wedding-invitations-issued-guest-lists-revealed |title=The Royal Wedding Invitations Issued |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110413204310/http://www.theroyalweddingwilliamkate.com/the-royal-wedding-invitations-issued-guest-lists-revealed |archivedate=13 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> ''the groom's first cousin'' *** [[Princess Eugenie of York]],<ref name="About weddinglist" /><ref name="Time weddinglist" /> ''the groom's first cousin'' ** [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex|The Earl]] and [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex|Countess of Wessex]],<ref name="Timings" /> ''the groom's uncle and aunt'' *** [[Lady Louise Windsor|The Lady Louise Mountbatten-Windsor]], ''the groom's first cousin'' *** [[James, Viscount Severn|Viscount Severn]], ''the groom's first cousin''
*''[[Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon|The Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon]]'s family:'' ** [[David Armstrong-Jones, Viscount Linley|Viscount]] and [[Serena Armstrong-Jones, Viscountess Linley|Viscountess Linley]],<ref name="BBC guestlist">{{cite news|title=Royal wedding guest list|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-13175842|work=[[BBC News Online]]|publisher=BBC|date=23 April 2011|accessdate=23 April 2011}}</ref> ''the groom's first cousin, once removed and his wife'' *** ''The Honourable'' [[Charles Armstrong-Jones]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's second cousin'' *** ''The Honourable'' [[Margarita Armstrong-Jones]], ''the groom's second cousin'' ** [[Lady Sarah Chatto|The Lady Sarah]] and [[Daniel Chatto]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's first cousin, once removed and her husband'' *** Samuel Chatto,<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's second cousin'' *** Arthur Chatto,<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's second cousin''
Other descendants of the Prince's great-great-grandfather King [[George V]] and their families: * [[Prince Richard, Duke of Gloucester|The Duke]] and [[Birgitte, Duchess of Gloucester|Duchess of Gloucester]],<ref name="Female First weddinglist 1">{{cite web|url=http://www.femalefirst.co.uk/royal_family/Queen+Elizabeth-54455.html|title=Queen Elizabeth to host dinner for visiting Lewis,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10720673|title='Denny and Gazza' on guest list for royal wedding|last=Erickson|first=Alanah|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]|date=21 April 2011}}</ref> ''the groom's second cousin, once removed and her husband'' ** Lady Rose and George Gilman,<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's second cousin, once removed and her husband'' * [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent|The Duke]] and [[Katharine, Duchess of Kent|Duchess of Kent]],<ref name="Female First weddinglist 1" /> ''the groom's first cousin, twice removed and his wife'' ** [[George Windsor, Earl of St Andrews|Earl]] and [[Sylvana Windsor, Countess of St Andrews|Countess of St Andrews]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's second cousin, once removed and his wife'' *** [[Edward Windsor, Lord Downpatrick|Lord Downpatrick]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's third cousin'' *** [[Lady Marina-Charlotte Windsor]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's third cousin'' *** [[Lady Amelia Windsor]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's third cousin'' ** [[Lady Helen Taylor|The Lady Helen]] and Timothy Taylor,<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's second cousin, once removed and her husband'' ** [[Lord Nicholas Windsor|The Lord]] and [[Lady Nicholas Windsor]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's second cousin, once removed and his wife'' * [[Princess Alexandra, The Honourable Lady Ogilvy]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's godmother and first cousin, twice removed'' ** [[James Ogilvy|James]] and [[Julia Ogilvy]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's second cousin, once removed and his wife'' ** Marina Ogilvy,<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's second cousin, once removed'' * [[Prince Michael of Kent|Prince]] and [[Princess Michael of Kent]],<ref name="Female First weddinglist 1" /> ''the groom's first cousin, twice removed and his wife'' ** [[Lord Frederick Windsor|The Lord]] and [[Sophie Winkleman|Lady Frederick Windsor]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's second cousin, once removed and his wife'' ** [[The Lady Gabriella Windsor]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the groom's second cousin, once removed''
===Other descendants of Queen Victoria=== Other descendants of the prince's great-great-great-great-grandmother [[Queen Victoria]] and their families. As is common in royalty, there has been slight intermingling of families. Where possible, the closest family title has been noted (first cousin on grandfather's side, instead of third cousin on grandmother's side, etc.): * {{flagicon|Denmark}} [[Margrethe II of Denmark|The Queen of Denmark]],<ref name="Kongehuset Calender">[http://kongehuset.dk/aktuelt/kalender/ Aktuel Kalender Kongehuset] - website Kongehuset {{da icon}}</ref> ''the groom's third cousin, twice removed'' * {{flagicon|Sweden}} [[Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden|The Crown Princess of Sweden]] and [[Prince Daniel, Duke of Västergötland|The Duke of Västergötland]],<ref name="Female First weddinglist 2" /><ref name="Aftenposten weddinglist" /> ''the groom's fourth cousin once, removed and her husband'' * {{flagicon|Norway}} [[Harald V of Norway|The King]] and [[Queen Sonja of Norway|Queen of Norway]]<ref name="Female First weddinglist 2" /><ref name="Aftenposten weddinglist">[http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/kongelige/article4084305.ece Monarkfest før bryllupet i London] groom's second cousin twice, removed and his wife'' * {{flagicon|Spain}} [[Queen Sofía of Spain|The Queen of Spain]]<ref name="Spain">[http://www.typicallyspanish.com/news/publish/article_29998.shtml Queen Sofia, Letizia and Felipe to attend the British Royal Wedding] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110411053911/http://www.typicallyspanish.com/news/publish/article_29998.shtml |date=11 April 2011 }} - website typicallyspanish.com</ref> ''the groom's second cousin, once removed'' ** {{flagicon|Spain}} [[Felipe, Prince of Asturias|The Prince]] and [[Letizia, Princess of Asturias|Princess of Asturias]]<ref name="Female First weddinglist 2" /> ''the groom's third cousin and his wife'' * {{flagicon|Baden}} [[Maximilian, Margrave of Baden|The Margrave]] and [[Archduchess /> and Mr Max Soltmann, ''the groom's second cousin, once removed'' * [[Flora Fraser, 21st Lady Saltoun|The Lady Saltoun]],<ref name="BBC guestlist" /> ''the widow of the groom's, second cousin, thrice removed'' * [[Patricia Knatchbull, 2nd Countess Mountbatten of Burma|The Countess Mountbatten of Burma]],<ref name="Message Board">[http://members3.boardhost.com/Oranjes/msg/1304936400.html Glittering Royal Events Message Board wedding coverage including mention of the Countess Mountbatten of Burma] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512224340/http://members3.boardhost.com/Oranjes/msg/1304936400.html |date=12 May 2011 }}</ref> ''the groom's first cousin, twice removed'' ** [[Norton {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110509080442/http://www.tribune242.com/news/05062011_Indiaroyalwedding_news_pg6 |date=9 May 2011 }}</ref> ''the groom's first cousin, twice removed on''
===Bowes-Lyon Family=== * [[Margaret Rhodes]], ''the groom's first cousin, twice removed''
===Spencer family=== *[[Lady Sarah McCorquodale]] and Neil McCorquodale,<ref name="Seating Plan">{{cite web|title=Seating plan for Westminster Abbey confirmed |url=http://www.officialroyalwedding2011.org/blog/2011/April/23/Seating-plan-for-Westminster-Abbey-confirmed |accessdate=30 April 2011 |date=23 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110427021749/http://www.officialroyalwedding2011.org/blog/2011/April/23/Seating-plan-for-Westminster-Abbey-confirmed |archivedate=27 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> ''the groom's aunt and uncle'' ** Emily McCorquodale, ''the groom's first cousin'' ** George McCorquodale, ''the groom's first cousin'' ** Celia McCorquodale, ''the groom's first cousin'' * [[Jane Fellowes, Baroness Fellowes|The Lady]] and [[Robert Fellowes, Baron Fellowes|Lord Fellowes]],<ref name="Seating Plan" /> ''the groom's aunt and uncle'' ** Laura Pettman, ''the groom's first cousin'' ** Alexander Fellowes, ''the groom's first cousin'' ** Eleanor Fellowes, ''the groom's first cousin'' *[[Charles Spencer, 9th Earl Spencer|The Earl Spencer]] and [[Karen Spencer, Countess Spencer|Karen Gordon]],<ref name="Seating Plan" /> ''the groom's uncle and his fiancée'' **[[Lady Kitty Spencer|The Lady Kitty Spencer]], ''the groom's first cousin'' **The Lady Eliza Spencer, ''the groom's first cousin'' **The Lady Amelia Spencer, ''the groom's first cousin'' **[[Louis Spencer, Viscount Althorp|Viscount Althorp]], ''the groom's first cousin'' *The Lady Anne Wake-Walker,<ref name="Seating Plan" /> ''the groom's great-aunt'' * [[Maurice Roche, 6th Baron Fermoy|The Lord]] and Lady Fermoy, ''the groom's first cousin, once removed and his wife''
==Relatives of the bride== :{{See also|Family of Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge}} *[[Family of Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge#Parents|Michael]] and [[Carole Middleton]],<ref name="LIFE weddinglist" /> ''the bride's parents'' **[[Pippa Middleton]]<ref name="LIFE weddinglist" /> and Mr [[Alex Loudon]],<ref name="ABC weddinglist">{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/Royal_Diary_Blog/official-royal-wedding-guest-list-revealed/story?id=13343147|title=Royal Wedding Guest List Revealed|last=Taylor|first=Cait|work=[[ABC News (US)|ABC News]]|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]]|date=10 April 2011}}</ref> ''the bride's sister and her guest'' ** James Middleton,<ref name="LIFE weddinglist" /> ''the bride's brother'' * Gary and Luan Goldsmith,<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist">{{cite news|url=http://www.emirates247.com/entertainment/the-royal-wedding-guest-list-2011-04-10-1.379135|title=The Royal Wedding guest list|work=[[Emirates 24/7]]|publisher=[[Dubai Media Incorporated]]|date=10 April 2011}}</ref> ''the bride's uncle and his ex-wife'' ** Tallulah Goldsmith,<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> ''the bride's first cousin'' * Richard Middleton,<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> ''the bride's uncle'' ** Adam Middleton,<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> ''the bride's first cousin'' * Simon Middleton,<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> ''the bride's uncle'' * Nicholas Middleton,<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> ''the bride's uncle'' ** Anne Gabriella Middleton,<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> ''the bride's first cousin'' ** Lucy Middleton,<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> ''the bride's first cousin'' * Matita Glassborow<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> ''the bride's first cousin, once removed''; great great-niece of [[Ellen Terry|Dame Ellen Terry]]<ref>{{cite web |last1=Joseph |first1=C. |title=Kate - The Making of a Princess |url=https://epdf.tips/kate-the-making-of-a-princess.html |publisher=Harper Collins 2011 |accessdate=23 September 2018 |quote=Ann Terry, who is the couple's great-niece – the niece of Dorothy's husband ...... Dame Ellen Terry's nephew, Dennis Neilson-Terry....(grandfather) of Maurice and Monica's daughter Matita Glassborow at Chapel Allerton Nursing Home on 12 ... Dame Ellen was the sister of (Sir John) Gielgud's grandmother Kate and Monica's...}}</ref> * Dr Penny Barton,<ref>{{cite web|title=Kate Middleton And Prince William ‘Humbled’ By Visit To Cambridge University|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/11/28/kate-middleton-prince-william-humbled-cambridge-university_n_2204853.html|publisher=Huffington Post - 28 November 2012|accessdate=25 October 2016|quote=Kate met a relative during the reception - Dr Penny Barton, a graduate tutor at Homerton College, who is her father Michael Middleton’s first cousin and attended the royal wedding.}}</ref> ''the bride's first cousin, once removed'' * David Middleton<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> * Elizabeth Middleton<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> * Timothy Middleton<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> * John Middleton<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> * Jean Harrison<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" /> * [[Lupton family|Stephen Lupton]]<ref name="Emirates 24/7 Guestlist" />

Toulousain|Toulouse]] the day after the wedding.<ref name=spi/><ref name=BOD/> * {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[Edward Fitzalan-Howard, 18th Duke of Norfolk|The Duke]] and [[Georgina Fitzalan-Howard, Duchess of Norfolk|Duchess of Norfolk]] – declined due to the announcement of their separation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Duke of Norfolk and wife separate|author=[[Press Association]]|url=http://www.bearsdenherald.co.uk/news/duke_of_norfolk_and_wife_separate_1_1577890|newspaper=Bearsden Herald|date=15 April 2011|accessdate=17 April 2011}}</ref>
==Invitation withdrawn== * {{flagicon|Syria}} [[Sami Khiyami]] (Syrian ambassador to the United Kingdom)<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/royal-wedding/8482347/Royal-wedding-Syrian-ambassador-embarrassed-at-being-disinvited.html|title=Royal wedding: Syrian ambassador embarrassed at being disinvited|last=Kirkup|first=James|date=28 April 2011|accessdate=29 April 2011|newspaper=The Telegraph|publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited|location=London}}</ref>

{{Prince William, Duke of Cambridge}} {{Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Wedding Guests Of Prince William, Duke Of Cambridge, and Kate Middleton}} [[Category:Royal weddings]] [[Category:2011 in England]] [[Category:Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Wedding]] [[Category:Marriage, unions and partnerships in England]] [[Category:Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]]

'''Lustfaust''' is a musical project created by artists Mike Harte, Euan Rodger, [[Jamie Shovlin]], and [[Murray S Ward]], though other musicians played with them, including Eleanor Mills.
The project was originally introduced as a collection of material created by and relating to a 1970s German [[glam rock]] band, whose memorabilia were notably featured in the [[Beck's Futures]] exhibition in 2006,<ref>{{cite web |url = http://comment.independent.co.uk/columnists_a_l/david_lister/article362338.ece |author = Lister, David |title = You couldn't make it up - but they do |publisher = ''[[The Independent]]'' |date = 2006-05-06 |accessdate = 2007-07-16 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927201329/http://comment.independent.co.uk/columnists_a_l/david_lister/article362338.ece |archivedate = 2007-09-27 |df = }}</ref> and which deceived ''[[Sunday Times]]'' cultural commentator [[Waldemar Januszczak]] into running an article describing their claimed activities in giving away free copies of their music to fans. Januszczak went so far as to tip the collection for the [[Beck's Futures]] prize.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/article698383.ece | author= Januszczak, Waldemar | title = Beck's Futures | publisher = ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' | date = 2006-04-02 | accessdate = 2007-07-16}}</ref>
The exhibit was eventually runner up for the prize after Lustfaust were revealed as a fabrication, set within a combination of fictional and actual histories. Shovlin had previously gained notoriety by setting up an exhibition of art that was claimed to have been produced by a 13-year-old missing schoolgirl called [[Naomi V. Jelish]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://arts.guardian.co.uk/news/story/0,,1258210,00.html | title = Forging ahead | publisher = ''[[The Guardian]]'' | date = 2004-07-10 | accessdate = 2007-07-16}}</ref>
The work has been praised for the depth of its deception — the artists set up fake web sites about the band and added it to [[English Wikipedia]],<ref>{{cite web | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A01EED8173FF932A15754C0A9609C8B63 | author= Smith, Roberta | title = Art in Review; Lustfaust -- A Folk Anthology, 1976-1981 | publisher = ''[[The New York Times]]'' | date = 2006-07-21 | accessdate = 2007-07-16}}</ref> assembled photographs and chronologies for their tours, recorded an interview with the band's "German-Belgian frontman", and even recorded excerpts of music which were attributed to them. The deception was so deep that some viewers actually boasted of having seen the band live.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/visual_arts/article1955829.ece | author=Whitworth, Damian | title = Jamie Shovlin: A Dream Deferred at Haunch of Venison | publisher = ''[[The Times]]'' | date = 2007-06-23 | accessdate = 2007-07-16}}</ref> This was in spite of deliberate clues which had been included in the exhibition, such as notes describing the band as veering "dangerously close to [[Spinal Tap (band)|Spinal Tap]]-isms" and "an [[Obscurantism|obscurantist's]] dream".<ref>{{cite web |url = http://arts.independent.co.uk/music/features/article361157.ece |author = Jones, Alice |title = It's only mock 'n' roll but we like it |publisher = ''[[The Independent]]'' |date = 2006-05-01 |accessdate = 2007-07-16 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930155538/http://arts.independent.co.uk/music/features/article361157.ece |archivedate = 2007-09-30 |df = }}</ref>
One person who guessed at the exhibition's nature was ''[[The Times]]'' art critic [[Rachel Campbell-Johnston]]. Four days before Januszczak's piece was published, she praised the collection, but cautioned "Don’t be surprised if the entire band is a fabrication — down to its references on internet sites."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/article697935.ece | author= Campbell Johnston, Rachel | title = Beck's Futures | publisher = ''[[The Times]]'' | date = 2006-03-29 | accessdate = 2007-07-16}}</ref>
In 2007, Lustfaust began to perform live shows across Europe in numerous cities. Featuring a loose and revolving collection of musicians, by 2011 they had performed at a broad range of venues including the [[Institute of Contemporary Arts]] London, Museo Madre Napoli, Teatro Eliseo Roma and [[The Big Chill (music festival)|The Big Chill]] Festival.{{citation needed| date= June 2018}}
== References ==
{{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070918114155/http://www.lustfaust.com/ Lustfaust "official" web site] * [http://www.myspace.com/lustfaust MySpace site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071011211840/http://lustfaust-live.de/ Lustfaust live with Schneider TM] * [http://www.ica.org.uk/?lid=17551 Lustfaust live at the ICA] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120714045054/http://museomadre.it/opere.cfm?id=737 Lustfaust live at Museo Madre] * [http://www.fondazionegiuliani.org/category/projects/hiker-meat-rough-cut/?lang=en Lustfaust at Teatro Eliseo] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110106213416/http://www.bigchill.net/news/2008/04/lustfaust/ Lustfaust at The Big Chill]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} The '''Maya ICBG bioprospecting controversy''' took place in 1999–2000, when the [[International Cooperative Biodiversity Group]] led by [[ethnobiologist]] Dr. [[Brent Berlin]] was accused of engaging in unethical forms of [[bioprospecting]] ([[biopiracy]]) by several NGOs and indigenous organizations. The ICBG had as its aim to document the biodiversity of [[Chiapas]], [[Mexico]] and the ethnobotanical knowledge of the indigenous [[Maya people]] – to ascertain whether there were possibilities of developing medical products based on any of the plants used by the indigenous groups.
While the project had taken many precautions to act ethically in its dealings with the indigenous groups, the project became subject to severe criticisms of the methods used to attain prior informed consent. Among other things critics argued that the project had not devised a strategy for achieving informed consent from the entire community to which they argued the ethnobotanical knowledge belonged, and whom they argued would be affected by its commercialization. The project's directors argued that the knowledge was properly to be considered part of the public domain and therefore open to commercialization, and they argued that they had followed established [[best practice]] of ethical conduct in research to the letter. After a public discussion carried out in the media and on internet listervers the project's partners pulled out, and the ICBG was closed down in 2001, two years into its five years of allotted funding.
The Maya ICBG case was among the first to draw attention to the problems of distinguishing between benign forms of bioprospecting and unethical biopiracy, and to the difficulties of securing community participation and prior informed consent for would-be bioprospectors.
==Events==
===Background=== In 1993 [[National Institute of Health]], [[National Science Foundation]] and [[USAID]] established the [[International Cooperative Biodiversity Group]] (ICBG) program to promote collaborative research on biodiversity between American universities and research institutions in countries that harbor unique genetic resource in the form of [[biodiversity]]. The basic aim of the program was to benefit both the host community and the global scientific community by discovering and researching the possibilities for new solutions to human health problems based on previously unexplored genetic resources. It therefore seeks to [[Conservation biology|conserve biodiversity]], and to foment, encourage and support sustainable practices of usage of biological resources in the [[Global South]]. Projects would be initiated by principal investigators who would apply for a five-year period of funding, and who would establish the terms of the collaboration.<ref>Rosenthal, Joshua. The International Cooperative Biodiversity Groups (ICBG) Program. [http://69.90.183.227/doc/case-studies/abs/cs-abs-icbg.pdf]</ref>
===Maya ICBG=== In 1998 the renowned [[ethnobotany|ethnobotanist]] [[Brent Berlin]] and his wife, Dr. [[Eloise A. Berlin]], founded an [[International Cooperative Biodiversity Group]] – the Maya ICGB.<ref>B Berlin, E A Berlin, J C F Ugalde, L G Barrios, D Puett, R Nash, M Gonzalez-Espinoza. 1999. The Maya ICBG: Drug discovery, medical ethnobiology, and alternative forms of economic development in the Highland Maya region of Chiapas, Mexico. Pharmaceutical Biology. Volume: 37, Pages: 127–144</ref><ref>On Maya Medicine and the Biomedical Gaze E. N. Anderson, Brent Berlin, Elois Ann Berlin, John Richard Stepp and Ronald Nigh Current Anthropology , Vol. 43, No. 5 (December 2002), pp. 789–793</ref> The two primary investigators had more than forty years of experience working with the ethnobotany and medicinal knowledge of the Maya peoples of Chiapas.
The group was intended as a combined [[bioprospecting]] and research cooperative between the University of Georgia where the Berlins were employed, the [[El Colegio de la Frontera Sur|ECOSUR]] (a University in Chiapas), a small [[Wales|Welsh]] pharmaceutical company called Molecular Nature ltd., and a newly created [[NGO]] called PROMAYA supposed to represent the [[Indigenous peoples of Mexico|Indigenous]] [[Maya peoples|Maya]] of Chiapas. The two primary investigators had worked for more than 40 years documenting and describing the ethnobotany of the [[Tzeltal people|Tzeltal]] Maya of the region.<ref name="brown">Brown, Michael F. 2004. Who Owns Native Culture? Harvard University Press Pp. 114 -125</ref><ref>Berlin, B. and Ann Berlin, E. (2003), NGOs and the process of prior informed consent in bioprospecting research: the Maya ICBG project in Chiapas, Mexico. International Social Science Journal, 55: 629–638. doi: 10.1111/j.0020-8701.2003.05504012.x</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author= Bjørkan, Maiken|author2=Qvenild, Marte|title=The Biodiversity Discourse: Categorisation of Indigenous People in a Mexican Bio-prospecting Case|journal=Human Ecology |date=2010-04-01|publisher= Springer Netherlands|issn= 0300-7839|pages=193–204|volume= 38|issue= 2|doi=10.1007/s10745-010-9305-7}} {{subscription required|date=May 2012}}</ref>
The aim of the project was to collect and document the ethnobotanical knowledge of the Maya people of Chiapas, one of the world's [[biodiversity hotspot]]s.<ref>James V. Lavery (2007). "Case 1: Community Involvement in Biodiversity Prospecting in Mexico". Ethical Issues in International Biomedical Research: A Casebook. Oxford University Press. p. 23.</ref>
===PROMAYA=== The NGO PROMAYA was established as a foundation that could receive a percentage of the profits from any marketable products resulting from the research, as well as exercise rights over the uses to which the indigenous knowledge would be put. As such, PROMAYA represented the project's will to comply with valid ethical standards and share rights and benefits with the original holders of the medicinal knowledge. Berlin began the NGO by contributing $30,000, money he had personally received as an award for his research. The benefit share agreement on any profits derived from the project allotted the majority to the Welsh pharmaceutical company, about 12–15 percent to the University of Georgia and 2–5% to the PROMAYA NGO. The plan was that Maya communities could then petition for grants from the NGO, to be used for community development.<ref>{{cite book|author=James V. Lavery|year=2007|publisher=Oxford University Press|chapter=Case 1: Community Involvement in Biodiversity Prospecting in Mexico|title=Ethical Issues in International Biomedical Research: A Casebook|pages=21–42}}</ref><ref>[http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2005/april/tradoc_122178.pdf Preston Hardison. 2000. ICBG-Maya: A Case Study in Prior Informed Consent The Monthly Bulletin of the Canadian Indigenous Caucus on the Convention on Biological Diversity November 2000 No. 16]</ref>
===Information campaign=== The project began with an information campaign directed at the Maya communities with which they wished to cooperate. Using the medium of theater they presented the aims and goals of the project to the Maya. The information step was a vital part of the project's attempt to obtain a prior informed consent from members of the participating communities. The project made the deliberate decision not to include information about the possibility that profits would eventually be made from the knowledge collected, or information how any potential benefits would be divided among them, surmising that the chance of this actually happening was so slim that it would be a better strategy to introduce this issue when and if it were to arise. This decision would later be an important point of criticism by activists claiming that prior informed consent had not been obtained.<ref name="brown"/><ref name="hayden"/><ref name="limitations"/>
===The controversy=== Soon after being initiated, the project became the subject of harsh criticisms by indigenous activists and Mexican intellectuals who questioned how knowledge obtained from individual Maya could be patented by researchers or foreign pharmaceutical companies, how the PROMAYA NGO established by the Berlins and under their control could be considered representative of the many different Maya communities in Chiapas, and how it was possible for the knowledge that had been collective property of the Maya peoples to become suddenly privatized without the prior consent of each of the individual initual holders of the knowledge. Among the most vocal opponents of the project were RAFI, a Canadian NGO, and COMPITCH an organization of indigenous healers. Much of the criticism was circulated on listservers and in internet fora.<ref>[http://www.etcgroup.org/en/node/349 Organizaciones indigenas denuncian biopirateria en Chiapas – ]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>[http://www.etcgroup.org/en/node/348 Biopiracy Project in Chiapas, Mexico Denounced by Mayan Indigenous Groups 12/01/1999] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511140348/http://www.etcgroup.org/en/node/348 |date=11 May 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.etcgroup.org/upload/publication/304/01/geno_stopbiopiracy.pdf RAFI "Stop Biopiracy in Mexico!" Indigenous Peoples’ Organizations from Chiapas Demand Immediate Moratorium] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809224351/http://www.etcgroup.org/upload/publication/304/01/geno_stopbiopiracy.pdf |date=9 August 2011 }}</ref>
The Berlins argued that the establishment of the NGO was the only feasible way of managing benefit sharing with the community and of obtaining [[prior informed consent]], and that since the traditional knowledge was in the public domain among the Maya no individual Maya could expect remuneration.<ref>{{cite book|author=Berlin, Brent|author2=Eloise A Berlin|editor=James V. Lavery|year=2007|publisher=Oxford University Press|chapter=Comment 1.1 Private and Public Knowledge in the Debate on Bioprospecting: Implications for Local Communities and prior Informed Consent|title=Ethical Issues in International Biomedical Research: A Casebook}}</ref> As tensions mounted the Mexican partner [[UNAM]] withdrew its support for the project, and later the [[National Institute of Health|NIH]] causing the project to be closed down in 2001 – without having been able to produce any results.<ref name="hayden">{{cite book|author=Hayden, Cori|year=2003|title=When Nature Goes Public: The Making and Unmaking of Bioprospecting in Mexico|publisher=Princeton University Press|pages=100–105}}</ref><ref>[http://www.gene.ch/gentech/2001/Nov/msg00035.html GENTECH archive listserv. Subject: Chiapas biopiracy project cancelled!]</ref><ref>[http://www.texasobserver.org/archives/item/12870-222-the-plant-prospectors-who-wins-who-loses-and-who-decides-whether-its-biopiracy-or-bioprospecting--the-battle-over-plants-in-the-highlands-of-chiapas Belejack, Barbara. 2001. The Plant Prospectors: Who wins, who loses, and who decides whether it?s biopiracy or bioprospecting? The battle over plants in the Highlands of Chiapas. Texas Observer. Thursday, 21 June 2001]</ref><ref>[http://ictsd.org/i/news/biores/8699/ Bridges Trade BioRes • Volume 1 • Number 1 • 22 November 2001 Mexico Biodiversity Project Cancelled Following NGO Criticism]</ref><ref>Nigh, Ronald. 2002. Maya Medicine in the Biological Gaze: Bioprospecting Research as Herbal Fetishism(pp. 451–477) DOI: 10.1086/339745 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1086/339745] {{subscription required|date=May 2012}}</ref>
==Significance== No one seriously doubted that Berlin and the ICBG had the best intentions of ethical conduct, but nonetheless there remain serious criticisms of the way in which the project was planned and carried out, and the assumptions on which the project was based have been characterized as naïve.<ref name="hayden"/> The Maya ICBG case was among the first to draw attention to the problems of distinguishing between [[bioprospecting]] and [[biopiracy]], and to the difficulties of securing community participation and prior informed consent for bioprospectors.<ref name="limitations">{{cite book|author= Feinholz-Klip, Dafna|author2=García Barrios, Luis|author3=Cook Lucas, Julie|editor=Wynberg, Rachel|editor2=Doris Schroeder|editor3=Roger Chennells |chapter= The Limitations of Good Intent: Problems of Representation and Informed Consent in the Maya ICBG Project in Chiapas, Mexico|title= Indigenous Peoples, Consent and Benefit Sharing|year=2009|publisher= Springer Netherlands|ISBN= 978-90-481-3123-5|pages=315–331|url= https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/978-90-481-3123-5_17|doi= 10.1007/978-90-481-3123-5_17}} {{subscription required|date=May 2012}}</ref><ref>Brent Berlin; Elois Ann Berlin. 2004. Community Autonomy and the Maya ICBG Project in Chiapas, Mexico: How a Bioprospecting Project that should have succeeded failed. Human Organization; Winter 2004; 63, 4; ABI/INFORM Global pg. 472 [http://www.cbd.int/doc/articles/2004/A-00278.pdf]</ref><ref>[http://www.thenation.com/article/bio-piracy-chiapas Bio-Piracy in Chiapas. Bill Weinberg August 20, 2001 edition of The Nation.]</ref><ref>[http://www.drclas.harvard.edu/revista/articles/view/813 Hayden, Cori. 2005. Bioprospecting: Can pharmaceutical research give back? REViSta – Harvard Review of Latin America.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811052133/http://www.drclas.harvard.edu/revista/articles/view/813 |date=11 August 2011 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Hoodia]] (A famous case of ethical complications of bioprospecting in [[South Africa]]) *[[Convention on Biological Diversity]] (UN convention on ethics of bioprospecting, not ratified by the US)
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=33em}}
